articles.title: UK government strategy to protect women and girls from violence ‘seriously underfunded’
articles.trailText: Campaigners welcome plans but say poor funding means Labour’s ambitions unlikely to be met
articles.summary: The UK government’s landmark £1bn VAWG strategy pledges prevention and tougher measures but campaigners say it falls seriously short. Only £3m is set aside for a teacher training pilot, with no long-term funding for frontline support. Policies include healthy-relationship and pornography education in schools, GP referrals, £50m therapy for child victims, bans on AI nudification apps, specialist police rape units, strict restraining orders, £19m for safe housing and £550m for criminal-justice support. Charities like End Violence Against Women and the domestic abuse commissioner warn it lacks sustainable core funding and has been weakened by publication delays.

articles.title: Long waits and ‘unacceptable’ lack of data at NHS gender clinics in England, review finds
articles.trailText: Impossible to judge safety or effectiveness as adult clinics not systematically recording outcomes, Dr David Levy finds
articles.summary: Dr David Levy’s review found NHS adult gender dysphoria clinics lack systematic outcomes data, making safety and effectiveness impossible to judge. Average wait for a first appointment is 5 years 7 months, projected to reach 15 years. Referrals have surged, now 57% aged 18–25 and more birth-registered females; only 31.5% complete treatment. Long waits drive some to self-source hormones online. Clinics recorded virtually no data on detransition. Funding for non-surgical care rose from £16m to £36m (2020-25). Levy issues 20 recommendations, including mandatory outcome reporting by birth sex and launching a national improvement programme in January.

articles.title: Stay at home if you have flu symptoms, experts urge amid fears of second surge
articles.trailText: NHS England on high alert as admissions reach all-time high for this time of year
articles.summary: Experts warn of a potential second flu surge as NHS England records a seasonal high of 3,140 hospitalised flu patients per day—an 18% weekly rise and starkly above last year’s 2,629. Although admissions plateau nationally (10.3 per 100,000), England’s east (+39%) and south-west (+40%) see sharp increases, while the north-west drops 4%. NHS England’s national medical director warns hospitals are “not out of the woods yet,” as critical care beds occupied by flu patients rise. With doctors on strike compounding winter pressures, officials urge handwashing, ventilation, free jabs and staying home if symptomatic through the festive period.

articles.title: Better to be online than on hold for a GP | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Booking system benefits | Resident doctors’ strikes | Awful arpeggios | Waiting for HS2 | Stages of ageing
articles.summary: Five readers respond: Anne McLaughlin, a single mother of two disabled children, welcomes her inner-city surgery’s new online GP booking system as more efficient and less stressful than waiting on hold; Tony Fletcher challenges politicians condemning junior doctors’ strikes to account for pay lost since 2008; Edward Collier recounts suffering carpal tunnel from grade-8 piano arpeggios; David Griffiths mocks HS2’s projected four-digit start date; and Chris Southey recalls his father’s quip on three ages of man.

articles.title: Badenoch accused of making ‘deeply inaccurate’ claims about violence against women
articles.trailText: Tory leader says Labour should focus on migrants ‘from cultures that don’t respect women’ rather than tackling misogyny in schools
articles.summary: After safeguarding minister Jess Phillips unveiled a government strategy calling violence against women a ‘national emergency’ and aiming to halve these crimes within a decade, Tory leader Kemi Badenoch downplayed misogyny in schools and blamed ‘cultures that don’t respect women’ among migrants. Critics including Phillips, Imkaan’s Ghadah Alnasseri and End Violence Against Women’s Andrea Simon condemned her rhetoric as ‘deeply inaccurate’, racist and politically exploitative, noting most abuse is domestic and perpetrated by known individuals rather than recent arrivals.

articles.title: UK’s former industrial regions face ‘entrenched disadvantages’ going back decades
articles.trailText: Stark regional inequalities persist, with rising numbers of young people not in work, education or training
articles.summary: Social Mobility Commission’s report warns that former industrial regions across Britain—especially Yorkshire, the north-east, the Midlands, Wales and Scotland—endure ‘entrenched disadvantages’ from decades of deindustrialisation. Between 2022 and 2024, one in seven 16–24-year-olds were NEET. Although professional employment rose to 48.2% among 25–29-year-olds, working-class and low-income women still face barriers, and job growth is concentrated in a few urban ‘beacons of hope’ such as Aberdeen, Brighton, Bristol and Manchester. Research also highlights widening class gaps, sticky class identities and shifts in success towards wellbeing and work-life balance.

articles.title: Boys to learn difference between porn and real life to tackle misogyny in England’s schools
articles.trailText: Teachers to be given extra training as Keir Starmer warns ‘toxic ideas are taking hold early and going unchallenged’
articles.summary: England will invest millions in teacher training and behavioural courses to tackle early misogyny in schools, teaching boys from age 11 porn literacy, coercion, consent, deepfakes and healthy relationships. Part of the government’s VAWG strategy aims to halve violence against women in a decade via RSHE reforms statutory for state schools from Sept 2026, pilots on explicit image dangers and support on online harms. It outlines three pillars: countering 'manosphere' influencers, dedicated sexual offence teams with enforceable orders and £550m for victim services. Critics warn funding shortfalls may hinder specialist support and overburden schools.

articles.title: Council funding deal: who are the winners and losers – and will tax bills rise?
articles.trailText: Cash is now being distributed using a new Fair Funding formula that gives greater weighting to local authorities with high ‘deprivation’ scores
articles.summary: The government has announced a three-year funding settlement for English councils, reallocating core grants via a new Fair Funding formula weighted toward areas with high deprivation (measured by income, employment, health, housing and crime). Deprived authorities like Middlesbrough, Manchester, Birmingham and Outer London boroughs (Haringey, Newham) gain, while affluent areas (Kensington & Chelsea, Surrey) lose. Most councils plan to raise council tax by the maximum 4.99% despite some local pledges to limit increases. Though redistribution is fairer, overall resources remain tight, and many councils face continued service cuts or may resort to exceptional financial support to avoid insolvency.

articles.title: Acas offers to help break deadlock in resident doctors’ strike
articles.trailText: Conciliation service ‘in contact with all the parties involved’ as medics in England strike for 14th time
articles.summary: Acas, the UK’s conciliation service, has offered voluntary, independent mediation to end the 14th strike by resident doctors in England over pay and training posts. Director Kevin Rowan confirmed Acas is ‘ready to help’ but has only made an offer; neither the Department of Health nor the BMA’s negotiating team has formally engaged. Patients Association CEO Rachel Power urged both sides to accept talks. The BMA’s legal mandate to strike runs until 6 January and a fresh ballot could trigger new action from February or March, while ministers focus on patient safety amid a record winter flu surge.

articles.title: ‘Permanent winter’: a day in the life of a hospital dealing with flu and strikes
articles.trailText: The Guardian gained rare access to Royal Stoke university hospital to see how staff free up beds for patients in a gridlocked system
articles.summary: At Royal Stoke University Hospital, all 1,178 beds are occupied and dozens of patients are treated in ED corridors as ambulances queue for hours, pushing Opel risk level to 4. An early, record flu spike collides with a five-day junior doctors’ strike, worsening chronic "permanent winter" pressure. Staff juggle discharges, corridor beds and isolation rooms—crucial for vulnerable patients like a 74-year-old man with motor neurone disease on NIV—using hot clinics, 'In-Reach' teams and virtual wards to free space. Meticulous computer monitoring and community response teams ease bottlenecks, but IT outages and delayed transfers intensify the gridlock.

articles.title: Some of England’s most-deprived councils to get funding boost in new deal
articles.trailText: Manchester, Bradford and outer London boroughs among those to receive increases ministers hope will ‘restore pride’
articles.summary: Under a new three-year settlement, ministers will boost grant funding for 31 deprived councils—including Manchester, Birmingham, Luton, Bradford, Coventry, Derby, Haringey and Enfield—shifting resources away from affluent south-east areas. Housing and Communities Secretary Steve Reed touts it as restoring youth services, libraries and clean streets after a decade of cuts. Some northern and county councils, alongside the County Councils Network, argue London’s suburbs are biggest winners. Wealthy boroughs like Wandsworth may exceed 4.99% council-tax cap; SEN deficits near £14bn remain unaddressed.

articles.title: Rights group challenges trans-inclusive swimming policy at Hampstead Heath
articles.trailText: Allowing entry on the basis of self-identification of gender rather than biological sex is unlawful, high court told
articles.summary: Sex Matters has applied for court permission to challenge the City of London Corporation’s interim trans-inclusive swimming policy at Hampstead Heath, arguing that allowing entry to single-sex ponds and changing rooms on self-identified gender rather than biological sex breaches equality law. Since 2019 trans and non-binary swimmers have used ponds matching their identity under EHRC guidance, but following last April’s Supreme Court ruling the City withdrew its gender-identity policy and is consulting on new rules. Interim signage welcomes women and those identifying as women at the ladies’ pond and men and trans men at the men’s pond. A ruling on permission is due in January.

articles.title: Will resident doctors lose support over latest strike? | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Karen Ford says strike action is set to continue because of political posturing, while an NHS consultant worries about the deteriorating relationship among colleagues. Plus letters from John Sowerby, Dr Mussaddaq Iqbal, Gill Kelly and a final-year medical student
articles.summary: Letters debate why resident doctors’ strikes persist: retired adviser Karen Ford blames insufficient specialty training posts (30k applicants vs 10k places) and political posturing over workforce planning, noting no mortality rise in past strikes yet high NHS costs. An NHS consultant warns striking again erodes consultant support and damages inter‐professional goodwill. Other correspondents highlight scapegoating overseas doctors, misrepresented “new” posts, poor government offers, crushing debts, and urge honest, long‐term training capacity plans. A final‐year student laments low morale, misleading offers and rehashed posts, while other readers contrast doctors’ 30% pay gains with nurses’ modest rises and decry strike timing during a flu surge.

articles.title: When ‘How are you?’ becomes a painful question to answer | Letter
articles.trailText: Letters: Mark Cottle , who has metastatic prostate cancer, responds to an article by Carolin Würfel
articles.summary: Mark Cottle, from Maesygwartha, Monmouthshire, living with metastatic prostate cancer, replies to Carolin Würfel’s article about the routine “How are you?” greeting. The question, once innocuous, now forces him to choose between a perfunctory lie and exposing his harsh reality. He’s settled on “All right today” to reflect fluctuating health and his “new normal.” On better days he’ll say “Pretty good today,” but always appends “today” to signal uncertainty about tomorrow. His letter highlights the emotional burden chronic illness imposes on everyday exchanges.

articles.title: Study finds 10% of over-70s in UK could have Alzheimer’s-like changes in brain
articles.trailText: Findings mean more than 1 million people could meet NHS criteria for treatment with anti-amyloid drugs
articles.summary: First population-based real-world study of 11,500 UK adults aged 50+ using a blood p-tau217 test found Alzheimer’s-linked proteins in 10% of those over 70—implying 1m+ could meet NICE criteria for anti-amyloid therapy versus NHS’s 70,000 estimate. Prevalence rose from <8% in 50–69, ~33% in 70s, to ~66% in 90s. Published in Nature by King’s College London et al., the work underscores integrating biomarkers into NHS diagnostics and exploring early treatment despite cost barriers.

articles.title: Soaring demand causing shortage of flu jab appointments across England
articles.trailText: Few bookable slots left as NHS urges people to get vaccinated amid surge in cases because of new strain
articles.summary: Surging demand for flu jabs across England has emptied bookable slots at major pharmacy chains (Boots, Superdrug, Tesco) as hospitals grapple with record admissions driven by a mutated H3N2 strain. While over-65 uptake is 71.7%, only 35.6% of pregnant women and 37.4% of under-65s with health conditions are vaccinated. NHS leaders and the WHO warn of an early, intense season and urge broader uptake to relieve NHS pressure; community pharmacies have been asked to reorder directly from manufacturers. Independent outlets report better stocks, and NHS England affirms no national shortage with millions of doses still available.

articles.title: New flu strain putting severe pressure on healthcare across Europe, says WHO
articles.trailText: At least 27 of 38 countries in WHO’s European region are reporting high or very high influenza activity, body says
articles.summary: WHO warns that a new A(H3N2) sub-clade K flu strain is driving an early surge across Europe, with 27 of 38 countries reporting high or very high activity. Over half of symptomatic patients in Ireland, Serbia, Slovenia and the UK test positive, as the season began four weeks early. Health systems in the UK, Germany, France, Spain, Romania and Hungary face severe strain. WHO urges vaccination—especially for older adults, pregnant women, children and health workers—plus masks and isolation if unwell. Early UK data show vaccines cut severe illness. Peak is expected late December–early January; misinformation remains a concern.

articles.title: ‘It’s shattered our family’: how illicit offshore bookies exploit struggling gamblers who are trying to quit
articles.trailText: International network appears designed to profit from gamblers who have signed up with UK self-exclusion scheme GamStop
articles.summary: The Long family’s son Ollie Long died by suicide after repeated gambling relapses, driven by unlicensed offshore bookmakers exploiting UK self-exclusion scheme GamStop. Affiliate sites advertising “Not on GamStop” casinos like MyStake, Donbet and Velobet in Curaçao bypass UK licensing, funneling vulnerable punters into illicit platforms. Industry data show offshore stakes rose from £122m in 2022 to £583m in 2024. Regulators face legal and technical barriers to block these sites, prompting calls for stronger enforcement, search-engine accountability and targeted funding to curb black-market gambling.

articles.title: Caesareans overtake natural vaginal births in England for first time, NHS data finds
articles.trailText: 45% of births were through C-sections, 44% through natural vaginal births and 11% assisted with forceps or ventouse
articles.summary: NHS data for April 2024–March 2025 reveals 45% of 542,235 births in England were by C-section—outpacing natural vaginal deliveries (44%) for the first time—with 11% assisted by forceps or ventouse. Elective C-sections rose to 20% and emergency to 25.1%, both record highs. Vaginal delivery remains most common under age 30, while C-sections prevail for women 30+ (59% at age 40+). Experts attribute the shift to more complex pregnancies, older maternal age, obesity, service closures and intervention-heavy maternity care.

articles.title: Resident doctors in England begin five days of strike action
articles.trailText: NHS leaders warn ‘more patients are likely to feel the impact of this round of strikes than the previous two’
articles.summary: Resident doctors in England began five days of strike action after overwhelmingly rejecting the government’s latest deal—83% voted against an offer boosting training places but withholding a pay rise. The British Medical Association and Health Secretary Wes Streeting failed to reach consensus in final talks, triggering the 14th strike since March 2023. BMA leaders demand a multi-year pay plan and genuinely new posts to avert a looming jobs crisis. NHS England warns that strikes amid record winter flu pressures will disrupt more patients than previous walkouts and deny staff a Christmas break. The Department of Health says it sought agreement and now aims to limit service disruption.

articles.title: The Guardian’s Hope appeal raises more than £350,000 for charities
articles.trailText: The 2025 appeal is helping charities that bring divided communities together and promote tolerance
articles.summary: The Guardian’s Hope appeal has raised over £350,000 in under two weeks, including £30,000 during its annual telethon featuring 40+ journalists like John Crace, Polly Toynbee and Simon Hattenstone. Funds support five grassroots charities—Citizens UK, The Linking Network, Locality, Hope Unlimited and Who Is Your Neighbour?—that foster empathy, community cohesion and tackle racism and xenophobia via projects like Citizens UK’s Walk of Hope, Back on the Map’s neighbourhood revival and interfaith school programmes. Editor Katharine Viner and trustees praise reader generosity for advancing tolerance, affordable housing, youth clubs, arts initiatives and refugee welcome schemes.

articles.title: Adults in England with eating disorders wait up to 700 days for treatment, report finds
articles.trailText: Audit finds on average adults wait twice as long as children for assessment and more than 10 times as long to be treated
articles.summary: NAED’s first national audit (Jan–May) reveals stark waits for adults with eating disorders in England: median 28 days to assessment and 42 days to treatment—some up to 700 days—compared with children’s 14-day/4-day medians and 450-day max. There are 69 adult vs 93 youth community teams and 33 vs 54 inpatient units. At audit time 3,855 adults awaited assessment and 4,537 treatment; 71% of teams cite demand exceeding capacity. Charity Beat decries a widening adult–child service gap, postcode lottery for disorders like binge eating and ARFID, and calls for expanded local intensive community/day services. NHS England says it will act on findings to drive down waits and urges GP referrals.

articles.title: Wes Streeting and resident doctors urged to agree to mediation to end strikes
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Health bosses say mediation urgently needed to break deadlock as resident doctors prepare to strike from Wednesday
articles.summary: NHS Confederation has urged Health Secretary Wes Streeting and the BMA’s resident doctors committee to accept independent mediation to resolve a 33-month dispute over pay and training, ahead of a five-day strike starting 7am Wednesday. Resident doctors demand a 26% pay rise over three years and more training places, while Streeting has increased offers from 1,000 to 4,000 spots. Last-ditch talks were ‘constructive’ but deadlocked. Hospitals have cancelled tens of thousands of procedures, with patients warned as collateral damage, and NHS head Sir Jim Mackey condemned the action as ‘cruel’. The BMA may reballot medics after its current strike mandate expires on 6 January.

articles.title: Striking resident doctors are digging in. History suggests this will go on and on
articles.trailText: The health secretary is winning the battle of public opinion but has not won over those who matter most in this dispute
articles.summary: With 7.42 m hospital tests and 6.24 m patients waiting, 18% of A&E cases in corridors and 16,600 annual excess deaths from bed delays, NHS pressures frame the latest walkout. Resident doctors in England begin their 14th strike in 33 months—days 55–59 of a dispute over a 26% pay rise. After eight Tory-era and three Labour-era strikes, BMA members have rejected three training-place offers by 83% to 17%. Streeting has won public opinion (33% support vs 58% oppose) but not medics’ trust. With the legal mandate ending on 6 January, a breakthrough looks unlikely before next year.

articles.title: NHS must learn lessons of Covid to overcome winter flu, say experts
articles.trailText: If not, academics say people will continue to get sick and die while schools close and hospitals are overwhelmed
articles.summary: As flu cases surge and resident doctor strikes loom, three UK academics argue NHS should apply Covid lessons—boost flu vaccine uptake through wider eligibility and accessible delivery in schools and workplaces; expand paid sick leave so unwell people can isolate; and improve ventilation and air quality. They caution without these measures, illness, deaths, school closures and hospital overload will persist. Highlighting an early, fast-spreading strain and inadequate UK sick pay vs Germany’s, they call for long-term political commitment and communal responsibility to protect vulnerable groups this winter.

articles.title: Dentists in England to be paid more for emergency NHS appointments
articles.trailText: British Dental Association says government’s plan has ‘no new money behind it’ and further changes needed
articles.summary: Dentists in England will from April be paid via a standardised package to deliver more emergency and complex NHS treatments—aiming to ease “dental deserts” and reduce DIY dentistry after patients were denied urgent care, sometimes resorting to self-extraction. Government says new fees could save patients £225 and mark the biggest contract modernisation in years, incentivising urgent pain, infection and gum disease care in a single appointment. The BDA warns there’s “no new money” and demands deeper reform, while Healthwatch calls for transparent data on 700,000 promised urgent slots.

articles.title: Alan Milburn launches major UK review into rising inactivity among young people
articles.trailText: Report to highlight ‘uncomfortable truths’ and could recommend ‘radical change’, former health secretary says
articles.summary: Former health secretary Alan Milburn has launched an independent review into Britain’s rising inactivity among 16- to 24-year-olds, with nearly one million NEET (not in education, employment or training). He vows to confront “uncomfortable truths” and recommend “radical” policy solutions. A panel including Charlie Mayfield, Andy Haldane and Dame Louise Casey will examine mental health, long-term sickness and disability—now cited by over a quarter of NEETs—and regional and socioeconomic disparities, with risks more than double for disadvantaged backgrounds and highest in the North-East, North-West and Midlands. Backed by a call for evidence from young people and experts, the review will issue an interim report in spring and a full report in summer.

articles.title: Officials fear NHS will be hit hard after resident doctors reject latest offer
articles.trailText: Wes Streeting and BMA urged to seek mediation as hospitals in England struggle amid flu outbreak
articles.summary: Resident doctors in England rejected the government’s final pay-and-training offer 83%–17%, triggering a five-day strike from Dec 18. Hospitals must cancel about 38,500 outpatient appointments and procedures, including surgery, chemotherapy and radiotherapy, amid a record flu surge. Health secretary Wes Streeting and the BMA face pressure to seek independent mediation in this nearly three-year dispute over pay (doctors demand 26% vs 28.9% granted since 2022) and training bottlenecks (doubling places from 2,000 to 4,000 but no 2025–26 pay rise). Hospitals warn winter pressures could put patient safety at risk.

articles.title: The slow death of social housing – and its original purpose | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Guardian readers respond to a report by the homelessness charity Crisis and our editorial
articles.summary: Letters contest the Guardian’s claim that social housing was solely for those unable to afford private rents, noting post-war estates like Becontree and Harold Hill were built to rehouse ordinary working families in decent, modern homes. They argue that Thatcher’s sell-off transferred up to half of this stock to often poorly maintained private landlords. Tom Murtha, writing a decade ago, warned housing associations would abandon the poorest; recent Crisis and Shelter reports confirm low-income applicants are shut out and homelessness is surging, prompting calls for a new government-funded, locally managed social housing model.

articles.title: Children need mental health care provided by humans, not chatbots | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Dr Roman Raczka says artificial intelligence can’t replace therapist-led care, even though it can offer benefits
articles.summary: Dr Roman Raczka argues children need human-delivered mental health care despite AI’s growing use, noting that a quarter of teenagers now turn to ChatGPT amid rising NHS therapy waiting lists and one in five young people experiencing mental health conditions. Overreliance on AI support risks triggering a new public health emergency. Though AI offers benefits, it must be integrated to augment, not replace, therapist-led care. Raczka calls on the government to urgently expand the mental health workforce and guarantee timely, face-to-face support for struggling youths.

articles.title: Resident doctors in England vote to go ahead with strike
articles.trailText: Five-day strike to start on Wednesday as Wes Streeting’s offer is overwhelmingly rejected by BMA members
articles.summary: Resident doctors in England voted 83% (35,107 of 55,000) to reject Health Sec. Wes Streeting’s latest offer—more training posts but no pay rise—and will strike for five days from Wednesday to Monday amid an ongoing pay and jobs dispute. They demand a 26% salary increase to restore real-terms pay to 2008-09 levels. Streeting calls the action “irresponsible” and warns of patient harm during an NHS winter crisis driven by super-flu; the BMA accuses him of offering “too little, too late,” citing no net new jobs. This marks their 14th walkout since March 2023.

articles.title: Tell us: have you ever had an allergic reaction caused by your clothes?
articles.trailText: Synthetic fabrics for clothes can be treated with a range of hazardous chemicals which can cause an allergic reaction. If you think this is happened to you, we’d like to hear from you
articles.summary: Researchers warn synthetic fabrics, especially from fast fashion, can be treated with hazardous chemicals—dyes containing heavy metals such as lead, antimicrobial agents and anti-wrinkle treatments—that may trigger skin irritation, respiratory issues or other allergic reactions. The Guardian solicits reader stories: which garments and brands provoked symptoms, their severity and duration, any medical interventions, long-term health impacts and subsequent changes to shopping habits. Include any medical consultations or hospital visits, chronic conditions or behavioral shifts. Responses will inform reporting on clothing-related chemical exposures. Submit via our form; see terms and privacy policy.

articles.title: Europe’s housing costs akin to ‘new pandemic’, warns Barcelona mayor
articles.trailText: Jaume Collboni and 16 other city leaders urge EU to unleash billions in funding as it prepares to tackle crisis
articles.summary: Barcelona mayor Jaume Collboni and 16 fellow city leaders have branded Europe’s soaring housing costs a “new pandemic,” urging the EU’s first-ever housing plan to include a €300 billion-a-year affordable housing fund. Their Mayors for Housing alliance, representing over 20 million residents from Athens to Amsterdam, demands NextGenerationEU-style investment and seats at the decision-making table. Between 2010 and 2023, EU house prices rose 48% and rents 22%, while nearly 10% of households spend over 40% of income on housing. Leaders warn inaction risks social cohesion, democracy and fuels populist backlash.

articles.title: Call for system that frees rape suspects as alternative to bail to be scrapped in England and Wales
articles.trailText: ‘Released under investigation’ leads to uncertainty and distress for both victim and accused, say campaigners
articles.summary: Campaigners urge government to scrap 'released under investigation' for rape suspects in England & Wales, introduced under the Policing & Crime Act 2017 as a bail alternative without statutory time limits. FOI data shows over 1,800 suspects have been RUI for at least three years, with nearly 800 released in 2020-21. Sir Brian Leveson recommends ending RUI and reinstating conditional bail. Rape Crisis, EVAW and Rights of Women warn RUI causes uncertainty, retraumatisation, evidence decay and prosecution barriers. Victims face long waits amid court backlogs, harming wellbeing. The Home Office is reviewing Leveson’s recommendations as part of its strategy to halve violence against women in a decade.

articles.title: People pulling own teeth due to lack of urgent NHS dental care in England, watchdog finds
articles.trailText: Emergency help should be available, but some being forced to travel 100 miles or go private, says Healthwatch England
articles.summary: Healthwatch England finds many in urgent dental pain in England denied NHS care despite guidance, leading to self-extraction of teeth and unprescribed antibiotic use. Patients face months-long waits for routine care, hours on hold to NHS 111, 100+ mile journeys or costly private treatment, with 20% rise in dental calls. Mystery calls found no urgent slots. Watchdog urges monthly reporting on 700,000 extra annual urgent appointments, legal right to NHS registration, contract reform to boost prevention and capacity. DHSC pledges reforms and extra appointments.

articles.title: Hospitals in England ‘face dangerous winter overcrowding due to discharge delays’
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Analysis of NHS data shows rise in patients ‘stranded’ in beds as flu crisis hits and resident doctors’ strikes loom
articles.summary: Analysis by the Health Foundation shows delayed discharges in England rose from 10.1% to 11% of bed days July–Sept 2025, adding 19,000 lost bed days and ~3,800 more stranded patients monthly. An early ‘flu-nami’ surge—potentially filling 8,000 beds—and a five-day junior doctor strike will deplete capacity, driving ambulance queues, corridor care and higher A&E mortality. Cash-strapped councils, an ageing population and NHS cuts fuel bottlenecks costing ~£200m/month. NHS is fast-tracking winter prep, vaccinating over 17m and injecting £4bn into social care.

articles.title: Wes Streeting is right to examine questions of overdiagnosis | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Dr Richard Hassall , Allen Frances and Natasha Fairbairn respond to a column by John Harris which argued that the health secretary should not jump on a rightwing bandwagon about mental health
articles.summary: Three respondents defend Wes Streeting’s inquiry into UK mental health services against John Harris’s charge of political overreach, arguing that the review’s focus on overdiagnosis is clinically warranted amid overstretched, underresourced CAMHS—autism assessment waits have risen from 4–6 months to two years. They highlight Suzanne O’Sullivan’s call for purposeful, practical diagnoses, while Allen Frances cites the DSM-IV era surge in psychiatric labels—driven by conflating distress with disorder, loose criteria, internet self-diagnosis, pharma influence and benefits linkage—misallocating resources to the “worried well.” Natasha Fairbairn adds ADHD remains underdiagnosed, with NHS capacity insufficient to assess the estimated two million UK cases.

articles.title: NHS administrators are vital to patients | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: They are not ‘bureaucrats’ who must be culled, writes Michael Joffe
articles.summary: Michael Joffe warns that systemic failures in NHS administration — from one in seven GP referrals 'vanishing' to missed hospital appointments and investigations — harm large numbers of patients. He argues that administrators are competent yet lack a robust, coordinated system ensuring coverage for absences and accountability. The burden shifts onto doctors and nurses, exacerbating stress and burnout. Joffe calls for valuing well-managed administration rather than cutting 'bureaucracy', noting similar liaison breakdowns across public services.

articles.title: Public should heed new rules on single-sex spaces, says Britain’s equalities chief
articles.trailText: Mary-Ann Stephenson says official guidance will not usher in ‘toilet police’ in businesses and public places
articles.summary: EHRC chair Mary-Ann Stephenson urged businesses and public bodies to follow soon-to-be-published guidance on single-sex spaces, drafted in response to an April supreme court ruling that defines women by biological sex. Leaked text advises toilets and similar facilities remain for same-sex use only, effectively barring transgender people from rooms matching their gender identity. While insisting there will be no “toilet police,” Stephenson said venues should improve signage, explanations and alternative provisions if complaints arise. She stressed balancing women’s need for secure spaces with trans rights. Her appointment drew criticism for funding gender-critical lawyer Allison Bailey’s case. Stephenson also warned against rising race-based discrimination in public discourse.

articles.title: DWP needs overhaul to restore trust after carer’s allowance scandal, adviser says
articles.trailText: Liz Sayce, who led inquiry into department’s failures, ‘distressed’ at carers being blamed for running up huge overpayments
articles.summary: Prof Liz Sayce’s review of the DWP carer’s allowance scandal found systemic, leadership and cultural failures—not carers’ errors—led to hundreds of thousands of overpayments, mental distress and possible wrongful fraud convictions. Distressed by senior civil servant Neil Couling blaming carers, Sayce urged a management overhaul to rebuild trust. Ministers have backed 40 recommendations, launched a £75m, three-year reform plan, ordered reassessment of 200,000 historical cases (cancelling or reducing about 26,000 debts), pledged clearer guidance and transparency. She praised whistleblower Enrico La Rocca for exposing the long-ignored issues.

articles.title: Police forces in England and Wales to get units that tackle violence against women
articles.trailText: Specialist teams will deal with offences such as rape and stalking as part of VAWG strategy, home secretary says
articles.summary: By 2029, all police forces in England and Wales must establish specialist rape and sexual offences teams led by trained investigators addressing rape mythology and cultural bias, with officers as sexual violence first responders. No extra funding is provided; costs absorbed from existing budgets. Meanwhile, domestic abuse protection orders—piloted in Greater Manchester, London, north Wales and Cleveland—will roll out nationally, covering economic abuse, coercive and controlling behaviour, stalking and honour-based violence, with judicial sanctions like electronic tagging, exclusion zones and up to five years’ jail for breaches. The government also allocates almost £2m for covert online VAWG squads under its VAWG national emergency strategy.

articles.title: Psychedelic treatments show promise for OCD while cannabis doesn’t, review finds
articles.trailText: Psychiatry professor theorizes that the difference is related to how the substances interact with areas of the brain
articles.summary: With SSRIs and exposure therapy failing in 40–60% of patients, Van Ameringen’s review finds psychedelics—especially psilocybin—offer stronger signals of OCD symptom relief by reducing connectivity in the default mode network, whereas cannabinoids show no lasting effect despite CB1 receptor activity. Preliminary trials by Ching and planned studies by Sherif emphasize therapeutic support, minimal facilitation and strict ethical protocols. Researchers caution that DEA restrictions and functional unblinding challenge rigorous evaluation but stress the need for controlled, culturally respectful psychedelic research.

articles.title: Risk to women of severe bleeding after giving birth at five-year high in England
articles.trailText: Rate rises by 19% compared with 2020, prompting fresh concerns about NHS maternity care
articles.summary: In England, postpartum haemorrhage rates climbed from 27 to 32 per 1,000 births in 2024—a 19% rise since 2020—totaling 16,780 cases, the highest in five years despite fewer births. As haemorrhage remains the UK’s leading maternal death cause, the Lib Dems demand a ‘maternity rescue plan’ amid CQC warnings that two-thirds of units are unsafe. Experts attribute the uptick to obesity and older maternal age. The health secretary has launched a rapid review and national taskforce. Data since trusts began reporting in 2020 cover hemorrhages >1.5L per birth; PPH now causes 7% of UK maternal deaths. Baroness Amos’s inquiry warns of ‘tragic consequences’ from substandard care.

articles.title: ‘People will listen’: turning anger into community pride in North Shields
articles.trailText: A tour of local ‘wins’ shows how the charity Citizens UK is working with residents to build a better, fairer society
articles.summary: In North Shields, Citizens UK’s “Walk of Hope,” led by Father Chris Hughes and organiser Sara Bryson, shows how grassroots organising channels community anger into constructive change. Teenagers from St Thomas More pressed MPs and ministers to secure a full-time school counsellor, a refurbished CAMHS centre and a pledge for 8,500 school mental-health staff nationwide. Mish Sony’s group clinched the “Get Around for a Pound” youth bus-metro scheme. MumsSpace volunteers transformed Alexander Scott park via litter-picks, and primary pupils won new bins and a zebra crossing. Amid rising scapegoating of immigrants, these wins rebuild local trust and reimagine democracy.

articles.title: ‘Beyond belief’ that resident doctors could strike amid flu crisis, says Starmer
articles.trailText: Exclusive: PM’s outspoken attack on stoppages planned for 17-22 December risks inflaming tensions with medics
articles.summary: Labour leader Keir Starmer denounced a planned 17–22 December junior doctor strike amid a record flu surge, calling it “beyond belief” and warning it could jeopardize NHS care. Health Secretary Wes Streeting pressed doctors to accept extra training places with no pay rise; the BMA accused ministers of scaremongering and refused to rule out strikes over a “poor” offer. Hospitals are canceling operations as flu admissions climb 55% week-on-week, straining resources. Charities and unions warn the dispute deepens the NHS’s worst crisis since Covid, urging a negotiated solution.

articles.title: Almost dead? The GP will see you now | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Booking appointments online | Ambridge beavers | San Serriffe invasion | Nun benefits | Stages of ageing
articles.summary: Five readers lampooned recent Guardian features: Rachel Phipps (Oxfordshire) decried the new online GP booking system that offers pharmacist calls and denies face-to-face slots unless you’re ‘almost dead’; Tracey Francis (Edinburgh) quipped the wild Norfolk beaver must have escaped from Ambridge; Richard Barnard (Essex) joked an invasion of fictional San Serriffe would begin with an ‘Arial bombardment’; Huw Griffith (Alicante) punned that being a nun offers ‘both worlds’; Pete Bibby (Sheffield) proposed adding a ‘writing-to-the-Guardian’ stage of ageing.

articles.title: Tell us: are you a young person from the UK who has recently moved abroad?
articles.trailText: We would like to hear from young people who have left the UK in recent months –or are planning to do so
articles.summary: The Guardian is seeking firsthand accounts from young UK residents aged 18–30 who have moved abroad in recent months or plan to. We want to uncover motivations ranging from pursuit of higher salaries and career progression to escaping rising living costs and tax pressures in the UK. Tell us how you chose your destination, managed relocation logistics, adapted to local culture, and how the experience compares to expectations. Submissions will inform our analysis of emerging youth migration trends and policy implications. Please review our privacy policy and terms of service. Technical assistance is available for form access.

articles.title: As NHS braces for record flu cases, is the strain active in continental Europe too?
articles.trailText: Mutations thought to be spreading flu faster and earlier, with vaccines less effective than hoped
articles.summary: The UK’s NHS is preparing for a record‐early flu surge driven by a drifted H3N2 subclade K strain—descended from Australia’s worst season—reaching 11% positivity by early November. Continental Europe’s season began 2–4 weeks early: Germany reports rising H3N2 alongside H1N1, France sees equal H1N1/H3N2 activity, while Spain, Romania, Hungary and Ireland face spikes in cases and hospitalisations. Current vaccines are mismatched to subclade K, cutting effectiveness but still offering 70–75% protection for children and 30–40% for adults against severe disease. Officials strongly urge vaccination, noting most ICU flu patients are unvaccinated elderly or high‐risk individuals.

articles.title: Tell us: how are you being affected by the rise in UK flu cases?
articles.trailText: We want to hear from the public and healthcare workers about the impact of the ‘worst-case scenario’ flu crisis
articles.summary: Flu infections climbed by 55% in England in a single week, pushing hospitals, GP practices and ambulance services towards critical capacity as the NHS warns of a 'worst-case scenario' within a fortnight. Concurrently, junior doctors in England plan strike action next week over pay disputes, heightening concerns about staffing and patient care. The Guardian is seeking firsthand accounts from patients who have fallen ill, individuals changing behaviour to avoid infection, and healthcare workers managing increased workloads. Readers can share experiences via an online form, with links provided to terms of service and privacy policy.

articles.title: ‘He was struggling with his breath. I sat beside him and sang’: the choir who sing to people on their deathbeds
articles.trailText: Just as lullabies send babies to sleep, so songs can help those at the other end of life on their way. The leader of a Threshold Choir reveals what they do – and the personal tragedies that convinced her we need to get better at dealing with death
articles.summary: In Devon, singer Nickie Aven leads MoorHeart, a 10-member Threshold Choir that volunteers a cappella, lullaby-style songs at the bedsides of terminally ill patients—whether at home or in hospices—to foster calm, connection and a peaceful transition. Originating from US founder Kate Munger’s 1990s chapters, Threshold Choirs now total around 200 worldwide. Members need only hold a tune and embrace death’s realities; they also perform at funerals and life-threshold events like baby blessings. Aven’s own losses—her husband’s glioblastoma and her son’s overdose—drive her mission, alongside grief workshops and interfaith ministry, to normalize end-of-life conversations and support families through ritualized singing.

articles.title: ‘Cruel’ amendments being used to thwart assisted dying bill, says lead MP
articles.trailText: Kim Leadbeater warns 1,150 Lords amendments are ‘unnecessary’ and designed to run down the clock
articles.summary: Kim Leadbeater, who spearheaded the assisted dying bill, says peers in the House of Lords have tabled over 1,150 "totally unnecessary" and "very cruel" amendments—ranging from filming terminally ill patients, barring those who travelled abroad from eligibility, to financial screenings of relatives—to stall and potentially derail the legislation. With only 80 amendments examined in three debate days, supporters fear time will run out before the next session. Peers argue detailed scrutiny is vital, while crossbenchers and Labour advocates push for safeguards, high-court oversight, and protections against coercion.

articles.title: Strikes could collapse flu-hit NHS amid worst crisis since Covid, says Streeting
articles.trailText: Health secretary urges resident doctors, who are to strike from 17 December, to accept his offer to end dispute
articles.summary: Health Secretary Wes Streeting warns that planned resident doctor strikes Dec 17–22, coupled with a 55% surge in winter flu admissions (averaging 2,660 hospitalised daily), could be “the Jenga piece” that collapses the NHS in its worst crisis since Covid. He urges the British Medical Association to accept the government’s latest offer—priority specialty training roles, 1,000 extra posts from 2026 and paid exam fees—and calls for a Jan strike reschedule. The BMA opens an online member ballot closing Monday to decide. Dr Chris Streather acknowledges strain but says capacity is stronger than during the pandemic.

articles.title: Guardian charity appeal donations top £200,000 before annual telethon
articles.trailText: Milestone reached as journalists including Polly Toynbee and John Crace prepare for fundraising event on Saturday
articles.summary: The Guardian’s first-week Hope appeal has raised over £200,000 for five grassroots charities (Citizens UK, The Linking Network, Locality, Hope Unlimited and Who Is Your Neighbour?) that unite divided communities, tackling racism and promoting inclusion through projects—from interfaith school exchanges in Bradford to Sunderland rebuilding after 2024 riots. Ahead of Saturday’s 10am–6pm telethon, journalists including Polly Toynbee, John Crace and Jonathan Liew will take calls at 0203 353 4368. Editor Katharine Viner emphasized hope as an antidote to polarisation, while Citizens UK CEO Matthew Bolton thanked readers for supporting community leadership and resilience.

articles.title: ‘It’s hardly an inconvenience’: your views on wearing a mask to combat flu
articles.trailText: With a record number of flu patients in hospital, Britons are weighing up the merits of face coverings
articles.summary: Facing 1,717 daily flu hospitalisations and 69 in critical care, England’s health trusts urge symptomatic mask use while Downing Street merely suggests it. Britons are split: supporters—from a surgeon to a charity worker—view face coverings as minor inconveniences that curb spread and protect others, recalling Covid protocols; detractors point to discomfort, sensory needs, limited efficacy, or rely on vaccination and staying home. The debate highlights mixed public health messaging, politicisation and diverse individual circumstances. Some decry post-Covid germaphobia and politicisation of disease prevention, arguing the focus should be on vaccinations and proper isolation over overstated mask benefits.

articles.title: Inquiry to be held into north-east England NHS trust after patient deaths
articles.trailText: Health secretary announces investigation into Tees, Esk and Wear Valleys trust that has seen young patients take their own lives
articles.summary: Health secretary Wes Streeting has announced a statutory public inquiry into Tees, Esk and Wear Valleys NHS foundation trust after several patient suicides over the past decade, including 17-year-olds Nadia Sharif and Christie Harnett and 18-year-old Emily Moore. The inquiry, triggered after families’ sustained campaigning and following a previous £215,000 fine for safety breaches, aims to uncover failures in mental healthcare delivery at the trust’s hospitals in Middlesbrough and County Durham. MP Andy McDonald described the move as a ‘huge relief’ for bereaved families. Trust CEO Alison Smith pledged transparency and commitment to meaningful reforms to guarantee safe, dignified care.

articles.title: NHS bracing for worst ever winter crisis in next fortnight amid rising flu cases
articles.trailText: Hospitals treating record numbers of flu patients but worst is yet to come as medical bosses urge people to get vaccinated
articles.summary: The NHS warns of its worst winter crisis yet as flu admissions jump 55% to 2,660 daily—an early, virulent H3N2 surge compounded by RSV and COVID-19 is overwhelming hospitals, GP surgeries and ambulances. Senior executives describe potential ‘mayhem’, with multiple trusts declaring critical incidents. Keir Starmer and Health Secretary Wes Streeting condemned the BMA’s planned five-day junior doctor strike, urging staff to accept a new pay offer. The UKHSA calls for urgent flu vaccinations—take-up remains under 40% in key risk groups—and advises masking and social distancing ahead of Christmas. Planned care waits hit 7.4m, underscoring chronic workforce and capacity gaps.

articles.title: What is happening to the assisted dying bill in the House of Lords?
articles.trailText: Peers have submitted an extraordinary number of amendments, slowing its progress and raising risk of failure
articles.summary: The assisted dying bill, which would legalise assisted dying for terminally ill adults with under six months to live in England and Wales, is stalled in the Lords committee stage after peers submitted over 1,100 amendments. Unlike the Commons, Lords members must debate each amendment group by group, risking delay until the session ends, possibly without any substantive vote. Opponents including Baroness Ilora Finlay and Lord Tanni Grey-Thompson have driven key amendments on coercion and safeguards, while some Conservative peers pressed arguably time-wasting changes. The government has added extra sitting days, but if the bill runs out of time it could fall, forcing backers to consider using the Parliament Act in the next session.

articles.title: Weighing up the risks and benefits of prostate cancer screening | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Aamir Ahmed , Dr Graham Simpson , Adrian Bell and David Gollancz respond to a letter by a reader whose husband died of the disease after delaying getting a PSA test
articles.summary: Letters debate routine PSA screening: Ahmed endorses the UK NSC’s decision against mass PSA tests, citing low sensitivity/specificity, overdiagnosis and unnecessary treatments; Simpson references a 2023 NEJM trial showing no mortality benefit from surgery or radiotherapy vs observation and warns of severe side-effects; Bell shares his case of asymptomatic PSA detection at 62 leading to successful prostatectomy; Gollancz urges adoption of mpMRI as a safer, more accurate non-invasive screening tool.

articles.title: Senior opponents of assisted dying bill urge Lords not to deliberately block it
articles.trailText: Letter says there is danger of Lords losing legitimacy as more than 1,000 amendments tabled, delaying any vote
articles.summary: Former ministers Justin Madders, Nia Griffith and Debbie Abrahams, initially opposed the assisted dying bill, have written to the Guardian urging Lords not to filibuster its committee stage, which has seen just 80 of 1,150+ amendments debated in three days. They warn that delaying tactics by the unelected chamber risk undermining democratic legitimacy and Commons primacy. Senior crossbenchers like Lord Carlile and pressure group Unlock Democracy are pushing for faster progress, including amendments to restore high court judges’ roles. Campaigners, such as Dame Esther Rantzen, caution the bill may lapse on procedural grounds, while sceptics insist detailed expert scrutiny is justified.

articles.title: ‘We don’t have enough rooms to isolate’: NHS doctor reveals impact of rise in flu cases
articles.trailText: As corridor care has become the norm, safest option for those with flu symptoms is to contact GP or NHS 111 and try to stay home
articles.summary: As flu cases spike across the UK, Amir Hassan, emergency medicine consultant and medical director at Epsom and St Helier NHS trust, reports overwhelming pressure on emergency departments and wards. Limited isolation rooms in older hospital buildings have normalised corridor care, raising infection risks. He urges patients with cold or flu symptoms to self-care using NHS 111, GPs, or pharmacies and reserve hospital visits for severe breathlessness. High-risk groups and children should get free immunisations. Widespread staff illness and rising admissions of frail elderly and some young patients make this winter especially challenging.

articles.title: NHS ‘facing worst-case scenario’ as hospital flu cases jump 55% in a week
articles.trailText: Number of people in England being treated remains at record level for this time of year with daily average of 2,660
articles.summary: NHS hospitals in England saw flu admissions jump 55% in a week to an average 2,660 daily patients, the highest for December. Year-on-year figures rose from 1,861 in 2024 and 402 in 2023. NHS medical director Prof. Pandit warns of a “worst-case scenario” amid record A&E demand, ambulance strains and looming junior doctor strikes. UKHSA data show hospitalisation rates up to 10.05 per 100,000, with vaccine uptake at 71.7% in over-65s but low among pregnant women (35.6%) and high-risk under-65s (37.4%). Experts cite a mutated H3N2 “super flu” strain driving this surge and urge vaccination ahead of Christmas.

articles.title: Starmer says resident doctors would be irresponsible to strike in face of flu crisis
articles.trailText: PM urges medics to ‘do the responsible thing, accept the offer that’s on the table, and we can all move forward’
articles.summary: PM Keir Starmer urged resident doctors to cancel a planned five-day strike next week amid a record “super flu” surge—2,660 inpatients daily—in England. Ministers offered more specialist training places, doubling vacancies, but offered no extra pay beyond a recent rise. The BMA called the offer a “mixed bag” and will ballot members via an external survey; only a simple majority could halt strikes. Health Secretary Wes Streeting and NHS chiefs hope the proposal resolves a long-running dispute over pay erosion and workforce shortages before Christmas pressures peak.

articles.title: Campaigners in legal effort to suspend trial of puberty blockers in England
articles.trailText: Activists argue research could harm children but NHS adviser says study is necessary to allow families to make informed decisions
articles.summary: Campaigners from the Bayswater Support Group, psychotherapist James Esses and detransitioner Keira Bell have launched legal action to suspend the NHS-funded Pathways puberty-blocker trial in England, arguing it endangers vulnerable trans and non-binary children with potential irreversible fertility harm and rests on weak evidence. The King’s College London study, set to enroll 226 participants aged 10 to 15.9, randomises one arm to two-year blockers and the other to a one-year delay. Despite MHRA and HRA approvals and oversight by health secretary Wes Streeting, critics call for observational follow-ups of past patients instead of randomized drugs.

articles.title: ‘This country’s divided’: how a Sunderland charity is changing that – one house, park and shop at a time
articles.trailText: Far-right rhetoric fuelled rioting here in 2024, but Back on the Map is helping to unite the community, through good accommodation, new shops, and an aim to genuinely uplift and improve people’s lives
articles.summary: After 2024 anti-Muslim riots fuelled by far-right misinformation, Back on the Map has transformed Hendon by acquiring and renovating derelict housing and shops, offering “social lettings” to vulnerable tenants and reinvesting profits into community centres, training sessions and park gardening. The charity’s purple-branded properties foster tenant pride and neighbourly bonds, revive local high streets with cooperative traders, challenge anti-immigrant myths through calm dialogue and programme social clubs to rebuild trust, belonging and optimism across ethnic and socioeconomic divides. Its model, built on hyperlocal consultation and collaboration, is being championed as a replicable blueprint to bridge national social fractures.

articles.title: Does the NHS trans doctor ruling mean there is no bathroom ban?
articles.trailText: Some businesses still waiting for final EHRC guidance while firms that moved early to exclude trans people show no sign of backtracking
articles.summary: A Dundee employment tribunal granted nurse Sandie Peggie a narrow win over sharing a female changing room with a trans doctor, yet ruled the Supreme Court’s biological-sex definition of ‘woman’ doesn’t inherently bar trans women from same-sex facilities. A similar decision upheld an inclusive toilet policy at Leonardo UK. Both are first-instance and non-binding; appeals are under way. Campaign groups are sharply split: gender-critical activists condemn the rulings, Stonewall and trans advocates see them as a check on blanket bans. Employers await final EHRC guidance and face a delicate balancing act crafting legally defensible, impartial policies.

articles.title: Online child sexual abuse surges by 26% in year as police say tech firms must act
articles.trailText: Figures for England and Wales show there were 51,672 offences for child sexual exploitation and abuse online in 2024
articles.summary: England and Wales police recorded 122,768 child sexual exploitation offences in 2024, a 6% rise year-on-year, with online abuse up 26% to 51,672 (42% of total). Half involved child-on-child offending among 10-17-year-olds, mainly sharing indecent imagery. Snapchat accounted for 54% of online reports, followed by WhatsApp (8%) and Instagram (8%). Acting Staffordshire chief Becky Riggs urged social media firms to deploy AI filters and in-device safeguards, while NSPCC and experts call for a national prevalence study amid emerging risks like teen sextortion.

articles.title: Britain slipping down global league table for youth employment, says report
articles.trailText: PwC warns that future of a generation is at risk and that jobs crisis is costing UK economy £26bn a year
articles.summary: PwC’s annual youth employment index warns Britain has fallen to 27th of 38 OECD countries as youth joblessness hits a 10-year low, costing the economy £26 bn a year. Nearly one million 16–24-year-olds are Neet, with regional rates peaking at 16% in Scotland and 15% in London. Youth unemployment has risen to 15.3%, the highest outside the pandemic since 2015. Labour proposes a six-month paid “youth guarantee” and 350,000 work or training placements (backed by sanctions), while PwC estimates matching Northern Ireland’s 9% Neet rate could boost GDP by £13–26 bn.

articles.title: Homelessness minister promises to end use of B&Bs as emergency housing
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Alison McGovern makes target for end of this parliament, but figures show homelessness has jumped
articles.summary: Minister Alison McGovern pledges to end B&B emergency housing by parliament’s end, branding any extension a personal failure, as she unveils a three-year homelessness strategy to halve rough sleeping and reduce temporary accommodation. The plan includes a £124m supported housing fund and a new 'duty to collaborate' law forcing agencies to prevent prison and hospital discharges onto the streets. Yet Shelter reports an 8% rise to 380,000 homeless (350,000 in temporary housing), and critics including Andy Burnham and charities condemn frozen housing benefits.

articles.title: Ruth Johns obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Community historian and social entrepreneur who set up a pioneering housing organisation for single mothers
articles.summary: Ruth Johns (died aged 91) was a social historian, journalist and activist whose early experience as an isolated young mother in the 1960s led her to found a part-time playgroup and then, with Gulbenkian funding, the Family First Trust in Nottingham. The trust provided non-institutional housing and a family centre for disadvantaged single mothers, later expanding to new-build flats. Author of Life Goes On (1982) and St Ann’s Nottingham: Inner City Voices (2002), she served as national director of the UK’s Action Resource Centre, advising government on community initiatives. She held an MA in peace studies. Survived by two sons, three grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

articles.title: Wes Streeting improves offer to resident doctors in England in attempt to stop strikes
articles.trailText: BMA puts health secretary’s offer, which includes pledge to double number of extra training places, to resident doctors
articles.summary: Health Sec Wes Streeting has offered to double extra specialty training places for early-career doctors—from 2,000 to 4,000 annually via emergency January legislation—to end planned five-day strikes from Dec 17 amid record NHS flu pressures. The BMA will survey resident doctors on accepting the deal, which excludes pay rises but addresses training bottlenecks and exam fees. If approved, the union will cancel the strike. NHS leaders warn further walkouts risk patient safety.

articles.title: Health experts criticise NHS chief’s remarks that people with flu symptoms ‘must wear face masks’
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Experts warn mixed messaging from Daniel Elkeles causes confusion and could undermine public faith in official guidance
articles.summary: NHS Providers chief Daniel Elkeles’s call for anyone with flu symptoms to ‘must wear’ a mask in public, including on transport, has drawn criticism from health experts who say it conflicts with UKHSA guidance that people should ‘consider’ masks. Behavioural scientists warn mixed messaging risks public confusion, alert fatigue and fuels misinformation, potentially undermining vaccine advice. Other NHS bodies reiterate mask-wearing as one option, stress vaccination and staying home, while hospitals introduce targeted mask policies in high-risk wards.

articles.title: Ethical dilemmas raised by the assisted dying bill | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Dr Sarah Davies , Sarah McCulloch , Jean Farrer and Charlie King respond to articles on the progress of the bill and the role of hospices
articles.summary: The letters to The Guardian contest Dave Sowry’s call for assisted dying, warning that elevating autonomy risks vulnerable groups amid inadequate palliative care. Dr Sarah Davies argues the bill should be removed from health services, asserting current law protects the elderly and disabled. Sarah McCulloch criticises Lords’ filibustering, endorsing legal choice. Jean Farrer says better hospice access changed a patient’s mind on death. Charlie King of Hospice UK stresses underfunding forces thousands into fear-driven decisions, urging improved hospice planning while remaining neutral on assisted dying.

articles.title: Bullying in the NHS results from a systemic problem | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Until you create an environment where staff have access to all the necessary resources to do their job, you will not fix bullying, writes an anonymous former NHS worker
articles.summary: In a letter responding to a Guardian investigation into Blackpool Victoria hospital, an anonymous former NHS research fellow describes two years of relentless bullying by senior management—mostly consultants-turned-researchers—who imposed unrealistic work demands, told him on day one to 'work until I drop,' and criticized compliant dress code choices as 'parrot-like.' He cites the infamous case of a surgeon branding initials on patients’ livers as a remnant of clinical elitism. Arguing that such harassment is symptomatic of systemic flaws and poor organisational structure across the NHS, he contends that procedural fixes alone cannot end bullying without providing staff adequate resources and leadership reform.

articles.title: Jailed Welsh women and their children face an additional trauma | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: Mary Wrenn points out that women given custodial sentences in Wales are sent to prisons in England, which has a negative impact on families
articles.summary: Mary Wrenn warns that, because Wales has no women’s prison, Welsh women—many survivors of domestic abuse—are sent to facilities in England (e.g., Cheshire, Gloucestershire), uprooting families and harming children. With self-harm rates in women’s prisons at record highs, she urges implementation of Wales’s preventive, trauma-informed residential women’s centres as community-based alternatives to short custodial sentences. A Swansea pilot with the Ministry of Justice remains delayed, leaving hundreds of women serving time hours from home in the meantime.

articles.title: One in five women in England say their concerns were ignored during childbirth, survey finds
articles.trailText: Women say fears were dismissed and help was unavailable at crucial moments during labour
articles.summary: A CQC survey of nearly 17,000 NHS births in England found 18% of women felt their concerns during labour were ignored and 15% received no meaningful support when contacting a midwife. One in ten women, including 7% in late labour, were left alone at worrying times. Post-birth, only 57% always accessed help and 10% got none. Women also reported poor communication, lack of empathy and discrimination against ethnic minority and working-class patients. While 89% said staff communicated clearly and 89% received mental-health support, chronic midwife shortages persist. Authorities pledge to implement national investigation recommendations and introduce daily performance monitoring.

articles.title: Scotland’s looser rules on assisted dying could lead to ‘death tourism’, say senior politicians
articles.trailText: Cross-party group of MSPs says bill going through Holyrood could attract people from elsewhere in UK
articles.summary: Senior politicians warn Scotland’s proposed assisted-dying bill, which allows residents with advanced progressive diseases to seek euthanasia without a six-month life expectancy criterion—only one year’s residency—could spur “death tourism” from England and Wales. The bill, set for a final vote in February and expected to take effect sooner than UK legislation under Kim Leadbeater, lacks time limits on applications. Critics including Edward Mountain and Michael Marra say cross-border implications are underexplored, while deputy first minister Kate Forbes fears broader eligibility may lead to non-terminal cases. Sponsor Liam McArthur argues logistic barriers and unique Scottish systems mitigate risks.

articles.title: Should people wear a mask in public if they feel unwell with flu?
articles.trailText: With NHS and No 10 advice differing, we look at best practice for flu prevention and protection
articles.summary: An NHS Providers chief urges anyone with flu symptoms—coughing, sneezing or slight cold—to “must” wear a well-fitting mask in public, contrasting No 10 and UKHSA guidance, which advise that mask-wearing is something to “consider” alongside handwashing, ventilation and limiting contacts. Current UK flu season is unusually early, driven by A(H3N2) subclade K, with record hospital admissions. Flu jabs remain available to older adults, at-risk groups, carers, pregnant women, children and health workers and offer good protection. To prevent infection, practice respiratory hygiene; rest, fluids and paracetamol help, and seek healthcare if high-risk or persistent symptoms.

articles.title: Half of people recently arrested by Met police may have undiagnosed ADHD, study finds
articles.trailText: Research by Cambridge University and Met calls for better neurodivergence screening for vulnerable people
articles.summary: Cambridge University and the Metropolitan Police piloted voluntary on-site screening for ADHD and autism among 303 people detained at six London custody centres in 2024. Seventy-one percent consented: 8% had existing ADHD diagnoses, while 50% screened positive for possible ADHD (17% with very high trait scores); 4.2% had autism diagnoses and 5.4% screened positive for possible autism. Overall, half may have undiagnosed ADHD and one in 20 possible autism. Led by Prof. Simon Baron-Cohen, Dr Tanya Procyshyn and Det. Dion Brown, authors argue routine neurodivergence screening using ASRS and AQ-10 could improve legal decision-making, fairer treatment, access to support and divert vulnerable individuals from the criminal justice system.

articles.title: ‘Highlight of my week’: how community choirs have changed people’s lives
articles.trailText: As James Corden and Ruth Jones announce new series, people share how choirs have brought friendship, belonging and valuable memories
articles.summary: James Corden and Ruth Jones’s new comedy drama The Choir, inspired by his mother’s choir joy, underlines the impact of community singing. In Wiltshire, Jemma Brown’s Big Sound Choir grew from 50 members into a weekly haven forging friendships and easing grief. In Nottingham, Music for Everyone sustained Jill Gaunt’s father with Parkinson’s, even leading to an Albert Hall performance. In London, Lewisham Creative Chorus member Bea celebrates its diversity and creativity. Disabled singer Katie finds belonging in Chelmsford Musical Theatre Choir, while NHS analyst Pat calls Porthmadog Pop Choir his weekly highlight.

articles.title: Tell us: have you ever been required to book a GP appointment in England via an online form?
articles.trailText: We’d like to hear from people in England who have been asked to only book a GP appointment via an online form
articles.summary: From 1 October 2025, GP surgeries across England must keep their online consultation portal open during core hours for non-urgent appointment requests, medication queries and administrative needs, while still offering telephone and in-person booking routes. However, reports indicate some patients are being directed to book exclusively via online forms, potentially limiting access for those unable to use digital channels. The Guardian invites readers who have experienced this policy in practice to share their stories; please get in touch for possible follow-up.

articles.title: People in the UK: how do you feel about wearing a face covering to help prevent spreading a virus?
articles.trailText: As the UK faces a surge in flu cases,an NHS leader has urged people who are ‘coughing and sneezing’ to wear face coverings on public transport. Share your views with us
articles.summary: NHS Providers CEO Daniel Elkeles warns the UK is facing an unusually early, severe flu strain and urges anyone coughing or sneezing yet still commuting to wear face coverings on buses, trains and other public transport—echoing Covid-era habits. While UK Health Security Agency guidance stops short at ‘consider’ wearing masks when unwell, Elkeles calls for a stronger, routine approach to prevent viral transmission. Readers are invited to share whether they’ve caught flu or colds, their willingness to mask up, any public reaction and confusion over current advice.

articles.title: More than £100,000 raised for Guardian’s charity appeal in less than a week
articles.trailText: Hope appeal supports grassroots charities who work in communities hit by division, distrust and racism
articles.summary: Guardian’s Hope appeal has raised over £100,000 in under a week to support five grassroots charities – Citizens UK, The Linking Network, Locality, Hope Unlimited and Who Is Your Neighbour? – working to counter division, distrust and racism via community projects: restoring libraries, parks, running food banks, youth clubs and refugee welcome initiatives. Editor-in-chief Katharine Viner highlighted the surge in far-right activism and racism as context, praising volunteers who build resilience and unity. Donors cited combating hatred and celebrating social justice. An annual telethon follows on 13 December.

articles.title: UK porn traffic down since beginning of age checks but VPN use up, says Ofcom
articles.trailText: Visitor numbers to UK’s 10 most-visited services have settled at a ‘lower level’ than before 25 July, report finds
articles.summary: Ofcom’s Online Nation report finds UK visits to the top 10 porn sites have fallen since age checks began on July 25. Pornhub’s traffic dropped by 1.5m in August and slid 36% to 7.2m unique visitors; Xvideos and Chaturbate fell 27% and 18%. VPN use to bypass checks more than doubled to 1.4m mid-August before settling at 900,000. The report also notes 60% of 11–17-year-olds acted after seeing harmful content, prompting new Online Safety Act rules. The government will review criminal porn laws—including incest and child-likened content—while peers propose extending indecent image offences to adult-played roles, banning incest themes and nudification tools, and creating a separate regulator.

articles.title: Consuming lots of energy drinks may raise heart disease and stroke risk, say doctors
articles.trailText: Study cites case of otherwise fit and healthy man in his 50s who had a stroke after eight-drink-a-day habit
articles.summary: Doctors warn that heavy energy drink intake—beverages typically containing >150mg caffeine per litre and high glucose sugar—may elevate cardiovascular disease and stroke risk. A BMJ Case Reports study described a fit man in his 50s who consumed eight cans daily (≈1,200mg caffeine), developed malignant hypertension (254/150mmHg) and suffered a stroke, resulting in permanent hand and foot numbness. After discontinuation, his blood pressure normalized and he no longer required antihypertensives. Researchers call for stricter regulation of energy drink marketing, targeted public health measures and clinician screening for consumption in young hypertensive or stroke patients.

articles.title: Corridor care ‘endemic’ in UK, doctors say as study reveals scale of problem
articles.trailText: One in five patients treated in hallways, offices and cupboards at almost every A&E, according to research
articles.summary: Doctors warn corridor care is ‘endemic’ across nearly every UK A&E after the Royal College of Emergency Medicine’s trainee network found 17.7% of patients receiving treatment in escalation areas—corridors, offices, cupboards, doubled-up cubicles or ambulances—contravening national guidance. Analysis of five March snapshots in 165 departments highlights mass overcrowding, dignity and safety breaches, and one excess death per 72 patients waiting eight to 12 hours. RCEM president says elderly, vulnerable and children are being failed. Health secretary vows to end corridor care by the next election; DHSC will publish corridor waiting figures to drive reforms.

articles.title: Young people have faced ‘violent indifference’ for decades, Lisa Nandy says
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Culture secretary announces first national youth strategy in 15 years to help ‘vulnerable’ generation
articles.summary: Culture secretary Lisa Nandy decried decades of ‘violent indifference’ to young people as she unveiled Youth Matters, the first UK national youth strategy in 15 years. Backed by £500m, it promises to connect 500,000 more under-25s with trusted adults, refurbish or open 250 youth clubs, create 50 professional-support hubs and boost online-safety skills. Recognizing the ‘most connected yet isolated generation’ shaped by Covid, cost-of-living crises and toxic digital spaces, the plan focuses on resilience, real-world enrichment and empowering youth to drive change rather than lecturing or banning social media.

articles.title: People urged to wear masks when they are ill as UK faces ‘tidal wave’ of flu
articles.trailText: NHS Providers boss says those who are ‘coughing and sneezing’ should wear face coverings on public transport
articles.summary: Daniel Elkeles, CEO of NHS Providers, warns of an early, severe flu strain hitting the UK, urging anyone coughing or sneezing—yet well enough to travel or work—to wear masks in public spaces and on transport. Downing Street describes mask use as optional guidance and highlights flu jabs as the best defence. UKHSA endorses masks to curb respiratory viruses. Conservative MP Kemi Badenoch rejects mandates, citing social barriers and personal trauma. Hospitals face record winter flu admissions, averaging 1,717 patients per day in England, including 69 in critical care.

articles.title: Former betting bosses facing bribery and fraud charges begin lawsuit against Gambling Commission
articles.trailText: Kenny Alexander and Lee Feldman say regulator breached right to privacy during Entain bid for casino website 888
articles.summary: Former Entain CEO Kenny Alexander and chair Lee Feldman, now facing bribery and fraud charges linked to HMRC’s Operation Incendiary, have launched a civil claim against the Gambling Commission. They allege the regulator breached their privacy and confidence by publicising a licence review that derailed their proposed 6.5% takeover and leadership bid at 888 Holdings. The pair claim reputational harm and distress, while the Commission insists its intervention was necessary. Their criminal trial is set for 2028.

articles.title: Badenoch announces Tory review of which conditions qualify for benefits
articles.trailText: ‘Age of diagnosis’ of ‘low-level mental health issues’ such as ADHD making system too costly, Conservative leader says
articles.summary: Conservative leader Kemi Badenoch has launched a review of which physical and mental health conditions qualify for UK welfare, citing the “age of diagnosis” and rising claims for “low-level” issues like ADHD as unsustainable. Proposals include time-limited payments, stricter disability definitions and scrapping relative poverty thresholds in favour of measures resilient to income growth. Framing rising benefit rolls partly as choice and abuse, Badenoch vows expert-led reforms to curb costs, absorb economic shocks and redraw entitlement lines.

articles.title: Victims of NHS maternity failings in England ‘received unacceptable care’
articles.trailText: Lady Amos’s investigation finds women let down and slow progress on reforms, with ‘devastating consequences��
articles.summary: Lady Valerie Amos’s interim report into England’s national maternity and neonatal investigation finds women and babies have suffered “unacceptable care” with “tragic consequences”. Despite 748 recommendations over the past decade, reforms remain slow and inconsistent across seven trusts visited. Key failings include ignored clinical concerns, poor information, discrimination against women of colour, younger or working-class parents, and lack of empathy. Health secretary Wes Streeting will chair a new taskforce; full findings on 12 trusts are due in 2026 with “fundamental” improvement proposals.
