articles.title: ICO promises legal action over ‘traumatic’ UK care-record access
articles.trailText: Information regulator reminds council leaders of need for compassion when releasing files on childhood care
articles.summary: Information Commissioner John Edwards has warned UK councils he will take legal action over protracted, traumatic care-record requests, where files are delayed (up to 16 years), lost, destroyed or heavily redacted. The ICO has already issued enforcement notices (Bristol), fined Birthlink £18,000 for destroying 4,800 records, and found 69% of applicants faced delays and poor communication. Edwards launched the Better Records Together campaign with new standards and a 19-organisation pilot, urging greater compassion and improved systems amid councils’ funding constraints.

articles.title: UK charities face ‘culture of fear’ as threats and violence surge
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Charity Commission chief condemns public hostility towards staff helping women and refugees and at places of worship
articles.summary: Charities serving women, refugees, faith and minority communities face a surge in death, rape threats, vandalism and harassment that the Charity Commission’s interim chair Mark Simms warns has created a ‘culture of fear’, normalising hostility and eroding social norms. In response, the Commission issued guidance urging charities to review security, redact trustee details and upgrade access controls. Simms condemned extremist targeting, misused complaints against ‘woke’ charities and affirmed regulators won’t tolerate abuse. He praised the sector’s role in safeguarding a civilised society, ahead of Julia Unwin’s January succession.

articles.title: Scottish nurse wins part of her tribunal in trans doctor changing room case
articles.trailText: Sandie Peggie wins harassment claim but tribunal dismisses allegations of discrimination and victimisation
articles.summary: Sandie Peggie, an NHS Fife nurse, sued the board and Dr Beth Upton under the Equality Act after being required to share a women’s changing room with the transgender doctor. A Dundee employment tribunal upheld only her harassment claim against NHS Fife—finding it unreasonably delayed revoking Upton’s interim access and investigating her complaint—and dismissed discrimination and victimisation claims and her case against Upton, whose evidence was deemed more reliable. Judge Sandy Kemp held April’s Supreme Court ruling on ‘sex’ in the Act is not determinative for changing-room policies, allowing trans women access based on context. A remedy hearing is pending.

articles.title: A better understanding of mental ill health is crucial | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Sagal Hassan and Dr Lisa Williams respond to the news that Wes Streeting has asked experts to investigate whether normal feelings have become ‘over-pathologised’
articles.summary: In letters responding to Wes Streeting’s call for a review into ‘over-pathologisation’ of everyday feelings, child psychotherapist Sagal Hassan underscores rising genuine distress—fueled by Covid’s blurred home-work boundaries and screen-based life—and argues ADHD and autism diagnoses can reduce self-blame, prompting tailored, multiagency support and diagnostic aftercare. Dr Lisa Williams warns against ‘cowboy’ online assessors who inflate neurodevelopmental diagnoses, advocating regulated, evidence-based evaluations by qualified clinicians to prevent misdiagnosis and protect long-term welfare.

articles.title: Rock star: Sasha DiGiulian on making history with a ‘crazy, audacious’ climb of El Capitán
articles.trailText: The 33-year-old hit rain, lightning, snow and ice in Yosemite – and still became the first woman to ascend the Platinum route
articles.summary: Sasha DiGiulian, 33, after three years of training on Yosemite’s 39-pitch Platinum route, became the first woman to free-climb El Capitan’s most audacious big-wall ascent. Starting 3 November with partner Elliot Faber, they battled rain, lightning and 50 mph winds that sopped and iced their ultralight portaledges, enduring a nine-day storm and living on the wall for 23 days. When Faber left for a family emergency three pitches shy of the summit, DiGiulian finished with support belayed by Ryan Sheridan. Her landmark climb, on slick rock and amid frostbite risk, demonstrated extraordinary resilience and mental focus.

articles.title: People on lowest incomes being denied access to social housing, research finds
articles.trailText: Benefit claimants having applications denied for being deemed too risky by housing associations, says Crisis
articles.summary: Research by Crisis, Heriot-Watt University and the UK Collaborative Centre for Housing Evidence finds that housing associations in England are increasingly rejecting applications from the lowest-income and benefit-claiming households over affordability checks and perceived tenancy risks. A third reported denying offers for financial reasons, nearly a quarter exclude below-threshold incomes from registers, and 71% cite benefit caps and the housing benefit freeze as drivers. Homelessness charity Crisis calls for a Scottish-style rehousing duty, better welfare alignment with rent levels, and urgent social housebuilding, while MHCLG points to a £39bn investment and upcoming homelessness strategy.

articles.title: Local authorities in England and Wales warn finances at ‘breaking point’
articles.trailText: More councils expected to fall into bankruptcy in near future as they face nervous wait over government funding
articles.summary: Local authorities across England and Wales warn of finances at ‘breaking point’, with 29 councils already reliant on special government loans. Leaders predict more bankruptcies after the December 17 fair funding review may cut allocations for high-need areas. Facing unrelenting demand in children’s and adult social care, SEND transport and homelessness, councils carry rising per-capita debt (£1,500) and shrinking reserves. Many plan service cuts, maximum council‐tax rises or asset sales to close multimillion-pound deficits, while awaiting clarity on 2026-27 budgets.

articles.title: Rules on single-sex spaces pose risk to trans people’s mental health, UK charities say
articles.trailText: Fifteen organisations sign letter expressing deep concern over EHRC guidance being considered by ministers
articles.summary: Fifteen leading UK mental health charities, including Samaritans, Mind and the Royal College of Psychiatrists, have warned equalities minister Bridget Phillipson that forthcoming EHRC guidance on single-sex spaces — which may bar trans and non-binary people from using facilities matching their gender identity and allow service providers to challenge them — risks worsening existing inequalities and deepening mental health crises. They urge ministers to strengthen equality protections, safeguard access to inpatient, community and crisis services, and meet to ensure policies promote dignity and safety for trans and non-binary people.

articles.title: Warning system to spot poor care at NHS England maternity wards
articles.trailText: Statistical analysis will track how many babies and mothers suffer harm so problems can be addressed urgently
articles.summary: Maternity Outcomes Signal System (Moss), co-designed by NHS England with Dr Bill Kirkup and Prof Sir David Spiegelhalter, is a real-time statistical monitoring tool tracking maternal and neonatal deaths and injuries at all 119 NHS maternity units. It compares each ward's outcomes against national benchmarks, triggering 95% confidence alerts for safety reviews within eight working days and 99% alerts for urgent action. Following scandals at East Kent, Shrewsbury & Telford, Leeds and Nottingham, Moss enforces ward-level investigations, board sign-off, and regional and national oversight to avert preventable harm.

articles.title: Thousands of patients in England at risk as GP referrals vanish into NHS ‘black hole’
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Watchdog finds 14% of cases not put on hospital waiting lists, with many reporting worsening health and rising anxiety
articles.summary: Healthwatch England reveals 14% of GP referrals in England are lost, rejected or delayed, trapping one in seven patients in a ‘referrals black hole.’ A YouGov survey of 2,622 adults shows 75% suffer physical or mental harm and 70% only discover the issue after chasing up. With 6.24m people on NHS waiting lists for 7.39m procedures, hidden demand and poor communication leave patients anxious and uninformed. The figure has improved from 21% in 2023, but public satisfaction has dropped to 21%. Ministers have rolled out NHS app tracking, Jess’s rule and £1.1bn for GPs, boosting primary care satisfaction from 60% to 75%, yet delays and uncertainty persist.

articles.title: Spiteful or fair? Reeves’s mansion tax plan proves divisive | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Robert Appleford says in the real world, this tax penalises hard-working families, while Tom Holden feels there is an increasing lack of any sense of privilege. Plus letters from Vicky Mills and Kit Jackson
articles.summary: Reader letters debate the proposed ‘mansion tax’ on £2m+ homes. Robert Appleford argues it punishes hard-working, self-made families over ideological wealth-bashing, while Tom Holden warns wealthy homeowners lack gratitude compared to genuine privilege. Vicky Mills highlights the contrast with shared-ownership renters facing steep balancing charges and sees a £2,500 levy as modest. Kit Jackson condemns rich individuals complaining about small taxes amid poverty and hunger. Collectively, readers reflect deep division over fairness, privilege and views on wealth redistribution.

articles.title: Senior DWP civil servant blames victims for carer’s allowance scandal
articles.trailText: Neil Couling said failings by individual claimants ‘at the heart’ of crisis, despite a report finding DWP shortcomings ‘unacceptable’
articles.summary: Neil Couling, director general of DWP services, sparked outrage by blaming carers for the carer’s allowance overpayments scandal, arguing individual failures to report earnings were “at the heart” of the crisis. His internal blogpost, removed after The Guardian queried it, conflicts with Liz Sayce’s independent review, which found a decade of systemic DWP leadership failings, convoluted rules and poor benefit design. Charities and MPs condemned his stance. The government will reassess 200,000 cases—potentially cancelling or reducing 26,000 debts—deploy extra staff, simplify guidance and rebuild trust.

articles.title: Young unemployed told to engage with jobs scheme or risk benefit cuts
articles.trailText: About 350,000 work and training places in care, construction and hospitality available but ‘sanctions’ may apply if ‘neets’ refuse offers
articles.summary: Labour’s work and pensions secretary Pat McFadden has unveiled 350,000 new training and job placements in construction, care and hospitality for 16–24-year-old universal credit claimants, with benefit sanctions for those who refuse. Funded by an £820m “youth guarantee” offering six-month paid placements for 55,000 18–21-year-olds from spring and £725m for 50,000 extra apprenticeships (including £140m to mayors, fully funded under-25 SME slots), the scheme also provides 900,000 young people with intensive work support. Target regions include Birmingham and Solihull, East Midlands, Greater Manchester, Hertfordshire and Essex, central and east Scotland, and south-west and south-east Wales. Critics warn sanctions may push NEETs into insecure roles.

articles.title: Gambling addicts risk losing ‘life-saving’ help due to funding overhaul, say UK charities
articles.trailText: Specialist clinics and support groups call for government emergency support due to delays caused by new levy system
articles.summary: UK gambling charities warn addicts risk losing vital treatment due to delays in new mandatory 1.1% levy system replacing voluntary 0.1% contributions. Since April, the £12.5bn sector’s £100m-a-year pot, routed via the NHS instead of GambleAware, remains unallocated amid unclear commissioning criteria. GamCare and Gordon Moody report clinics and support groups face funding gaps, threatening smaller providers and life-saving residential and counselling services. Chief executives demand interim government funding and clarity on bids to avoid service disruptions beyond March 2026. Former patients warn of higher suicide rates if support lapses. Government pledges transition with GambleAware.

articles.title: New US seed ban risks driving cannabis genetics underground, growers warn
articles.trailText: Part of the shutdown deal, the ban could kill the cannabis genetics market, with only big firms able to comply
articles.summary: Last month’s spending bill includes a provision banning US sales of any Cannabis sativa L. seeds that could grow plants over 0.3% THC, overturning a 2018/2022 framework treating hemp seeds as non‐controlled. Growers say regulating unidentifiable seeds by potential THC yield is unworkable, forcing smaller firms and home cultivators—especially medical patients relying on specific strains for epilepsy, pain or chemotherapy nausea—out of the market. Only large companies can absorb compliance costs, industry leaders warn, driving genetic diversity underground and ceding seed leadership to foreign producers.

articles.title: Gen Z office survival guide: how to overcome telephobia and get up early
articles.trailText: Experts advise younger workers to practice phone calls with friends and embrace adventure of small talk
articles.summary: Study of 1,500 UK Gen Z workers finds 38% dread small talk, 60% fear collaborating with older colleagues and 30% avoid phone calls. Careers adviser Liz Baxter recommends practicing calls with friends, scripting purposes and using confident posture. Executive coach Marie O’Riordan urges treating office chit-chat as an adventure: ask about tenure to spark connections. Dr Radha Modgil advises shifting bedtime early, planning morning routines and pacing work with mental-health days, flexible hours and WFH options.

articles.title: London councils have a ‘sustained reliance’ on private firms as report shows £500m spend
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Research prompts warning that authorities rely on companies to carry out basic functions
articles.summary: An Autonomy Institute and CADA Network report reveals London councils paid private consultancies and outsourcing firms £555m in 2024, over half a billion pounds annually since 2022, after a one-third cut in central funding since 2010. Spending on consultants has risen 76% per council (2013-23), averaging £20.2m in 2023. Firms like Matrix SCM (£2.1bn contracts since 2010), Capita (£1.1bn) and Serco (£500m) now perform core functions from IT and temp staffing to waste management. The report warns of "structural dependency" hollowing out public capacity. Lambeth and Barnet councils’ £80m and £40m outsourcing bills and Barnet’s reversal of its Capita "easyCouncil" model illustrate the risks. Councils dispute some cost classifications.

articles.title: What is polygenic embryo screening in IVF and does it work?
articles.trailText: Scientists have developed algorithms that give predictive scores for a host of physical and mental traits
articles.summary: In the UK, IVF patients are using GDPR provisions to obtain low-resolution embryo genome data, exploiting a regulatory grey area to apply polygenic embryo screening (PGT-P) for traits such as IQ, health risks and height. While current UK law restricts genetic tests to ~1,700 monogenic disorders and aneuploidy checks, couples combine parental genomes with embryo sequences to generate predictive scores for complex traits. Proponents argue this could reduce disease risk; critics and regulators warn that polygenic scores capture only a small fraction of heritable variance and lack validation, making PGT-P premature and ethically fraught.

articles.title: UK IVF couples use legal loophole to rank embryos based on potential IQ, height and health
articles.trailText: British fertility clinics raise scientific and ethical objections over patients sending embryos’ genetic data abroad for analysis
articles.summary: UK IVF patients are bypassing domestic bans on embryo polygenic screening by exporting raw genetic data under data protection laws to US firms like Herasight. For $50,000, the companies score embryos on IQ, height, sex and disease risk using polygenic risk algorithms. The HFEA prohibits such testing in clinics and says UK centres must not use patient-acquired score data for embryo selection. Clinics face ethical and legal confusion and question enforceability if patients demand specific embryo transfers. Critics, including the European Society of Human Genetics, call the unproven technique “unethical” and warn it risks social inequality and inflated parental expectations.

articles.title: AI deepfakes of real doctors spreading health misinformation on social media
articles.trailText: Hundreds of videos on TikTok and elsewhere impersonate experts to sell supplements with unproven effects
articles.summary: Full Fact has identified hundreds of AI‐generated deepfake videos on TikTok, X, Facebook and YouTube that misuse real doctors’ footage—notably Liverpool University’s Prof David Taylor‐Robinson and ex-PHE chief Duncan Selbie—to peddle unproven supplements via the US firm Wellness Nest. Manipulated from public talks dating to 2017, these clips falsely endorse probiotics and Himalayan shilajit for menopausal ‘symptoms’. Critics, including factchecker Leo Benedictus and Lib Dem health spokesperson Helen Morgan, demand faster removal, stronger platform policing and legal accountability for medical misinformation.

articles.title: What is in the UK government’s child poverty strategy?
articles.trailText: Several elements had already been announced, including lifting the two-child benefit cap and increasing free school meals
articles.summary: Labour’s first child poverty strategy in a decade aims to lift half a million children from hardship by 2031 through a suite of policies: scrapping the two-child universal credit cap—projected to pull 300,000 from relative poverty by 2027; extending free school meals to 500,000 extra pupils; launching free breakfast clubs in primary schools; piloting an £8m, 20-council scheme to rehouse homeless families within six weeks plus a duty to alert schools and health visitors; introducing a “deep material poverty” metric covering 2m children; mandating clear, grouped display of affordable baby formula; expanding childcare cost refunds for parents on universal credit; and overhauling the child maintenance service with lower fees and tougher enforcement.

articles.title: Mixed messages on prostate cancer testing proved deadly for my husband | Letter
articles.trailText: Letters: Conflicting advice on whether all men should be tested – and around the test’s reliability – can have heartbreaking consequences, writes Pat Sharpe
articles.summary: Pat Sharpe recounts how her husband’s delayed PSA test—misled by warnings about unreliability and overdiagnosis—led to an advanced prostate cancer diagnosis and his death aged 68, less than three years later. She criticizes conflicting messages from expert bodies: Dr Jayne Spink of Prostate Cancer Research urges early screening due to asymptomatic progression, while Cancer Research UK and the UK National Screening Committee argue evidence of harm outweighs benefits. The Royal College of GPs recommends personalized risk–benefit discussions, but Sharpe warns that such mixed messaging may deter men from testing and result in preventable fatalities.

articles.title: We must warn travellers about the risk of methanol poisoning | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: Jim Dickson MP says much has been done since the death of Simone White, but a wider campaign is needed to educate tourists on the dangers of drinking spirits in countries where methanol-lacing occurs
articles.summary: Labour MP Jim Dickson highlights 14,600 suspected methanol-poisoning deaths since 2015 and calls for broader tourist education after Simone White’s fatal lapse in Laos. Following bereaved families’ campaigns, the UK has added methanol-risk teaching to the national curriculum and strengthened Foreign Office travel advisories, extending warnings to more destinations. Dickson urges a nationwide campaign with tour operators, advising travellers to avoid spirits entirely in high-risk countries—particularly Indonesia, which has reported the highest number of suspected methanol-poisoning incidents over the past decade.

articles.title: A guide to the Guardian’s 2025 charity appeal partners
articles.trailText: This year’s appeal theme is hope – we are partnering with five charities supporting grassroots community work that challenges division, hate and despair
articles.summary: The Guardian’s 2025 charity appeal, themed around hope, backs five grassroots partners tackling division and hate: Locality, a network of 2,000 community groups awarding grants to build resilience and counter extremism; The Linking Network, which pairs schools across 26 areas to reduce prejudice through shared experiences; Citizens UK, a 30-year-old alliance campaigning for living wage, refugee welcome and training community organisers via its Power-Building Fund; Who Is Your Neighbour?, facilitating structured dialogues to foster empathy amid social change; and Hope Unlimited, a grant-giver supporting hyper-local initiatives that strengthen relationships and challenge hateful narratives. Donations will expand grants, training, dialogues and projects that bridge communities and build hope.

articles.title: Whales, beards, mules and VIPs: the secret world of high-rolling professional gambling
articles.trailText: How elite gamblers buy betting accounts of losing punters to bamboozle bookmakers
articles.summary: An unprecedented court filing reveals how Tony Bloom’s gambling syndicate, fronted by Reform UK insider George Cottrell, allegedly used his VIP betting accounts to amass some $250m, sparking a profit-sharing claim. It exposes a hidden "wild west" sector where pro punters, shut out ("chinned") by major UK bookmakers via stake-factoring, buy or rent "whale" accounts—beards or mules—through Telegram/WhatsApp, and access unregulated offshore sites via VPN or crypto. This clandestine market, estimated at £1bn, thrives beyond Gambling Commission oversight, fueling tax avoidance and money-laundering fears.

articles.title: Tell us: have you lived in temporary accommodation in the UK with children?
articles.trailText: We want to hear from UK parents with experience in temporary accommodation about the impact on their lives, family and schooling
articles.summary: Official figures show over 172,000 children in England lived in temporary accommodation at June’s end, an 8.2% year-on-year rise, across 130,000+ households. Crisis CEO Matt Downie warns of record levels of families deprived of stable space for play, homework or security. The Guardian invites UK parents who currently or recently lived in temporary housing with children to share the duration, impact on family life, schooling disruptions, relocations and children’s wellbeing and development.

articles.title: Communities are our defence against hatred. Now, more than ever, we must invest in hope
articles.trailText: For this year’s Guardian charity appeal we are asking readers to donate to Citizens UK, The Linking Network, Locality, Hope Unlimited Charitable Trust and Who is Your Neighbour?
articles.summary: In its 2025 charity appeal, the Guardian asks readers to fund five grassroots partners—Citizens UK, The Linking Network, Locality, Hope Unlimited Charitable Trust and Who is Your Neighbour?—to counter rising extremism, racism and austerity-driven inequality by nurturing locally led projects: housing campaigns, park and library restorations, food banks, youth clubs, arts workshops and refugee welcome schemes. As Locality observes, communities are our defence against hatred. Donations split evenly, with a telethon on 13 December and 20p per Guardian Bookshop order until 31 December. Past appeals have raised £15 m.

articles.title: Rising racism blamed for collapse in number of foreign nurses coming to UK
articles.trailText: Number of overseas nurses and midwives registered between April and September was half that of a year ago
articles.summary: Between April and September 2025, only 6,321 overseas nurses/midwives registered in the UK, half the figure from last year (12,534). Rising racism and stricter immigration rules are blamed, with steep drops from India (58%), the Philippines (68%), Nigeria (28%) and Ghana (9%). International staff departures from Britain are also rising. NHS experts warn the collapse will worsen understaffing, lengthen patient waiting times, and hamper care. Critics link government labour policies doubling the wait for indefinite leave to remain to anti-immigration politics. Despite the slump, total registrations hit a record 860,801.

articles.title: GPs failing older people living with frailty, National Audit Office finds
articles.trailText: Of patients diagnosed with condition in 2024/25, only 18% were assessed for fall risk and just 16% had a medical review
articles.summary: NAO audit finds GPs assessed only 17% of over-65s for frailty in 2024/25 (down from 25% in 2017/18). Of 226,000 diagnosed, just 18% had fall-risk assessments and 16% medical reviews. Workforce pressures—each GP now cares for 2,241 patients on average—limit time for proactive, continuous care. The report highlights stark regional variation and inconsistent support for severe frailty. NAO head urges leveraging the NHS ten-year plan to standardize care, while RCGP warns improvements need more staff and investment. Health department pledges rapid action to better support older people.

articles.title: Families to be offered help to leave temporary accommodation under UK child poverty strategy
articles.trailText: Government says series of measures, including childcare support, will lift 500,000 out of poverty
articles.summary: UK government’s delayed child poverty strategy will pool measures—including abolishing the two-child benefit cap (£3bn cost), £8m to pilot rehousing families from B&Bs within six weeks across 20 councils, legal duty for councils to alert schools/GPs/health visitors when children enter temporary accommodation, NHS-council cooperation to stop mothers with newborns returning to hostels, easier upfront childcare cost support under Universal Credit, and adopting CMA recommendations to steer parents to cheaper baby formula brands—to lift 550,000 children out of poverty by 2030 alongside expanded free school meals, breakfast clubs and family hubs.

articles.title: Parents say concerns were not acted on before London nursery worker’s arrest for abusing children
articles.trailText: Lawyer for parents say allegations included children coming home injured and claims about how Vincent Chan treated toddlers
articles.summary: From 2017 until June 2024, nursery worker Vincent Chan allegedly abused girls aged two to four at Bright Horizons in north London. Parents reported children returning with bite marks, cuts and scratches and recounted Chan inciting toddlers to fight and shouting at them—but say management ignored their concerns. Chan, who filmed some assaults, pleaded guilty to 26 sexual offences and will be sentenced on 23 January. Bright Horizons cites compliance with safer recruitment, is cooperating with a child safeguarding review; Bridget Phillipson promises a full government review, CCTV and vetting reforms.

articles.title: Sir Terence English obituary
articles.trailText: Pioneering cardiac surgeon who directed the Papworth hospital heart transplant programme
articles.summary: Sir Terence English (1932–2025) was a pioneering cardiac surgeon, aged 93 at death, who led Papworth Hospital’s heart transplant programme. After training under Donald Ross and studying with Donald Shumway, he broke a 1973 moratorium to perform two transplants in 1979: the first failed, the second kept builder Keith Castle alive for nearly six years, prompting expansion to 342 operations by 1989. Knighted in 1991, he presided over the Royal College of Surgeons and the BMA, then championed conflict-area medical aid and assisted dying. Born in South Africa, he shifted from engineering to medicine at Guy’s, married twice, and pursued adventurous travel in retirement.

articles.title: Preventing infections in older people is hit and miss, says England’s chief medic
articles.trailText: Chris Whitty contrasts systematic approach in children and calls for more research into managing infections in elderly
articles.summary: England’s chief medical officer, Prof Chris Whitty, warns that infection prevention and management in older adults remains “hit and miss” due to insufficient research, despite systematic approaches in younger populations. 2023 data show most infectious-disease deaths occur in the elderly, mainly from respiratory infections and Covid. Whitty urges uptake of RSV and other vaccines, enhanced hygiene, food safety and limited visitor exposure. He also recommends a lower antibiotic threshold to prevent sepsis amid AMR concerns. Experts, including Prof Arne Akbar, say targeted research could boost older people’s quality of life and relieve pressures on health and social care systems.

articles.title: NHS braces for ‘unprecedented flu wave’ as hospitalised cases in England rise
articles.trailText: Average of 1,717 flu patients in beds last week, up 56% on a year ago, after ‘unusually early’ start to season
articles.summary: NHS England recorded an average of 1,717 flu inpatients per day last week—56% more than 1,098 in the same week last year—with 69 in critical care. Seasonal flu began unusually early and shows no peak yet. Ambulance handover delays (30% waited over 30 min) persist. A junior doctors’ strike (17–22 Dec) threatens to intensify pressure; NHS chiefs warn staff may be “stretched close to breaking point,” predicting flu beds could reach 8,000. Policymakers promise contingency planning and investment to “weather this storm.”

articles.title: Children in England most active since 2017 – but majority still fall short of targets
articles.trailText: Exercise levels have increased but less than half do more than 60 minutes of activity per day, survey shows
articles.summary: Sport England’s 2024-25 Active Lives survey finds 49.1% of 5-16 year-olds (3.6m) average >60 mins of daily activity - the highest since the survey began in 2017 (up 1.3% year-on-year, 5.8% since 2017). Participation gains reflect schools, clubs and community efforts, says CEO Simon Hayes, though fewer than half meet guidelines. Inequities persist: boys outpace girls, White/mixed children surpass ethnic minorities, wealthier households exceed poorer (58% vs 45%), and activity dips in 7-9 age group. Uptake in walking, cycling and gym/fitness classes rose, while team sports stayed flat. Government pledges £400m to improve grassroots facilities and broaden PE partnerships to boost inclusion.

articles.title: Parents and young people: share your concerns about ultra-processed foods (UPFs)
articles.trailText: We’re particularly interested in hearing from parents in low- and middle-income countries where the rise in childhood obesity is steepest
articles.summary: Parents and young people worldwide are being asked to share their concerns about ultra-processed foods (UPFs), which a new Lancet review—the largest of its kind—finds are replacing fresh foods across all continents, exposing millions to long-term health threats. With one in ten children now obese and advertising driving junk-food consumption, the steepest obesity increases occur in low- and middle-income countries. The article solicits insights on: availability and affordability of fresh produce; key obstacles to healthy eating; and policy or community actions needed to support childhood nutrition and curb UPF consumption.

articles.title: Pornography company fined £1m by Ofcom for not having strong enough age checks
articles.trailText: AVS Group, which runs 18 websites, has 72 hours to make changes required by UK’s Online Safety Act
articles.summary: Ofcom has fined AVS Group £1m—the largest penalty under the UK Online Safety Act—for failing to deploy sufficiently robust age checks across its 18 adult websites and slapped an additional £50,000 fine for non-compliance with information requests. The Belize-based firm must implement effective age verification within 72 hours or incur £1,000-per-day fines. Ofcom has opened probes into 92 services, including 83 pornography sites and an unnamed social platform over inadequate risk assessments, with further enforcement imminent as the regulator prioritises high-traffic sites and illegal content removal. It is also reviewing a major platform’s systems for removing terror and hate content.

articles.title: Probation officers in England and Wales to be given self-defence training after stabbings
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Pilot schemes for bodycams, knife arches and metal detectors in probation offices also approved after attacks in Oxford and Preston
articles.summary: Following two recent stabbings in Oxford and Preston probation offices, the UK Ministry of Justice will pilot self-defence (Spear) training, body-worn cameras, bleed kits, knife arches and metal-detecting wands for England and Wales’ 6,000 probation officers supervising over 244,000 people—including violent, sexual and domestic offenders under the SDS40 early-release scheme, which freed nearly 40,000 prisoners in nine months. The Probation Officers’ Union warns of 'palpable fear' amid high workloads, pay disputes and mental-health absences. Prison-reform groups caution new security measures must not undermine vital officer-client relationships.

articles.title: Leasehold ‘wild west’ under scrutiny as minister criticises FirstPort’s fees and failures
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Senior minister raises ‘significant concerns’ over one of UK’s biggest property managers
articles.summary: Senior minister Matthew Pennycook has warned the unregulated leasehold market is a “wild west” after dozens of complaints about FirstPort – the UK’s largest leasehold manager – over steep service charges, opaque fee structures, slow repairs and aggressive debt collection. In a letter to MD Martin King he highlighted unreasonable charge hikes, lack of transparency, poor responses to complaints and heavy-handed legal demands. Pennycook is preparing a draft bill to ban new leaseholds, simplify conversions and license managers. FirstPort says it’s investing in reforms but admits more work remains.

articles.title: Wes Streeting orders review of mental health diagnoses as benefit claims soar
articles.trailText: Health secretary has asked experts to investigate whether normal feelings have become ‘over-pathologised’
articles.summary: Wes Streeting has commissioned a clinical review, led by Prof. Peter Fonagy and vice-chaired by Sir Simon Wessely, to assess rising diagnoses of mental health conditions, autism and ADHD amid a surge in sickness benefit claims among working-age Britons (up 1.2m since 2019 to 4.4m). Concerned that everyday feelings may be 'over-pathologised', he seeks evidence-based insights from research, clinicians and service users to improve access to accurate diagnosis and support. The review, launching Thursday, aligns with ministers' push to control welfare costs and reform benefits, a policy Labour leader Keir Starmer also advocates.

articles.title: Discussing breast density after mammograms may cause unneeded anxiety, study finds
articles.trailText: Data from Australia shows women told about density had more anxiety and confusion, as measure considered in UK
articles.summary: An Australian BMJ-published trial of 2,401 women screened between September 2023 and July 2024 found that disclosing dense-breast results (with written or video information) raised anxiety and confusion without improving informed decision-making. Notified women were more likely to plan GP consultations (22.8%/19.4% vs. 12.9% control) but felt uncertain about next steps. UK experts warn that adding density reporting to NHS screening—currently under UKNSC review—requires clearer guidance and further research.

articles.title: ‘From taboo to tool’: 30% of GPs in UK use AI tools in patient consultations, study finds
articles.trailText: Survey shows rise in GPs using tools such as ChatGPT to produce appointment summaries and assist with diagnosis
articles.summary: A Nuffield Trust/Royal College of GPs survey of 2,108 UK family doctors finds 28% using AI tools like ChatGPT for appointment summaries, diagnoses and admin tasks. Adoption skews male and affluent areas. GPs fear legal, clinical error and data security risks amid unregulated wild west tools. Regional NHS boards vary in support; time saved is used for rest, not extra appointments. Researchers warn of lack of training and oversight. Patients also turn to AI for health advice, raising concerns over inconsistent quality. Government commission on AI regulation pending.

articles.title: Blackpool report: why do England’s deprived areas have the most troubled hospitals?
articles.trailText: Clinicians in deprived areas are overwhelmed by generational ill health and poverty
articles.summary: Leaked Royal College of Physicians review of Blackpool Victoria exposes racist, bullying culture fueling staff exodus and substandard chronic-disease care. It reveals that hospitals in England's most deprived areas—seven Blackpool neighbourhoods among the ten most deprived nationally—struggle under generational ill health (COPD, depression, Parkinson's), GP shortages (2,450 patients per doctor), outdated Carr-Hill funding and recruitment gaps. Disparate private income, looming NHS budget and 13,500 job cuts amplify risks. Health secretary Wes Streeting's shift to community-based prevention faces questions over funding equity and impact on local services.

articles.title: Women’s prisons report finds 97 deaths in decade as self-harm hits record high
articles.trailText: Charity director warns ‘more deaths will follow’ unless government changes tack and closes women’s prisons
articles.summary: Over 2015–24, 97 women died in English and Welsh prisons and self-harm incidents hit a record 6,056 per 1,000 female inmates, versus 687 per 1,000 for men. Inquest’s report attributes deaths—from solitary births to suicides—to missed medical checks, ignored cell-bell alarms and poor mental-health oversight. Despite the 2007 Corston review and a 2023 care inquiry, women in custody rose 12% since 2020. Charity Inquest calls for closing women’s prisons; the MoJ vows community sentencing reforms.

articles.title: Leaked report reveals culture of bullying and harassment at scandal-hit NHS hospital
articles.trailText: Exclusive: report into Blackpool Victoria hospital by Royal College of Physicians finds systemic failings have affected patient safety
articles.summary: Leaked Royal College of Physicians report finds systemic bullying, harassment and racial discrimination at Blackpool Victoria hospital, with delayed internal circulation hindering action on 19 safety recommendations. Staff cited excessive workloads for inexperienced doctors, poor supervision and a “keep‐your‐head‐down” culture. The trust has faced a string of criminal scandals—staff jailed for drug theft, unlawful sedation, sexual assaults and a pending murder investigation—and suffers chronic understaffing, leadership churn and recruitment challenges. Under CQC scrutiny and NHS recovery support, the trust has recruited 116 doctors, strengthened junior training and introduced protected learning time, but BMA demands an external probe.

articles.title: Having a dog can boost teenagers’ mental health, say scientists
articles.trailText: Researchers find children who own dogs score lower for social problems, aggressive behaviour and delinquency
articles.summary: Researchers from Azabu University analyzed 343 healthy 13-year-olds in the Tokyo Teenager Cohort, 96 of whom owned dogs. By age 14, dog-owning teens scored significantly lower for social problems, withdrawal, thought issues, aggression and delinquency. Saliva tests identified 12 bacterial taxa (including Streptococcus and Prevotella) more abundant in dog owners. Transplanting their microbiota into germ-free mice boosted social sniffing and empathetic concern. While canine microbiomes weren’t sampled directly, findings suggest pet exposure may shape adolescent microbiota and enhance social behavior.

articles.title: Labour proposed in opposition how to introduce assisted dying via private member’s bill
articles.trailText: Leaked document raises questions over amount of government control behind MP Kim Leadbeater’s bill
articles.summary: Leaked November 2023 memo shows Labour in opposition plotted to introduce assisted dying via a private member’s bill—mirroring Kim Leadbeater’s eventual proposal to limit eligibility to mentally competent, terminally ill adults with under six months to live—while retaining government influence over drafting and timing. The leak intensifies a Lords debate stalled by hundreds of amendments deemed a filibuster. Critics warn of a “shadow policymaking process” outside Labour’s manifesto; Leadbeater denies collusion. The memo cites polling, Dignity in Dying support and older voter appeal.

articles.title: What to know when the ban on most US hemp products goes into effect
articles.trailText: Ban set to be enforced in November 2026 will change pricing, availability and composition of products
articles.summary: Congress passed a federal ban on most hemp-derived products as part of the spending bill, to take effect November 2026. States with existing hemp or cannabis frameworks can continue regulated sales, but interstate commerce and online purchases will be prohibited. Federal hemp will be redefined to 0.4 mg THC per package, collapsing full-spectrum CBD and limiting effectiveness. Producers face Section 280E taxation, shrinking economies of scale and forcing price hikes—CBD balms could rise from $10 to ~$80. THC beverages lack distributor support, threatening nascent market. Companies will explore alternative terpenes (mango, lavender, holy basil) to mimic entourage effects.

articles.title: Scott Galloway on the masculinity crisis: ‘I worry we are evolving a new breed of asexual, asocial males’
articles.trailText: When his book Notes on Being a Man was released last month, it raced to the top of the bestseller lists. The US author, tech entrepreneur and podcaster explains his theories on dating, crying – and the rise of Donald Trump
articles.summary: Scott Galloway’s Notes on Being a Man diagnoses a masculinity crisis in young men, citing rising suspensions, unemployment, loneliness and college dropouts, and links it to social media dopamine loops and political neglect that fueled Trump’s resurgence. Combining pithy maxims—protect, provide, procreate—and data on dating norms, he urges men to build economic viability, emotional openness and strong male role models. A liberal “Jordan Peterson” with progressive insights, Galloway acknowledges his book’s limits on race or sexuality, shares his own father’s abandonment, and champions crying, mentorship programs and societal support to prevent a new breed of asexual, asocial males.

articles.title: Quality of migraine care dependent on ethnicity, UK survey finds
articles.trailText: Ethnic minority people more likely to experience poor treatment and even racism, Migraine Trust research shows
articles.summary: A Migraine Trust survey of 2,200 UK adults reveals ethnic minority patients face worse migraine care and discrimination: 23% mixed-ethnicity, 19% Asian and 16% Black respondents report ethnicity negatively affected treatment versus 7% of white respondents. Black respondents (37%) fear job discrimination vs 26% of whites; 19% of Asians and 14% of Blacks worry they won’t be believed vs 8% of whites. High rates of misdiagnosis, dismissal and stereotyping prompt calls for urgent action to close care gaps across ethnicity, gender and social grade.

articles.title: Two in five teenagers in England and Wales ‘abused’ in intimate relationships
articles.trailText: Survey of 11,000 13- to 17-year-olds says emotional and physical abuse includes control, pressure or violence
articles.summary: A Savanta survey of 11,000 13–17-year-olds in England and Wales for the Youth Endowment Fund found 28% had been in a relationship over the past year; of these, 39% reported abuse—36% emotional and 15% physical or sexual. Common controlling behaviours included checking phones (19%), location monitoring (14%) and body criticism (11%). One in ten felt pressured into sex; 12% feared disagreeing; 13% felt unable to leave; 5% had explicit images shared. Girls (41%) and boys (37%) experienced abuse similarly. Three-quarters said it harmed their daily life (sleep, self-esteem, school attendance). Experts urge funded relationship-education in schools and open boundary discussions at home.

articles.title: Numbers leaving A&E without treatment triples in six years
articles.trailText: Sharp rise in waiting times has led to ‘shocking’ rise in untreated patients leaving NHS emergency departments in England, data shows
articles.summary: Between July–September 2025 over 320,000 people left A&E untreated in England—more than triple the 2019 figure of just under 100,000—and those waiting over 12 hours jumped 90-fold from 1,281 to 116,141. The Royal College of Nursing warns under-resourced primary and community care and delayed discharges are gridlocking emergency departments, forcing frustrated patients away. Private market data shows NHS-funded acute activity hit £2.2bn in 2024 but self-pay growth stalled at 0.1%, risking further NHS pressure. Campaigners argue outsourcing depletes staff rather than easing demand. The Department of Health is investing £450m in same-day care, ambulances, mental health crisis centres and corridor waiting transparency this winter.

articles.title: Rape victims in England and Wales to be protected from ‘serial liar’ trope in legal shake-up
articles.trailText: Exclusive: New laws will also curb questioning and aim to stop complainants being discredited over previous reports
articles.summary: England and Wales will introduce landmark reforms protecting rape complainants from being portrayed as ‘serial liars’ in court: new legislation will ban ‘bad character’ evidence of a victim’s past sexual history or prior reports unless there’s proof of deliberate lying, and prohibit questions on unrelated abuse or compensation claims. Prosecutors gain easier access to defendants’ prior domestic abuse. Announced by justice secretary David Lammy alongside plans to scrap jury trials for sub-three-year sentences, the changes—backed by £550m in victim support—aim to curb retraumatizing cross-examination, tackle crown court backlogs, and restore faith in the justice system.

articles.title: Trans girls banned from joining Girlguiding
articles.trailText: Girls’ adventure charity says it made decision after seeking legal advice in wake of supreme court ruling on gender
articles.summary: After April’s Supreme Court ruling that the Equality Act’s legal definition of “woman” depends on biological sex, Girlguiding has decided, following expert legal advice and member input, to bar trans girls (those not recorded female at birth) from joining as new members. The charity says current members and volunteers, who remain unaffected, include any gender in non–women-only roles. While affirming its commitment to inclusion and respect, it plans a new taskforce to support marginalized groups. The move follows legal challenges and reflects wider uncertainty awaiting EHRC guidance.

articles.title: Children’s home providers in England putting profit over need, says Ofsted
articles.trailText: Watchdog says trend of care homes being registered in cheap areas, not where need is greatest, is ‘national scandal’
articles.summary: Ofsted warns record 4,010 children’s homes in England—up 15% in a year—are being sited in cheap areas like the north-west (25% of homes vs. 18% of looked-after children) driven by profit over need. Local authority spend on looked-after children rose from £3.9bn in 2015-16 to £8.1bn in 2023-24 (£97,200 per child). Unregistered providers charge up to £30,000 a week, prompting nearly 900 investigations. With 84% privately owned and the top 10 groups holding 20% of homes, Ofsted calls this a “national scandal” and urges government action to curb profiteering and expand specialist placements.

articles.title: BMA chair denies using junior doctors’ strikes to progress political career
articles.trailText: Tom Dolphin, who applied to be Labour candidate in 2024, says political career not relevant as he defends strikes
articles.summary: BMA chair Tom Dolphin, previously a Labour candidate applicant and agent for MP Dawn Butler, insists the 14th junior doctors strike (17–22 Dec) is driven by pay and training disputes, not his political ambitions. He defends union action amid warnings from Health Sec Wes Streeting (calling it a “cynical attempt to wreck Christmas”) and NHS England’s Dr Chris Streather (labeling it “highly irresponsible” for harming patient care). Dolphin argues pay rose 30% in three years but needs 26% more to offset real-terms cuts since 2008, and calls for prioritizing UK graduates in scarce training posts.

articles.title: Twelve more prisoners in England and Wales released in error in last month
articles.trailText: Justice secretary David Lammy says two are still at large but overall ‘trend is downwards’
articles.summary: Since November, 12 inmates have been released in error in England and Wales, according to Justice Secretary David Lammy. This follows 91 accidental releases recorded between April and October. Two of the recent escapees—neither violent nor sexual offenders—remain at large. Lammy says the “trend is downwards” after tougher security checks were introduced post high-profile errors, including the mistaken release of Algerian sex offender Brahim Kaddour-Cherif and Ethiopian national Hadush Kebatu. In the year to March 2025 there were 262 wrongful releases out of 57,000 total releases.

articles.title: UN experts raise concerns over homes rented out by English social landlord
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Letter says L&Q appears to have systematically failed in its duty to provide adequate standard of living
articles.summary: UN housing experts have accused L&Q, one of England’s largest social landlords, of systemic habitability failings after disabled tenant Sanjay Ramburn and his family endured years without electricity, four ceiling collapses, severe damp and mould and unaddressed racial harassment in their east London home. The UN letter warns that L&Q’s delayed or insufficient action violates tenants’ right to adequate housing. In 2023 the housing ombudsman fined L&Q £142,000, but a £2,271 compensation offer and cramped temporary rehousing were deemed inadequate. L&Q says it is working with the tenant, while the government pledges tougher damp-and-mould laws.

articles.title: Almost 4 million children in UK affected by economic abuse, charity finds
articles.trailText: Research shows perpetrators use methods such as stopping mothers accessing bank accounts and child benefits
articles.summary: SEA research finds nearly 4m UK children suffer economic abuse: 27% of mothers with under-18s last year faced partner-driven financial control—denied bank accounts, child benefit, unreliable or withheld maintenance. One in six reported pocket or birthday money stolen, same proportion blocked from benefits. Consequences include lack of essentials like food and clothing. A third experienced ex-partners refusing child support despite ability to pay. SEA CEO Sam Smethers urges urgent publication of the government’s Violence Against Women and Girls strategy to close loopholes in maintenance systems. Minister Jess Phillips emphasizes economic abuse prevention is key to halving violence against women and girls in ten years by protecting children, too.

articles.title: Resident doctors in England to go on strike in run-up to Christmas
articles.trailText: Five days of strike action over jobs and pay to take place from 17 to 22 December
articles.summary: From 7am on 17 December to 7am on 22 December, England’s resident doctors—junior medics represented by the BMA—will stage a five-day strike over pay and job security. It is the 14th walkout since March 2023 after failed government talks over real-terms pay cuts and tight training post numbers. The BMA demands a 26% pay rise and more specialty training places to reverse pay erosion since 2008. Previous strikes cost the NHS £300m and delayed 1.5m appointments. Health Secretary Wes Streeting condemned the timing as “Grinch”-like, while the BMA ballots to extend its strike mandate to August 2026.

articles.title: Assisted dying bill is safer than any other in the world | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Dr Jacky Davis and Stephen Sedley respond to letters that supported the Lords’ scrutiny of the bill
articles.summary: Dr Jacky Davis and Stephen Sedley counter defence of the Lords’ scrutiny, arguing that over 1,000 amendments amount to obstruction rather than meaningful review – citing, for example, a requirement for a dying 90-year-old to take a pregnancy test. They maintain the Commons-approved assisted dying bill is the world’s safest, with robust patient and doctor safeguards, including conscience protection under Clause 31. Sedley adds that the six-month prognosis cap is arbitrary and excludes those enduring indefinite suffering, urging ministers to back a new bill without a life-expectancy test.

articles.title: Beware flammable skincare, too many sprouts and overindulging in cheese this Christmas, say health experts
articles.trailText: Some foods can interact negatively with certain medication while medical moisturisers can make clothes more flammable
articles.summary: MHRA warns that emollient skin creams can soak into fabrics and become flammable around candles or heat, while festive vegetables high in vitamin K (sprouts, broccoli) may affect warfarin dosing—patients should keep intake consistent. Tyramine-rich foods (aged cheese, dark chocolate, smoked fish) can spike blood pressure with MAO inhibitors. Caution advised with alcohol and medicines that impair coordination. Only buy weight-loss drugs via prescription from reputable sources, heed dosage guidelines, and consult pharmacists or NHS 111 if unsure.

articles.title: Shortage of ‘breakthrough’ weight loss drugs will slow fight against obesity, WHO warns
articles.trailText: WHO urges countries to make drugs such as Mounjaro more accessible to people and asks drugs companies to lower prices
articles.summary: WHO says GLP-1 weight-loss drugs like Mounjaro and Ozempic mark a new chapter in obesity treatment but face critical shortages and high prices. Only about 100 million of the 1 billion eligible can access them. WHO urges governments to boost production, ensure affordability and strengthen health-system readiness, while advising against use in pregnant women. Obesity is projected to double to 2 billion people by 2030, costing $3 trillion globally. GLP-1 therapies can reduce risks of heart attacks, strokes, type 2 diabetes and related comorbidities, but must be paired with diet, exercise and counseling. Key barriers include manufacturing capacity, availability, cost, health-system preparedness and universal healthcare; experts warn drugs aren’t a silver bullet and weight is often regained post-treatment.

articles.title: Testing at A&Es part of plan to end new HIV cases in England by 2030
articles.trailText: Labour announces prevention programme as well as efforts to re-engage people who have fallen out of medical care
articles.summary: England’s government unveiled a £170m HIV action plan on World AIDS Day to end new transmissions by 2030, introducing opt-out HIV screening during routine bloodwork in high-incidence A&E departments (eg, London, Manchester) and anti-stigma training for staff. It targets roughly 5,000 people who have fallen out of care—due to mental health, addiction, poverty or stigma—and expands home-testing via the NHS app (£5m trial), formula milk provision for infants of HIV-positive mothers and streamlined PrEP access. Senior officials stressed that 95% of diagnosed cases are under treatment, but late diagnoses persist among Black African communities and older adults.

articles.title: A more nuanced approach to ultra-processed foods is necessary | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: The discussion over UPFs distracts from the real public health problem: meat and dairy products, writes Noah Praamsma
articles.summary: Advocating a refined view of ultra-processed foods (UPFs), Noah Praamsma highlights that plant-based UPFs—like cereals, canned beans and veggie burgers—can lower risks of type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease and mortality, while animal-derived UPFs increase these risks. Endorsed by the AMA and AHA, studies show ultra-processed cereals cut diabetes risk by 22%, whereas animal UPFs raise it by 44%. Replacing meat and dairy with plant-based UPFs aids weight loss, improves insulin sensitivity and reduces menopausal symptoms, underscoring the need to target meat/dairy, not all UPFs.

articles.title: Dignitas founder ends his own life through assisted death
articles.trailText: Ludwig Minelli, whose work had lasting influence on Swiss law, dies just days before his 93rd birthday
articles.summary: Ludwig Minelli, the 92-year-old founder of Swiss right-to-die group Dignitas, ended his life via assisted suicide days before his 93rd birthday. A former journalist-turned-lawyer, he led legal battles up to the Swiss Supreme Court and European Court of Human Rights, shaping Swiss self-determination law with a landmark 2011 ECHR ruling. Since 1998 Dignitas grew to over 10,000 members and helped more than 4,000 people—571 Britons—end their lives. His death comes amid global shifts on assisted-dying laws, with reforms in France, Canada, Australia, NZ, Spain, Austria, 10 US states and a pending UK bill in the Lords.

articles.title: Illegal weight-loss drugs being sold in UK by firms with high Trustpilot scores
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Guardian investigation finds unlicensed jabs offered as experts call for more online regulation
articles.summary: Guardian investigation reveals unlicensed weight-loss drugs like experimental retatrutide sold in UK by operators such as Retatrutide UK, Alluvi Health Care and Retatide with high Trustpilot scores (4.4-4.7) and even AI-generated positive summaries. These pens, unlicensed and unsterile, risk infections, blood sugar crashes, pancreatitis and cardiovascular events. TikTok sellers promote 20-40mg doses with Black Friday deals under coded hashtags. Experts warn of weak online safeguards, calling for stricter regulation, proactive enforcement and market-wide fines. Trustpilot, MHRA and TikTok have blocked flagged profiles, but regulatory gaps persist.

articles.title: Failure to diagnose treatable male infertility leading to unnecessary IVF, experts say
articles.trailText: Men represent 50% of all infertility cases but poor understanding among GPs means it is often untreated
articles.summary: Experts warn NHS failures to diagnose treatable male infertility are driving unnecessary IVF. GPs lack training, few dedicated andrologists, and men face years of delay before basic tests, while women undergo rapid assessment. Men cause 50% of infertility, with treatable issues like varicocele or lifestyle factors often overlooked. Experts criticise the new UK Men’s Health Strategy for omitting male fertility measures; NICE updates may improve testing. Research shows 80.6% of GPs lack male fertility education, fuelling mental health strains on couples. Experts call for top-down policy change and rigorous trials.

articles.title: ‘It was soul destroying’: men on the struggle to get answers about infertility
articles.trailText: Failure by GPs to diagnose treatable causes had huge time, money and mental health costs for these men
articles.summary: In a Guardian investigation, men recount extensive delays and mental health tolls due to NHS GPs failing to diagnose common, treatable male infertility causes. Toby Trice endured six years of childless struggle and two failed IVFs before private testing revealed a varicocele, surgery for which led to a natural pregnancy. Similarly, Martin Bowers faced eight years and four IVF cycles before discovering sperm DNA fragmentation, treated by lifestyle changes and medication. Sean Farrell waited over a year for a urology referral, then learned privately he has Sertoli cell-only syndrome. Experts warn NHS under-resourcing and low awareness force couples into costly, traumatic IVF unnecessarily.

articles.title: Lessons not learned after Georgia Barter driven to suicide by abuse, says her mother
articles.trailText: Family ‘saddened’ by minister’s response to London coroner’s concerns over police database access
articles.summary: Georgia Barter, 32, took her own life after years of abuse by partner Thomas Bignell. A London inquest found she was unlawfully killed and highlighted that officers from at least four forces lacked easy access to the police national database (PND) when responding to reports. Coroner Dr Shirley Radcliffe urged improved PND access to flag cross-border domestic-abuse histories, but Policing Minister Sarah Jones said no operational changes are planned. Barter’s mother, Kay, condemned the outdated, time-consuming system and warned that without reform, more lives will be lost.

articles.title: ‘We’ve got to listen to dead women’: critical part of Queensland’s DV response stops reviewing all recent deaths
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Experts raise concern as Queensland’s Domestic and Family Violence Death Review and Advisory Board turns focus to historical, rather than new, data
articles.summary: Queensland’s Domestic and Family Violence Death Review Board has stopped routine analysis of recent DFV deaths, focusing on historical themed cases for over two years. Experts, including resigned board member Prof Molly Dragiewicz, warn this shift undermines timely case-based recommendations, lacks representation from frontline and First Nations experts, and weakens public accountability. An internal 2020 audit flagged resource shortages, staff trauma, and reliance on an Excel database—issues persisting amid high vacancy rates. A whistleblower and former police liaison highlight missed cases and systemic failures, raising fears that key lessons to prevent future fatalities are being lost.

articles.title: What has happened since the UK supreme court’s gender ruling?
articles.trailText: Official guidance has yet to be published after landmark judgment seven months ago
articles.summary: Since April’s Supreme Court ruling that defines “woman” by biological sex under the Equality Act, most public services await EHRC’s updated code to apply the judgment. A handful of firms like Barclays and Virgin Active have already barred trans people from using facilities matching their gender identity, while gender-critical campaigners press for broader enforcement and sue over prison policies. Trans advocates report increased policing of toilets and a chilling effect, prompting a Council of Europe warning. The EHRC’s draft guidance—leaked and aligned with interim advice excluding trans women from single-sex spaces—is pending ministerial approval amid GLP and other legal challenges.

articles.title: Rage rooms: can smashing stuff up really help to relieve anger and stress?
articles.trailText: Venues promoting destruction as stress relief are appearing around the UK but experts – and our correspondent – are unsure
articles.summary: Rage rooms, pay-to-destroy venues where patrons smash TVs, plates or furniture, have proliferated across the UK since 2008’s Japan origins. Operators charge about £50 for 30 minutes, hosting customers from stressed mothers, break-up parties and youth care groups to PTSD sufferers and therapist referrals. Proponents tout ‘cathartic release’ and improved mental wellbeing, yet studies by Kjærvik and colleagues and experts like Martin and Bushman warn that aggressive venting can heighten anger and entrench violence cues. Critics including Suzy Reading highlight the expense, lack of root-cause insight and recommend mindfulness, CBT and expressive writing for lasting relief.

articles.title: Cuts to insulation scheme will leave homes cold over winter, experts say
articles.trailText: E3G thinktank warns retrofit sector could shed 10,000 skilled jobs as small firms struggle to survive
articles.summary: Experts warn that axing the £1.3bn ECO scheme in March, which funds insulation, solar panels and heat pumps for households under £31,000 income, risks leaving 222,000 planned retrofits in limbo, damp, draughty homes this winter and 10,000 skilled jobs—including apprenticeships—on the line. Since 2013 ECO delivered upgrades to 15m homes, saving £110bn on bills despite 23,000 faulty cladding cases. Retrofit firms and thinktank E3G urge a one-year extension and ring-fenced funding until the delayed £15bn Warm Homes Plan launches, while ministers insist they’ll invest an extra £1.5bn in the successor scheme.

articles.title: ‘The admin’: why it’s not easy to rename streets called after Prince Andrew
articles.trailText: Councils consult on removing former prince’s name as residents report ‘embarrassment’ and ‘smirks’ when giving their addresses
articles.summary: Across the UK and Northern Ireland, councils are weighing formal renaming of streets bearing Prince Andrew’s name after his titles were stripped amid the Epstein scandal. In Carrickfergus, ‘Prince Andrew Way’ faces public consultation following a council vote; in Maidenhead, local rules now allow two-thirds of residents to approve changes. Renaming incurs complex admin—bank details, deeds, utilities, maps and emergency-service databases must be updated—and demands consensus on a new name. Under the 2023 Levelling Up Act, local authorities decide what counts as ‘sufficient support,’ but secondary regulations are still undefined, leaving the process legally and logistically muddy.

articles.title: Brain damage, blindness and death: the global trail of trauma left by methanol-laced alcohol
articles.trailText: Methanol, a cheap relative of ethanol, is entering the supply chain, causing thousands of deaths around the world
articles.summary: Methanol-laced alcohol is causing a hidden global health crisis of brain damage, blindness and death. Tourist victims in Laos, including Simone White, and Brazilian gin consumers died after consuming methanol-contaminated drinks. Data from MSF and Oslo University document over 1,000 incidents, 41,000 poisonings and 14,600 fatalities, likely underreported in regions where alcohol is illegal or taboo. Methanol, cheaper than ethanol, is being mixed into both illicit and sealed-brand spirits. Early treatment with fomepizole or ethanol is highly effective, yet scarcity and lack of awareness persist. Over-taxation and bans driving illicit markets fuel outbreaks in Iran, India and Turkey.

articles.title: Londoners told to be vigilant with messages after cyber-attack on council
articles.trailText: Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea says it is checking whether data taken contained residents’ details
articles.summary: After a cyber-attack this week, Kensington & Chelsea council confirmed theft of historical data from its systems. As NCSC, National Crime Agency and Met Police investigate whether personal or financial details of 147,500 residents were compromised, the council advises residents to be vigilant against suspicious calls, emails or texts. The breach, linked to attacks on Westminster and Hammersmith & Fulham, has caused at least two weeks of disruption. While no ransomware claim has been made, it echoes past UK public sector hacks. Council leader Elizabeth Campbell stresses early warning lets residents protect themselves with official guidance.

articles.title: The loss of access to and respect for autonomous midwifery is tragic | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: A concerned NHS midwife responds to an article about the Free Birth Society
articles.summary: An NHS midwife’s letter rebuts a Guardian feature on the Free Birth Society, asserting that medical intervention can be lifesaving yet ‘medical overreach’ has dismantled autonomous midwifery. She underscores midwives’ vital balance of clinical monitoring (eg checking for pre-eclampsia) and empathetic ‘watchful waiting’—providing emotional support that alleviates pain. The letter argues that sidelining autonomous care drives both hospital-based obstetric violence and dangerous free births, and calls for renewed investment in accessible, respectful, experienced midwifery.

articles.title: We older people are always a footnote | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Life’s five ‘eras’ | Levelling up Huddersfield | Favourite headlines | Posh breakfasts | Grieving nominative determinism letters
articles.summary: Five Guardian readers write in: Dave Headey, an older reader, laments that recent research on five ‘eras’ of brain development skimps on the last two stages for older adults; Lynn Brooks quips that discarded Royal Opera House curtains could furnish Huddersfield’s stage as part of promised “levelling up”; Dr Richard Carter recalls the pun “Queen in brawl at Palace” from a football match; Brian Stevenson argues that Eggs Benedict is too posh for a greasy spoon; I Grieve apologises for missing the nominative determinism-themed letters deadline.

articles.title: Expert panel advises against prostate cancer screening for most men in UK
articles.trailText: Charities express ‘deep disappointment’ as government advisers find harms of screening all men would outweigh benefits
articles.summary: The UK National Screening Committee advises against universal prostate cancer screening—citing minimal mortality reduction, high over-diagnosis and overtreatment risks—and instead recommends biennial PSA testing for men aged 45–61 with confirmed BRCA1/2 mutations. It rejected screening based on family history or ethnicity (including Black men) due to insufficient evidence. The draft guidance, open for 12 weeks ahead of a March decision, has drawn ‘deep disappointment’ from charities and public figures, while officials stress the need for targeted programmes and further research.

articles.title: What is prostate cancer and should I be worried if I wee a lot at night?
articles.trailText: While risk of developing prostate cancer increases as you age, some groups are much more likely to get it than others
articles.summary: Prostate cancer, the UK’s most common male cancer after breast cancer, starts in the prostate gland, causing about 55,300 diagnoses and 12,200 deaths annually. Incidence has risen 55% since the 1990s and may reach 85,100 cases by 2038. Early stages are often symptom-free; later signs include urinary changes, erectile issues, weight loss or bone pain. Risk increases with age, is twice as high in Black men, and is amplified by family history or BRCA1/2 variants. Men over 50 can request a PSA test; MRI and biopsy confirm diagnosis. Early detection yields >80% 10-year survival; treatment ranges from active surveillance to surgery or radiotherapy. Lifestyle factors—diet, exercise, non-smoking—can lower risk.

articles.title: Wes Streeting calls BMA ‘impossible’ and says they made ‘misleading’ claims
articles.trailText: Health secretary responds to speech given by GP committee leader accusing Labour of ‘gaslighting’ behaviour
articles.summary: Health secretary Wes Streeting has branded the BMA “impossible” and its claims “misleading” after GP contract changes, introduced in February 2025 to extend online access, were criticised by BMA GP committee head Dr Katie Bramall as “traitorous” and “gaslighting”. In a rare letter to 50,000 GPs, Streeting stripped the BMA of its sole negotiating role and accused it of unprofessionalism. The union argues new measures risk overwhelming practices—42% report cutting face-to-face slots. Streeting will now involve the RCGP and NHS Confederation in 2026-27 talks amid possible further doctors’ strikes.

articles.title: Ministers set aside £75m to fix failures that caused carer’s allowance crisis
articles.trailText: Most of money earmarked to fix ‘systemic’ problems expected to pay for officials needed to reassess overpayments
articles.summary: Ministers have earmarked £75m from 2026 to 2029 to address systemic failures in the DWP’s handling of Carer’s Allowance, following an independent review by Liz Sayce. Outdated IT, confusing guidance and leadership lapses led to penalisation and overpayments for 145,000 unpaid carers, who face cliff-edge income rules. The funds will cover staffing to reassess cases and partly write off or reimburse debts. Campaigners welcomed the change but await details on compensation and preventative measures under new guidance introduced in September.

articles.title: Analysts back British gambling firm stocks despite tax rises for sector
articles.trailText: Paddy Power owner Flutter and other betting and gaming firms say higher online gambling taxes will hit profits hard
articles.summary: Despite £1bn profit downgrades after chancellor Rachel Reeves’s duty rises—projected to cost the sector £8.3bn by 2030-31—analysts at Deutsche Bank, UBS and Jefferies maintained buy ratings on major UK gambling stocks. They cite the removal of tax-rate uncertainty and the scale of diversified operators such as Entain and Flutter (Paddy Power owner) enabling them to absorb smaller rivals hit by the increase from 15% to 25% online sports duty and 21% to 40% gaming duty. Smaller firms warn of job cuts and punters shifting to unlicensed sites. Flutter forecasts a $860m profit impact over two years but plans 40% cuts in marketing by 2027.

articles.title: Severe asthma can be controlled by a monthly injection, trial finds
articles.trailText: Tezepelumab treatment may mean asthmatics for whom inhalers are ineffective can reduce or stop taking steroids
articles.summary: In the international Wayfinder trial of nearly 300 adults with severe uncontrolled asthma across 11 countries, monthly injections of AstraZeneca’s tezepelumab allowed over 50% to stop daily oral steroids and nearly 90% to reduce to low doses after one year, with two-thirds free of attacks, and significant improvements in symptoms, lung function and quality of life. Tezepelumab, approved by NICE in 2023, targets airway inflammation and may mitigate steroid-related side effects, offering a once-monthly alternative for patients not controlled by inhalers. Trial findings published in Lancet Respiratory Medicine.

articles.title: System failed our daughter, say parents, as NHS trust fined £200,000 over death
articles.trailText: Ellame Ford-Dunn, 16, who had mental health problems, absconded from a ward and killed herself shortly afterwards
articles.summary: Ellame Ford-Dunn, 16, who suffered severe mental health issues, absconded from 24-hour supervision at Worthing hospital’s Bluefin ward in March 2022 and killed herself minutes later. University Hospitals Sussex NHS Trust pleaded guilty to failing to provide safe care and was fined £200,000 by Brighton magistrates for health and safety offences. In court, her parents said the system meant to protect their daughter failed. The trust cited an unclear missing-patient policy and bed shortages; it has since overhauled policies, training and ward environments. The family is pursuing damages and urges the fine be used to bolster child mental health services.

articles.title: Peers are just doing their job in scrutinising the assisted dying bill | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Dr Lucy Thomas and Penelope Jenkins support the House of Lords’ examination of the bill, but Margaret Pelling says they seem to be blocking the legislation, not scrutinising it
articles.summary: Three letters debate the House of Lords’ scrutiny of a private members’ assisted dying bill: palliative care doctor Lucy Thomas and campaigner Penelope Jenkins defend peers’ line-by-line review, highlighting gaps in the draft law – no mandatory suffering criterion, state-driven eligibility and doctor-led death decisions – and warning that the Commons’ rushed process, driven by a single MP and lobby group, precludes ethically coherent alternatives. Margaret Pelling counters that peers now appear to be blocking a limited proposal that risks restricting access to well-connected patients rather than expanding choice.

articles.title: Shortfall in return on investment in health | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Great Western Park health centre | Cricket headlines | UK emissions | Quick Crossword | Air guitar
articles.summary: A White Horse district councillor warns that after 10 years of delays, the developer’s required return on investment for the Great Western Park health centre in Didcot exceeds NHS reimbursement, risking no GP practice taking it on. Other letters praise a witty cricket print headline (“Lights, Canberra, no action”), criticise Ed Miliband’s claim that UK emissions equal 1% of the world despite higher per-person output, flag gender bias in crossword clues (“ex-servicemen” and “emeritus”), and advocate air guitar to de-stress to Ramones tracks.

articles.title: Online betting firms to pay billions more in UK tax, Reeves confirms
articles.trailText: The chancellor almost doubled remote gaming duty in Wednesday’s budget, taking it to 40% from April next year
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves will almost double the remote gaming duty from 21% to 40% in April, raising £1.1 bn pa by 2029-30 from online casinos and bookmakers. General betting duty on sports bets rises from 15% to 25% for online wagers from April 2027; high-street bets stay unchanged, bingo duty is abolished and horse racing is exempt. Firms like Entain, Evoke and Rank warn of £100–150 m profit hits, job cuts and share volatility. The Betting & Gaming Council warns this will fuel an unregulated black market. Government pledges £26 m to boost the Gambling Commission, linking extra revenue to lifting the two-child benefit cap.

articles.title: ‘I didn’t even know this type of attack existed’: more than 200 women allege drugging by senior French civil servant
articles.trailText: In a case echoing the Pelicot trial, dozens of women allege they were given hot drinks mixed with a diuretic to make them urinate. Three of them speak out here
articles.summary: In a case echoing 2018’s Pelicot trial, over 240 women allege that Christian Nègre, a senior civil servant at France’s culture ministry, spiked their coffees or teas during recruitment interviews between 2011 and 2020 with a powerful diuretic, triggering urgent urges to urinate while he allegedly prolonged interviews on outdoor walks. A police investigation opened in 2018 after a colleague’s tip‐off uncovered a spreadsheet titled “Experiments” documenting times and reactions. Nègre was formally charged in 2019, but trial delays exacerbate victims’ trauma and lawyers decry state “secondary victimisation.”

articles.title: Horrific death of Kardell Lomas sparks urgent calls for new independent oversight of police
