articles.trailText: Federal government’s expert advisory panel on sexual violence says it repeatedly warned of chronic failure of police to adequately investigate violence
articles.summary: Guardian Australia’s Broken Trust investigation revealed that Queensland police dismissed repeated pleas for help from 31-year-old First Nations woman Kardell Lomas before her killing. Sixteen of 20 members of the federal sexual violence advisory panel urge attorney-general Michelle Rowland to order an inquest, enact urgent national independent oversight of police and set up civilian-led integrity units in every state and territory. They warn ALRC reforms fail to confront chronic police neglect of marginalized survivors’ domestic violence reports, risking more preventable deaths.

articles.title: ‘Outdated and ever less fit for purpose’: five takeaways from the carer’s allowance report
articles.trailText: Dysfunctional DWP failed to notify some carers that they were accruing enormous debt for years, Liz Sayce’s damning report reveals
articles.summary: Liz Sayce’s 146-page independent review exposes the DWP’s carers allowance as outdated, punitive and error-ridden. Officials deliberately ignored half of real-time earnings alerts, leaving 230,400 unpaid carers—mostly women in poverty—unaware of mounting debts. A brutal “cliff edge” forces full-week benefit repayments plus £50 penalties for breaches as small as 1p, while claimants are presumed negligent and often criminalised. Many suffered mental health crises and family breakdown. Sayce calls for ending automatic fault assumptions, tapering earnings thresholds, modernising systems and clearer rules. The DWP will review 185,000 historic cases and has accepted most of 40 recommendations but offers no apology or compensation.

articles.title: UK gambling firms make extra £1bn from punters amid calls for tax rises
articles.trailText: Betting companies made £12.6bn in 12 months to March, with 15% rise in takings from online casino players
articles.summary: UK gambling firms’ revenue excluding lotteries jumped 9.3% to £12.6bn in the year to March, led by a near-15% rise in online casino yield to £5bn (55% above pre-pandemic levels). Cross-party figures like Iain Duncan Smith and Meg Hillier demand higher taxes on addictive games, while Betfred threatens to close all 1,287 shops and other operators signal up to 200 closures if duties rise. Adult gaming centres’ winnings rose 10% to £683m despite a slight drop in premises. The Betting & Gaming Council warns tax hikes could strengthen the unregulated black market.

articles.title: CPS to train staff on ‘spectrum of abuse’ in violence against women and girls
articles.trailText: Five-year strategy aims to improve casework after analysis finds domestic abuse in more than third of rape cases
articles.summary: CPS launches five-year Violence Against Women and Girls strategy to train staff in recognising overlapping abuse—after finding domestic abuse in 35% of rape, 83% of stalking and 86% of image-based sexual abuse charges, and 94% of honour crimes. Measures include training on honour-based violence, forced marriage, FGM, stalking/harassment and cyberstalking; a stalking action plan; embedding research on domestic/sexual offence links; victim liaison officers; pre-trial meetings for adult sexual offence victims; enhanced services for high-risk domestic abuse survivors; and national scrutiny panels. It aims to boost case quality, victim communication and sentencing that reflects the full spectrum of offending.

articles.title: Ministers urged to apologise after review finds systemic failures led to carer’s allowance crisis
articles.trailText: Unpaid carers were pushed into debt and distress and hundreds of millions of pounds of taxpayers’ money wasted
articles.summary: An independent review by Liz Sayce has found that systemic failings at the Department for Work and Pensions inflicted hardship, debt and distress on unpaid carers through complex “cliff-edge” carer’s allowance rules. Between 2019-25, 180,000 carers accrued £300m in unfair overpayments, with many facing penalties, prosecutions and mental health crises. The report urges ministers to apologise, scrap excessive repayments, write off debts, end minor fraud prosecutions and fully reform the outdated £83.30-a-week benefit. The government has accepted 40 recommendations, but pressure mounts for compensation.

articles.title: What is prostate cancer and how is it diagnosed in the UK?
articles.trailText: As David Cameron receives treatment and backs calls for an NHS screening programme, we look at the disease and its treatment
articles.summary: After his own treatment for prostate cancer, former PM David Cameron has backed calls for targeted NHS screening for high-risk men (black men, those with a family history of prostate/breast/ovarian cancer, and BRCA1/2 carriers). Prostate cancer is the UK’s most common male cancer (55,300 new cases and 12,200 deaths annually, 80% 10-year survival). Early stages often asymptomatic; detection relies on PSA screening, pre-biopsy MRI and transperineal biopsy pathways. Healthcare bodies like Cancer Research UK cite PSA’s false positives/negatives and overdiagnosis risks, while advocates argue MRI-first protocols mitigate harm. The UK National Screening Committee will review evidence alongside the £42m TRANSFORM trial due in 2027.

articles.title: NHS directed pregnant women to controversial Free Birth Society via charity
articles.trailText: Exclusive: NHS websites pointed women to factsheet featuring podcast by ‘dangerous’ influencers linked to baby deaths
articles.summary: NHS websites until August linked expecting mothers to an AIMS factsheet recommending the Free Birth Society (FBS), a US-based promoter of unassisted birth linked to 48 cases of neonatal harm, including deaths in 18 instances. FBS discourages medical scans, midwives and resuscitation, spreading misinformation expert reviewers call dangerous. Although NHS removed the link, several trusts still distribute AIMS leaflets. AIMS has since deleted FBS references, claiming no endorsement. A 2024 study and NMC data (142 recorded free births, one stillbirth, two neonatal deaths) suggest growing UK freebirthing amid distrust of maternity services. The NHS stresses the right to unassisted birth but urges professional care.

articles.title: UK charity records original music by people living with dementia
articles.trailText: Project aims to unlock memories and sensations for participants while creating nine-track CD, recorded at Glyndebourne
articles.summary: At Glyndebourne, the charity Raise Your Voice has spent a year guiding people with dementia and their carers through weekly workshops to compose nine original tracks for the CD Murmuration. Supported by Glyndebourne, the Royal Academy of Music, Alzheimer’s Society and Arts Council England, participants use musical prompts to articulate emotions, unlocking memories—eighty-year-old Colin dreams of a hot-air balloon, Barbara recalls “a world outside my door.” Researchers report cognitive and conversational gains that persist post-session. The charity plans online tutorials to help others replicate this model, proving dementia doesn’t erase creativity.

articles.title: DWP to reassess hundreds of thousands of cases in carer’s allowance scandal
articles.trailText: Damning official review finds many unpaid carers left with huge debt because of government failure
articles.summary: An independent review led by Liz Sayce found that DWP errors and rigid 'cliff-edge' earnings rules forced hundreds of thousands of unpaid carers into debts—some up to £20,000—and penalties since 2015. Ministers will reassess all overpayments for fluctuating earnings, cancel or reduce wrongful penalties per 40 accepted recommendations, but offer no compensation. The scandal, with over £357m wrongly paid and 144,000 carers still repaying £251m, has triggered legal challenges, government reforms to rebuild trust, and calls for clearer policy and justice for carers.

articles.title: The carer’s allowance scandal – a timeline
articles.trailText: Ten years of bureaucratic failure, whistleblowing, political neglect and groundhog day-style policy inertia
articles.summary: Timeline of 2016–2025: a DWP whistleblower exposed failures in carer’s allowance overpayments—claimants breaching a £196 weekly earnings limit by any amount faced full-week clawbacks, unknowingly incurring debts over £20,000 and fraud charges. NAO reports (2019) and Guardian investigations (2024–25) revealed £357m in errors and departmental inertia, worsened by COVID and ministerial delays. A 2024 Labour-led Sayce review prompts major reforms: raising earnings thresholds, reviewing 2015–24 cases, overturning convictions and improving real-time data warnings.

articles.title: More than 100 MPs urge Streeting to approve prostate cancer screening
articles.trailText: Rishi Sunak hands health secretary open letter calling for testing for men at the highest risk
articles.summary: Over 100 MPs, led by Rishi Sunak, have written to Health Secretary Wes Streeting urging the introduction of a prostate cancer screening programme for high-risk men. They want the UK National Screening Committee to recommend checks for Black men, those with a family history of prostate, breast or ovarian cancer, and BRCA1/2 gene carriers. The MPs criticize the current unstructured PSA testing as unfair and postcode-dependent, warning it erodes trust and perpetuates preventable deaths. Their call follows David Cameron’s diagnosis and a New England Journal of Medicine study suggesting screening could cut prostate cancer mortality by 13%, preventing one death per 456 men screened.

articles.title: John Stuart Brown obituary
articles.trailText: Doctor whose lobbying led to a government sanctioned increase in minor surgery undertaken by GPs
articles.summary: John Stuart Brown (1935–2025) was a Kent GP whose 1979 BMJ paper showed GPs could safely perform four minor operations weekly at £5 each versus £78 in hospital, saving £15,000 annually. His lobbying led to the 1987 white paper Promoting Better Health and the 1990 GP contract, boosting GP-performed surgeries by 41% in 1991. By retiring in 2000, he’d done around 20,000 procedures, trained colleagues, volunteered with St John Ambulance and authored the enduring Minor Surgery textbook. Made MBE in 1997, he trained at King’s College London, married nurse Anne Price, volunteered in Zambia, and is survived by his wife, three children and six grandchildren.

articles.title: People who stop using Mounjaro suffer reversal of health benefits, says study
articles.trailText: Ceasing use of jabs brings regained weight plus loss of benefits regarding ‘bad’ cholesterol and blood pressure
articles.summary: Analysis of the 88-week Surmount-4 trial of tirzepatide (Mounjaro) in 308 adults who lost ≥10% body weight over 36 weeks found that one year after switching to placebo, 82% regained ≥25% of their weight loss. Greater weight regain correlated directly with reversals in waist circumference, LDL cholesterol, blood pressure and blood glucose. Participants with ≥75% regain saw cardiometabolic measures return to baseline, while those with ≤50% regain retained some benefit. Researchers emphasize the importance of long-term lifestyle and medication strategies to sustain health gains after Mounjaro discontinuation.

articles.title: Time for doctors to face salary reality | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: Bob Forster doesn’t think an anaesthetist’s wage is unreasonable. Plus a letter from Martin Ryle
articles.summary: Two readers challenge a recent letter by consultant anaesthetist Elizabeth Taylor, who deemed her £100,000 NHS salary “pathetic”. Retired head teacher Bob Forster of Shipton under Wychwood argues that £100k is generous compared to his £50k final teacher’s salary after 37 years. Martin Ryle of Lewes highlights that many ward staff earn less than half an anaesthetist’s pay and wonders what term Taylor would apply to their wages. The Guardian invites further letters from readers on today’s coverage.

articles.title: Princess of Wales calls for end to ‘stigma’ around addiction
articles.trailText: Forward Trust patron says ‘compassion and love’ are needed to end fear and shame felt by those affected
articles.summary: The Princess of Wales, patron of Forward Trust, has urged society to end the stigma around addiction—describing it as a complex mental health condition shaped by fear, shame and judgment rather than personal failing. In a message for Addiction Awareness Week she called for open conversations, empathy and love to help individuals and families access support. An Ipsos poll for the charity found 53% of respondents have personal experience of addiction and 81% believe those affected deserve help, not judgment. She also announced £100,000 funding for research on gadget-related ‘technoference’ in family life.

articles.title: More than 2,000 trafficked children and lone child asylum seekers missing from UK councils’ care
articles.trailText: Charities say vulnerable young people are being failed by local authorities, the police and central government
articles.summary: Freedom of information data from 135 UK councils shows that of 2,335 trafficked or suspected trafficked children in care last year, 864 (37%) went missing; separately, 141 councils reported 1,501 (13%) of 11,999 unaccompanied asylum-seeking children disappeared. The joint ECPAT UK and Missing People report ‘Until Harm Ends’ warns that lack of central data, insecure immigration status and unsuitable placements—especially for 16–17-year-olds—heighten risks of re-trafficking and exploitation. It calls for strict adherence to safeguarding frameworks, improved accommodation and stronger multi-agency coordination. The government cites its children’s wellbeing and schools bill as a major social care overhaul.

articles.title: Hospitals must get smaller to stop NHS ‘permacrisis’, thinktank urges
articles.trailText: Re:State report says role hospitals play needs ‘fundamental reinvention’ to deliver better care for patients
articles.summary: Thinktank Re:State calls for a fundamental reinvention of NHS hospitals to end a decade-long “permacrisis”, urging a reduction in bed numbers and a shift towards diagnostics, outpatient and home-based care. Downsizing, it argues, would save billions, improve patient outcomes and relieve overworked staff by delivering faster, preventative services outside inpatient settings. With general and acute beds down from 180,889 in 1987-88 to 100,916 now, leaders including Milton Keynes CEO Prof. Joe Harrison and NHS Confederation chiefs back radical reform. Government plans for neighbourhood health centres, expanded community diagnostic hubs and future hospitals with single-patient rooms and tech-driven efficiency align with this vision.

articles.title: Private finance plans for NHS buildings | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Johnbosco Nwogbo says adding a new private finance debt burden is a bad idea, while Lord Hutton thinks PFIs have been good for the NHS and patients
articles.summary: Two letters debate Labour’s plan to use private finance initiatives (PFIs) for NHS buildings. Johnbosco Nwogbo (We Own It) warns PFIs saddle trusts with unsustainable debt—repayments can exceed medicine budgets—and urges Reeves and Streeting to reclaim wasted public funds, levy VAT on private healthcare or explore non-PFI funding. Lord Hutton counters that past PFIs delivered 350 centres and 90 hospitals on time, on budget and with long-term maintenance, while non-PFI schemes face 2032 start dates. Ideology must not hinder patient care.

articles.title: Budget 2025: how inflation and the two-child benefit cap have increased poverty
articles.trailText: A visit to Kent reveals more people struggling with rising food bills and turning to food banks already suffering higher demand and fewer donations
articles.summary: In Herne Bay, a mother of four relying on the Canterbury food bank describes how benefits barely cover essentials: £1 frozen meals, no treats, and constant energy rationing. Demand for parcels has soared from 450 monthly in 2019 to 1,100–1,400 today, pushing the charity’s food spending from £0 to £10k monthly as donations lag and inflation cuts buying power by 10%. Rising bread, meat and veggie costs and benefits capped at two children deepen hardship for 350k families. Volunteers use apps and ‘reverse advent’ drives to source supplies as this cost-of-living crisis becomes the new normal.

articles.title: Bereaved parents face ‘harrowing’ delays for NHS postmorterms
articles.trailText: Shortage of specialist doctors means service is in crisis, says chair of Royal College of Pathologists committee
articles.summary: An RCPath report warns that the NHS faces a critical shortage of paediatric and perinatal pathologists, leaving one in five bereaved parents waiting over six months—some more than a year—for child postmortem results. With 37% of consultant posts vacant, just 52 specialists nationwide, and only 13 trainees, regions like Northern Ireland, the south-west and Midlands lack coverage, forced to transfer cases to Alder Hey in Liverpool. Service collapse delays closure, hampers pregnancy planning and genetic screening. Sands and clinicians urge ministers to boost training posts amid this “dire” staffing crisis.

articles.title: ‘We’ve got to find answers’: Corby families affected by cancer searching for truth about toxic waste sites
articles.trailText: Alison Gaffney believes her son’s rare leukaemia was caused by dumped toxic waste from the town’s steelworks
articles.summary: In response to her son’s rare leukemia diagnosis in 2018, Alison Gaffney joined other former classmates and affected parents in Corby to trace childhood cancer cases back to the 1979 closure of the local steelworks. They allege negligent disposal of millions of tonnes of toxic waste—partially confirmed in a 2009 civil judgment and dramatised by Netflix’s Toxic Town—may have contaminated residential areas. Now representing 130 families, they’ve pressed North Northamptonshire council to locate and test historical dump sites, demand full transparency and urge a statutory public inquiry to establish causation and safeguard future generations.

articles.title: UK gambling firms spent ‘astronomic’ £2bn on advertising last year
articles.trailText: Calls for Rachel Reeves to increase taxes in budget as estimate outstrips duties collected from online casinos
articles.summary: WARC estimates UK gambling firms—bookmakers, online casinos and slot operators—spent an “astronomic” £2bn on advertising and affiliate programmes last year, far outstripping the £1.2bn collected in online casino duties and nearing the £2.5bn raised by all gambling taxes; true spend may be higher due to untracked digital promotions. MPs, think-tanks and former PM Gordon Brown urge chancellor Rachel Reeves to hike duties in her budget, while the Betting and Gaming Council disputes the £2bn claim, citing a £1bn spend and warning tax rises could drive gamblers to black-market operators.

articles.title: South Africa declares gender-based violence a national disaster amid G20 protests
articles.trailText: Women’s groups welcomed the announcement on the eve of the international leaders’ summit in Johannesburg
articles.summary: Hundreds of women across 15 South African cities staged a 15-minute silent lie-down protest in black on the eve of the Johannesburg G20 summit, symbolising the 15 daily femicide victims. Organised by Women For Change’s G20 Women’s Shutdown—which urged women and LGBTQ+ people to halt paid and unpaid work and spending—the month-long campaign amassed over one million petition signatures and social-media support. Responding, NDMC head Dr Bongani Elias Sithole declared gender-based violence and femicide a national disaster after ruling it met Disaster Management Act criteria. President Ramaphosa and minister Velenkosini Hlabisa pledged dedicated resources, while Women For Change plans a detailed action-plan meeting next week.

articles.title: Dangerous shortage of medics threatens safe patient care in England, top GP says
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Royal College of GPs chair says surgeries desperate to hire more doctors but lack funding to do so
articles.summary: Prof Kamila Hawthorne, chair of the Royal College of GPs, warns chronic underfunding has left general practice on the brink: GPs now average 2,241 patients (+16% in 10 years) while delivering 386 m annual consultations, forcing unsafe hours and risking missed conditions. An RCGP survey shows 61% of practices need more doctors but 92% lack funding. Over 8,000 GPs have petitioned Health Secretary Wes Streeting for a detailed 10-year workforce plan with concrete recruitment targets. They say government pledges—£1.1 bn extra funding and 2,500 new GPs—are undercut by higher national insurance contributions, and reject unfunded online access mandates as undeliverable.

articles.title: Coroners’ prevention of future deaths reports should be legally enforced | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: Christine and Francis Saunders , who lost their beloved daughter Juliet, respond to the news that advice on maternal deaths in England and Wales has been routinely ignored
articles.summary: Christine and Francis Saunders, parents of Juliet Saunders who died aged 25 after a misdiagnosis and unsafe hospital discharge, highlight that coroners’ prevention of future deaths (PFD) reports in England and Wales are often ignored. An inquest exposed systemic failings and neglect; the coroner issued a PFD with eight recommendations, but the trust resisted and no legal enforcement followed. The Saunders argue PFDs must be legally binding to safeguard vulnerable patients, especially those with learning disabilities at higher risk of avoidable deaths.

articles.title: Why thousands of NHS GPs are cutting their hours despite plan to increase access to doctors
articles.trailText: Just one in 13 early career GPs work full-time, NHS figures show, with job stress and childcare significant factors
articles.summary: NHS data show early career GPs increasingly opting for part-time work: only 7,480 out of over 30,000 in September 2024 worked more than 37.5 hours—a third fewer than in 2017—and just 8% of 30–34-year-olds are full-time. Average weekly GP hours have fallen by five since 2017. Doctors cite high stress, unremunerated admin, burnout, childcare shortages and punitive tax/pension rules. Meanwhile locum roles remain unfilled as practices cut hiring amid budget pressures. Although headcount has grown, total contracted hours are marginally down. Without stronger recruitment, retention incentives and workload reforms, plans to expand neighbourhood health centres and improve patient access risk being undermined.

articles.title: We know ultra-processed foods are bad for you – but can you spot them? Take our quiz
articles.trailText: Test your knowledge in eight questions to prove you know your onions from your emulsifiers
articles.summary: Global report links ultra-processed foods (UPFs) to damage across major human organs; in the US, UK and Australia, UPFs account for over 50% of daily calories. The Nova classification divides foods into four groups: unprocessed/minimally processed (whole produce, milk, rice), processed ingredients (salt, sugar, oils), processed foods (canned legumes, bread, cheese), and ultra-processed (industrial extracts with additives like emulsifiers, flavours). UPFs’ lengthy, unfamiliar ingredient lists (eg maltodextrin, soy lecithin) signal risk; users can verify products via the Open Food Facts app. Test your skills in our eight-question quiz, vetted by Dr Priscila Machado.

articles.title: How could Reeves hit gambling firms – and are they fearmongering over impact?
articles.trailText: Chancellor is expected to increase duties bookies and casinos pay, ending months of speculation and lobbying
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves is poised to raise gambling duties in next budget, potentially adding £1–3bn in levies on remote gaming duty (21% of profits), machine games (20%) and general betting (15%). Thinktanks (IPPR, SMF) urge RGD to double to 50%, citing social costs; industry warns of 40,000 job losses, illicit market growth and lower receipts. MPs accuse firms of fearmongering. Horse racing seeks carve-outs. Treasury likely to strike a middle path, hiking RGD by ~10–20pp to raise £1–2bn without triggering mass closures.

articles.title: Overseas-trained doctors leaving the UK in record numbers
articles.trailText: Medical bodies warn that hostility towards migrants is behind a 26% rise in departures last year that imperils NHS
articles.summary: Overseas-trained doctors quit the UK in record numbers, with 4,880 departures in 2024—a 26% rise on 3,869 in 2023. Medical bodies blame anti-migrant rhetoric and rising racism for driving away talent, risking huge NHS staffing gaps. Foreign medics make up 42% of the workforce, yet new arrivals plateaued at 20,060, and only one in eight newly registered doctors secured NHS posts within six months. The GMC warns that hostile discourse and reduced training slots for overseas doctors could undermine the UK’s appeal to global medical talent.

articles.title: Prozac ‘no better than placebo’ for treating children with depression, experts say
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Clinical guidelines should change to avoid exposing young people to potentially harmful side-effects, researchers say
articles.summary: Meta-analysis of 12 trials (1997–2024), flagged for ‘novelty bias’ in early studies, finds fluoxetine (Prozac) offers no clinically meaningful benefit over placebo in treating depression among children and adolescents, improving symptoms by a negligible amount akin to a 100-gram weight loss. Experts warn potential side effects—weight gain, sleep disturbance, concentration issues, increased suicidal ideation—outweigh benefits and urge global guidelines (including NICE, US and Canadian) to withdraw pediatric recommendations. NICE defends its stance—psychological therapy first, antidepressants under specialist supervision for moderate to severe cases—while researchers debate the evidence and poorly understood long-term harms.

articles.title: Councils in north of England and Midlands to get more funding in shake-up
articles.trailText: The changes could see funding boosts for Reform-led councils in the north with high levels of deprivation
articles.summary: Ministers have overhauled local funding from April, shifting cash away from affluent rural areas to deprived urban councils in the North and Midlands, guaranteeing real-terms increases over three years. Reform-led authorities like Durham, Lancashire and Kent could get at least £20m annually to limit council tax rises below 5%. The tweaks also restore support for formerly losing areas such as south Tyneside and Wigan. Urban leaders call it a fairer ‘Fair Funding’ formula, while rural CCN and London Councils warn of cuts, bailouts and strained services.

articles.title: Keeping youths in care out of trouble | Letter
articles.trailText: Letters: Prof Mike Stein responds to news of a proposal to restrict the ‘over-policing’ of looked-after young people
articles.summary: Responding in the Guardian letters page to proposals to curb ‘over-policing’ of looked-after young people, Prof Mike Stein welcomes a UK review ending their automatic arrest but stresses crime prevention hinges on stable foster placements, educational success, extended care past 18, supportive birth and social networks, secure housing and robust leaving-care support. Citing international research and the Prison Reform Trust’s 2016 'In Care, Out of Trouble' report, he warns inconsistent opportunities inflict high societal costs. He recommends personal, careers, housing and financial support from specialist leaving-care teams to ensure positive transitions.

articles.title: How prohibition-based policies caused a cannabis problem | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: Prof D Nutt and Prof Ilana Crome respond to an article about the dangers of cannabis-induced psychosis in vulnerable people
articles.summary: Professors D Nutt and Ilana Crome argue that prohibition-based policies have unintentionally driven up street cannabis potency—now the main source for vulnerable users—and thus worsened cannabis-induced psychosis. They cite Drug Science’s T21 project and international prescription data showing medical cannabis can treat psychiatric and neurological conditions without triggering psychosis. They warn that proposals to restrict medical cannabis access in hopes of reducing psychosis rates are misguided and would harm patients benefiting from regulated treatment.

articles.title: Musical comfort at the end of your life | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Choir for the dying | John Crace on Starmer | Storm in a teacup | Paine by name… | Dr Jabalot
articles.summary: Letters respond to various Guardian pieces: Companion Voices, modelled on Kate Munger’s Threshold Choirs, has offered voluntary three-part harmony for the dying across 12 groups in England since Judith Silver founded it 12 years ago. Other correspondents quibble with John Crace’s assessment of Keir Starmer’s Labour, critique the BBC’s adoption of “Storm Cloudier” over reader suggestions, ponder nominative determinism in a dentist Mr Paine of Tooth Acre, and recall their 1962 French family doctor, Dr Jabalot.

articles.title: Up to 50,000 nurses could quit UK over immigration plans, survey suggests
articles.trailText: Exclusive: union leaders say proposed changes are immoral and could threaten patient safety if there is staff exodus
articles.summary: Survey by the Royal College of Nursing suggests up to 46,000–50,000 of the 200,000 internationally educated nurses (25% of the 794,000-strong NHS workforce) could quit the UK if the government extends the qualifying period for indefinite leave to remain from five to ten years, raises skill and English-language requirements and ties visas to employers. Nursing leaders warn this “immoral” shift would deepen staffing crises, endanger patients and derail waiting-time targets. The RCN also highlights risks of exploitation, family distress and benefit exclusion. A public consultation on Keir Starmer’s net-migration plans is imminent; the government maintains workers can reduce settlement time via contributions.

articles.title: ‘Possibly the most prolific sex offender in British history’: the inside story of the Medomsley scandal
articles.trailText: At a youth detention centre in north-east England, the paedophile Neville Husband raped and assaulted countless boys. Why was his reign of terror allowed to go on – and why hasn’t there been a public inquiry?
articles.summary: At Medomsley youth detention centre (1961–87) in north-east England, prison officer Neville Husband orchestrated systematic rape, torture and physical abuse of boys, with 2,852 allegations—388 naming Husband. Successive investigations (Operation Seabrook, PPO’s Operation Deerness) exposed collusion by staff, police intimidation of complainants and institutional failures by the Prison Service, police and Home Office. Victims remain profoundly traumatized, have received no formal apology and are campaigning for a public inquiry with statutory powers to compel testimony.

articles.title: ‘Shock’ loophole in NSW law meant to protect children against incarceration could mean more will be locked up
articles.trailText: Minns government bill says presumption known as doli incapax can be overturned if child knew conduct was ‘seriously wrong’
articles.summary: The NSW Minns government bill codifies doli incapax for 10–14-year-olds but lets prosecutors rebut it if they prove beyond reasonable doubt a child knew their conduct was “seriously wrong,” stripping judges of considering intellectual or moral development. Experts (Associate Prof John Kasinathan, NSW Bar’s Dominic Toomey SC) warn it undermines the 2021 RP v The Queen ruling that saw prosecutions fall from 76% to 16% in six years. Attorney-General Michael Daley cites difficulty getting psychological evidence. Greens’ Sue Higginson will move to delete the loophole.

articles.title: Microsoft has ‘ripped off the NHS’, says MP amid call for contracts with British firms
articles.trailText: Samantha Niblett highlighted government’s multi-billion-pound deals with Microsoft and ‘getting locked in’
articles.summary: Labour MP Samantha Niblett alleged Microsoft 'ripped off the NHS', criticizing a five-year, £700m productivity tools deal. MPs on the science and technology committee warned that US firms lock public services in long-term contracts, inflating costs. Government licensing outlay reached £1.9bn in 2024-25, while overall public-sector tech spend hit £21bn. Ian Murray (minister) and DSIT officials conceded fragmentation, pledging to boost UK suppliers, strengthen sovereign capacity and reform procurement. Niblett cited outdated Windows 10 renewals at Defra triggering extra security fees. Emily Darlington pressed reliance on US vendors such as Palantir’s £330m NHS data platform, arguing for homegrown capacity to bolster security.

articles.title: Pam Zinkin obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives : Paediatrician and expert in the care of children in war and disaster
articles.summary: Pam Zinkin (died aged 94) was a British consultant paediatrician and NHS campaigner whose global work spanned war, disaster and disability. In 1977, as head of paediatrics at Maputo Central Hospital in newly independent Mozambique, she cut child mortality from 25% to 4% in five years and trained a generation of local doctors. Later, she advised WHO, UNICEF, Save the Children, Oxfam and Medical Aid for Palestinians, set up community-based rehabilitation and emergency child-care courses at the Institute of Child Health, and lobbied for public health. A lifelong activist in anti-Vietnam War and anti-apartheid movements, she balanced academic posts with single parenthood and remained professionally active into her nineties.

articles.title: I am the king of the common cold – and I can tell you how to avoid one | Adrian Chiles
articles.trailText: No one suffers a cold like I do. Drops and brandy don’t touch the sides – but thanks to a friendly singer, I’ve learned a more extreme regime for countering the snuffles, writes Adrian Chiles
articles.summary: Adrian Chiles describes his uniquely severe, prolonged colds—loud coughs, blocked nose, failed remedies from sprays, drops, plum brandy to raw onions—and his embarrassment on-air and at home. Last winter, amid rehearsals with a rapper, pop star and mezzo-soprano, he adopted the singer’s intense prevention regime: hourly hand sanitiser all winter plus party prep and post-care with two blasts of Vicks First Defence per nostril. The routine kept him cold-free through winter; he’s fully stocked again for the season ahead. His family and studio colleagues would clear the room at the first cough or sniffle.

articles.title: Are resident doctors right to strike over pay? | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Elizabeth Taylor fully backs industrial action and feels that doctors have been taken advantage of for decades; Dr Natasha de Vere would not consider striking
articles.summary: Two letters debate resident doctors’ strike: Elizabeth Taylor Norton, a retired consultant anaesthetist, backs industrial action, citing decades of underpayment, unsafe 80–100-hour weeks, minimal overtime rates and loss of staff due to high stress, arguing for up-to-date pay recompense after governments exploited doctors as cheap labour. In contrast, Dr Natasha de Vere, a paediatric NHS consultant, rejects strike action, values her good salary and work-life balance, and notes lack of alternative representation outside the BMA.

articles.title: Labour is privatising the NHS in plain sight | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Private appointments, tests and operations are a grave threat to the future of the health service, writes Margaret Greenwood
articles.summary: Margaret Greenwood warns that the NHS reorganisation and rising private provision—6.15m appointments, tests and operations delivered by independent providers this year, up 500,000—amount to open privatisation. Finite medical staff drawn into private work undermine NHS capacity and training of future clinicians. Private providers now perform 30% of hip replacements (0.1% in 2002–03). Newcastle University research links this substitution to reduced in-house services and longer waits. Greenwood urges the government to end private sector reliance to protect the NHS’s future.

articles.title: Krysty was diagnosed with breast cancer months after getting the all-clear. New Australian guidelines aim to help women like her
articles.trailText: Exclusive: New federal guidelines advise GPs to provide additional care to patients with higher breast density, which can make cancers harder to detect in mammograms
articles.summary: Krysty Sullivan, 48, received a clear mammogram in 2019 but was diagnosed with aggressive triple-negative breast cancer 11 months later after a lump appeared. Her high breast density (Bi-RADS D), which lowers mammogram sensitivity and raises cancer risk, was not communicated to her. New federal GP guidelines recommend informing women of dense breast findings, assessing additional risk factors, and considering further imaging or risk-based screening under Medicare. Developed with input from consumers and experts, the guidance aims to standardize GP advice, personalize care and detect cancers earlier without promoting unnecessary over-screening. GPs will need support to implement and monitor the impact of these changes.

articles.title: Mahmood and Lammy breached human rights law over segregation of prisoner, judge finds
articles.trailText: Treatment of terrorist with known mental health needs said to have contravened prohibition on inhuman or degrading treatment
articles.summary: Mr Justice Sheldon ruled that justice secretaries Shabana Mahmood and David Lammy breached article 3 of the ECHR by subjecting Sahayb Abu—a convicted terrorist with documented trauma and mental health issues—to an enhanced segregation regime at HMP Woodhill. Following Hashem Abedi’s attack on officers, Abu spent 22 hours a day in isolation for over four months without assessment or therapy, triggering PTSD, paranoia and suicidal ideation. This landmark judgment is the first to hold ministers directly liable for inhuman or degrading treatment in custody.

articles.title: Coroners’ advice on maternal deaths in England and Wales routinely ignored, study finds
articles.trailText: Nearly two-thirds of ‘prevention of future deaths’ reports by coroners are not acted upon, say researchers at King’s College London
articles.summary: A King’s College London study of 29 coroner Prevention of Future Death reports (2013–2023) on maternal fatalities in England and Wales reveals nearly two-thirds go unaddressed. Over half of deaths followed childbirth, with haemorrhage, early-pregnancy complications and suicide most common. Coroners cited failures in treatment escalation and staff training, yet only 38% of NHS bodies responded within the 56-day legal deadline. England’s maternal mortality rate is 12.82 per 100,000 births (2021–23). Researchers urge embedding PFD findings into Baroness Amos’s independent maternity investigation and government taskforce to prevent repeat tragedies.

articles.title: NHS failing to cut waiting times as promised in recovery plan, report warns
articles.trailText: Public accounts committee finds Labour’s progress ‘appears to have stalled’ despite billions of pounds in investment
articles.summary: The public accounts committee warns that, despite over £3.2bn invested in community diagnostic centres and surgical hubs, the NHS recovery plan has stalled. Elective waiting lists remain at 7.4m pathways—just 220,000 fewer since July 2024—with 192,000 patients waiting over a year and 22% still facing diagnostic delays beyond six weeks, missing the 5% target. PAC criticises the unplanned NHS reorganisation under Streeting as costly and akin to HS2 failures. Ministers point to a 230,000 backlog reduction, but charities and opposition parties say patients continue to suffer dangerous delays, undermining the 18-week pledge by 2029.

articles.title: Lack of planning has hit Labour’s efforts to fix public services, says thinktank
articles.trailText: Keir Starmer accused of failing to adequately strategise while in opposition, leading to uncoordinated policymaking
articles.summary: An Institute for Government report led by Nick Davies criticises Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s lack of strategic planning in opposition, blaming it for haphazard first-year reforms across health, courts, prisons and social care. Only children’s social services saw clear progress; adult social care worsened and five areas, including GPs and hospitals, saw little change. Analysts cite poor cross-department coordination, funding mismatches—NHS budgets rising faster than local government—and contradictory moves like redrawing NHS board boundaries before a local government review, warning Starmer must act fast to meet targets ahead of the next election.

articles.title: Ultra-processed food linked to harm in every major human organ, study finds
articles.trailText: World’s largest scientific review warns consumption of UPFs poses seismic threat to global health and wellbeing
articles.summary: A Lancet series of three papers reviewing 104 long-term studies by 43 experts finds ultra-processed foods (UPFs) harm every major organ system and elevate risks of obesity, type 2 diabetes, heart disease, depression and early mortality. UPF intake—now over 50% of diets in the US/UK and up to 80% among disadvantaged groups—is driven by profit-oriented corporations employing aggressive marketing, additives and lobbying to skew science and block regulation. Authors advocate Nova-based UPF labelling, tighter marketing restrictions (especially for children), bans in schools, and policies to curb production and restore fresh foods, citing Brazil’s school-meal success.

articles.title: Plastic surgeons wrestle with requests for ‘Mar-a-Lago face’: ‘You’re going to look like Maleficent’
articles.trailText: The puffy, artificial look is rising in popularity - thanks to Maga elite such as Kristi Noem and Matt Gaetz
articles.summary: Washington DC plastic surgeons report a rise in patients requesting the so-called "Mar-a-Lago face" – exaggerated, bee-stung lips, frozen brows and overfilled cheeks popularized by MAGA figures like Kristi Noem and Matt Gaetz. Surgeons describe a trend toward obvious, politicized enhancements imported from Florida, driven by younger Trump aides and a culture embracing body contouring. While some practices advertise the look, many DC doctors refuse unsafe filler levels, warning of lumpy results and "perception blindness." They argue these procedures are temporary, reflecting a fleeting political aesthetic rather than lasting style.

articles.title: ‘I knew I was starting to have a seizure’: women describe lasting effects of being ‘choked’ during sex
articles.trailText: Three women tell of blacking out, feeling dazed and dizzy, and of ongoing memory issues and fatigue
articles.summary: Three women share lasting consequences of consensual sexual choking—seizures, blackouts, chronic headaches, memory lapses and fatigue—despite lacking visible injuries. A major study found over 50% of under-35s report strangulation during sex, often modeled on violent porn and popularized by teen exposure online. Victims faced denial, shame and reluctance to seek medical care, risking brain injury, strokes and anoxic hypoxia. Advocates call for legal bans (UK outlawing such content by year-end), platform restrictions, better consent education and immediate medical evaluation for anyone experiencing strangulation-related symptoms.

articles.title: Nearly half of sexually active young people in UK have experienced strangulation, study shows
articles.trailText: Survey reveals crisis of distress, consent issues and physical harm caused by strangulation during sex
articles.summary: Survey by Institute for Addressing Strangulation (Ifas) finds 43% of sexually active UK 16–17-year-olds and over half under-35 have experienced or inflicted “choking” during sex, often without clear consent. 36% reported fear, 21% suffered symptoms from dizziness to unconsciousness, yet most didn’t seek medical help. Men more often enact strangulation, with 5% admitting over 50 incidents. Mainstream porn is cited as the primary influence. Experts warn of long-term brain, nerve and mental health damage and note UK’s upcoming ban on strangulation pornography. The report calls for awareness campaigns and highlights legal gaps around consent and serious harm.

articles.title: Children in care who lash out may no longer face automatic arrest under UK review
articles.trailText: Plan aims to restrict ‘over-policing’ of looked-after young people and ensure challenging behaviour is met with support rather than criminalisation
articles.summary: A planned UK government review will require stronger limits on automatic arrest or charging of looked-after children who assault staff or damage property, replacing criminalisation with targeted support such as trauma counselling. Children in care—ten times likelier than peers to receive cautions or convictions—would benefit from a tightened 2018 protocol against over-policing. Deputy PM David Lammy and children’s commissioner Rachel de Souza cite cases like an autistic boy fined over a minor incident. Research shows low-level incidents in care often escalate into criminal records, a trend the review aims to reverse by spring.

articles.title: Woman killed herself after south London hospital neglect, coroner concludes
articles.trailText: Michelle Sparman, 48, died after staff at Queen Mary’s hospital in Roehampton failed to search her possessions adequately, inquest finds
articles.summary: In August 2021 personal trainer and police call dispatcher Michelle Sparman, 48, took her own life at Kingston hospital after staff at Queen Mary’s Roehampton psychiatric Rose Ward failed to adequately search her for harmful items on admission and discharge, despite red flags as a voluntary inpatient. Assistant coroner Bernard Richmond KC ruled 'suicide whilst balance of mind disturbed, contributed by neglect' and cited her anxiety, depression, perimenopausal symptoms, financial strain and toxic ex-partner messaging. He will issue a report recommending centralized records of dangerous items in mental health wards.

articles.title: ‘It’s cruel’: relatives of residents react to proposal to close Lancashire care homes
articles.trailText: Elderly residents of care home left anxious after Reform-led county council started consultation over plans for its closure
articles.summary: Reform-led Lancashire county council's consultation to close five local authority care homes, including Woodlands in Accrington, has sparked outcry from residents and relatives. Families such as Phil Aspden’s and Dorothy Devereux's accuse the council of prioritizing budgets and ‘Doge’ efficiency over vulnerable elders’ wellbeing, citing outdated data, insufficient alternatives, and dementia patients’ distress. MP Sarah Smith warns the changes may cost more and erode frontline services, while cabinet member Dalton says the review seeks sustainable, high-quality care and invites public input before February’s decision.

articles.title: Why is social mobility such an obsession? | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Surely the focus should be on making all occupations viable, rewarded and respected, says Mary Evans
articles.summary: In a Guardian letter Mary Evans critiques the narrow obsession with social mobility in English secondary education reforms. She argues that governments overlook the more socially radical, equitable goal of ensuring every occupation is viable, respected and properly rewarded. By framing jobs as ladders to escape, policy entrenches class competition, diminishes the value of essential roles and excludes children who don’t conform to this success narrative. Evans calls for policymakers to challenge underlying values that foster failure and exclusion, promoting mutual respect and true social equality across all professions.

articles.title: ‘Better and cheaper’: the case for prostate cancer screening among black men
articles.trailText: Decision over routine PSA testing is due at end of this month, though some feel the supporting data is unclear
articles.summary: Junior Hemans diagnosed after requesting a PSA test; black men face a one in four lifetime risk, double the national average. The UK National Screening Committee will decide on NHS screening next month, with Prostate Cancer UK advocating targeted PSA tests for black men aged 45–69, citing strong evidence for earlier detection, cost-effectiveness and equity. Critics warn of unclear data due to higher baseline PSA levels, over-diagnosis concerns and limited genomic research. The Transform trial, including 10% black participants, aims to fill evidence gaps, and experts urge proactive GP outreach if formal screening is delayed.

articles.title: Stephen Dawson obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Doctor who established an integrated sexual health service in Slough
articles.summary: Stephen Dawson (d.2025) was a pioneering urologist who, after charting early HIV-opportunistic diseases in London, in 1988 became the first consultant in genitourinary medicine in east Berkshire. Over 28 years at Upton Hospital he expanded a three-doctor unit into the UK’s first fully integrated sexual health service, later adopted nationwide. Beyond medicine he wrote three short films screened internationally, painted award-shortlisted acrylic portraits and reached the Times crossword final. He retired to Hastings and died of cancer aged 78, survived by partner Dimitry Kalinin.

articles.title: Two-thirds of nurses in UK work while unwell, says union
articles.trailText: Understaffing is driving workers to ill health and discouraging them for taking leave, says Royal College of Nursing CEO
articles.summary: An RCN survey of over 20,000 UK nurses finds 66% worked while ill (up from 49% in 2017), with 65% citing stress (up from 50%). Seven in ten exceed contracted hours weekly, half unpaid. England faces 25,000 nursing vacancies. RCN chief Nicola Ranger warns understaffing is driving burnout, panic attacks and chronic illness and calls for urgent investment to grow staff. Staffing-related helpline calls are set to reach 2,175 this year. The NHS highlights wellbeing advocates and a graduate guarantee to ease pressure.

articles.title: ‘I’d run down the road thinking I was God’: a day at the cannabis psychosis clinic
articles.trailText: Katie hears voices and has been sectioned 50 times. Isiah became paranoid and tried to kill himself. Both link their illness to cannabis – and the drug is getting more and more potent. Is a tiny London clinic showing the way forward?
articles.summary: The Cannabis Clinic for Patients with Psychosis in south London offers specialist dual-diagnosis support for adults whose severe psychosis is fuelled by daily high-potency cannabis, providing weekly one-to-ones, online groups, monthly brunches and practical tools (craving boxes, cannabis diaries, role-play). Founded by Dr Marta Di Forti with NHS and King’s support, it has helped 90 patients (74% quit, 91% re-enter work/education) yet faces long waits. Cases like Isiah’s suicide attempt and Katie’s 50 detentions illustrate rising psychosis linked to 14–16% THC skunk strains dominating London and an urgent need to scale this integrated model.

articles.title: Hundreds of low-paid NHS hospital staff win improved terms after strike threat
articles.trailText: More than 330 workers, mainly cleaners, caterers and porters, at St George’s, Epsom and St Helier hospital group had voted to strike
articles.summary: Hundreds of cleaners, caterers and porters at St George’s, Epsom and St Helier hospital group won full NHS Agenda for Change contracts after 98% of 330 facilities staff voted to strike. In-house since 2021 but excluded from AfC terms, they’d lost £32m in pay, £6m in pensions, earned £13.85 vs £14.92/hr, had reduced holiday and 3% employer pensions. After UVW accusations of institutional racism and a Nov 6 board vote, they secure £2,000+ pay rise, NHS leave and 23.7% pensions from April 2026. Staff hailed this as a victory for equality and better family life, praising improved weekend rates.

articles.title: Call for inquiry after families stripped of child benefit due to flawed travel data
articles.trailText: Andrew Snowden MP says government ‘must immediate take action’ on failures of anti-fraud benefits crackdown
articles.summary: Thousands of families had child benefit wrongly suspended after unreliable Home Office travel data flagged them as overseas. Flight logs recorded departures without returns, misidentifying parents as absent. Andrew Snowden (Conservative MP) demands an independent inquiry into how flawed exit/entry records were used to suspend payments, urging full publication of findings. HMRC froze benefits for 23,500 households, causing hardship, missed rent, debt. Treasury Committee and Lib Dems also seek answers. Former Border Inspector John Vine warns broader system failures. Privacy experts call it function creep in Passenger Name Record use. HMRC apologised and tightened suspension process.

articles.title: ‘I was scared’: parents reveal stress of HMRC’s child benefit errors
articles.trailText: From incorrect repayment demands to mistaken claims about emigration or non-existent holidays, those caught in anti-fraud debacle tell their stories
articles.summary: HMRC's new anti-fraud checks wrongly flagged dozens of parents as emigrants, demanding repayment of thousands in child benefit based on flawed Home Office data. Tetiana, a Ukrainian refugee and carer, was told she'd left the UK in 2020; Sharna Vincent, recovering from sepsis, was accused of a phantom Portugal holiday; lecturer Jess Paine forced to hand over sensitive medical and bank records after an unbooked Mexico flight; and postpartum Sarah Butler had to prove an Ireland visit. All endured severe stress navigating unresponsive HMRC and inadequate appeals.

articles.title: ‘It was the last time Mum smiled at me’: the choirs singing to the dying in three-part harmony
articles.trailText: A worldwide movement to sing gentle songs to the dying provides comfort, peace and release to both the suffering and the singers
articles.summary: Ballina’s Threshold Choir, one of 185 worldwide chapters founded by Kate Munger in California 25 years ago, sings gentle three-part lullaby harmonies to the dying and their carers in homes, hospitals and hospices. Under musical director Cathy Ridd, members rehearse weekly and follow strict bedside protocols—block colours, seated close, 20-minute sets from a 500-song library. Families like Joy Hurnall’s and Heather Wood’s report profound peace, emotional release and a treasured final shared experience.

articles.title: ‘There is a gap where Alex should be’: the young woman who lost her life in a neglectful prison system
articles.trailText: An inquest has found a Cheshire prison guilty of neglect after Alex Davies, 25, was found dead inside a segregation cell after a lifetime of mental health struggles
articles.summary: Alex Davies, 25, who had severe borderline personality disorder and PTSD from childhood sexual abuse, died by neglect in Styal prison’s segregation cell on Christmas Eve after four psychiatrists recommended a hospital transfer within 28 days of her sentence. Despite her self-harm history and national guidelines against isolating at-risk inmates, Alex spent 27 days on the care and separation unit, was stripped to boxer shorts, observed by male officers triggering her trauma, and denied constant watch. A coroner’s inquest ruled neglect contributed to her death. Her family, who recall her talent as a footballer and longstanding mental health struggles, demand accountability and prison reform to prevent similar tragedies.

articles.title: AI, Covid and taxes: what is behind steep rise in youth unemployment?
articles.trailText: Last year’s employer NICs increase and a weak economy are adding to tricky conditions for young people
articles.summary: UK youth unemployment (16–24) has hit 15.3%, the highest since the Covid lockdowns. Key drivers include a sluggish economy marked by high inflation and weak demand, a 1.2-point rise in employer NICs and a lower earnings threshold that discourage part-time hires, higher youth wage floors that may price out entry-level workers, AI and automation replacing basic tasks, Covid-induced education disruptions, surging mental health issues and prolonged austerity and public service cuts hampering job entry.

articles.title: ‘It’s so demoralising’: UK graduates exasperated by high unemployment
articles.trailText: Many question value of their degrees and hard work when confronted with a brutally competitive jobs market
articles.summary: UK graduates, despite first-class degrees and internships, face a brutal job market with youth unemployment at 15.3%, the highest since 2015. Applicants report over 100 applications for a handful of interviews, hampered by AI CV filters and entry-level roles demanding years of experience. Many rely on universal credit or temporary, unrelated work to survive. Cases include a marketing graduate stalling after six months, an A-level leaver blocked by ‘experience’ requirements, and a journalism grad now working in a supermarket fearing skill erosion.

articles.title: English councils plan to sell off social clubs and sports centres to balance books
articles.trailText: Survey finds 60% of key cities councils are planning to sell assets to meet costs of adult and children’s social care
articles.summary: Survey of key cities councils finds 60% plan to fire-sell social clubs, sports centres and shopping arcades to plug escalating adult and children’s social care budgets, reversing 2024’s focus on service redesign. Medway council will sell Rainham shopping centre, Rochester social club, Gillingham golf club and business parks to raise £20m over five years. Over 70% intend council-tax hikes next April amid rising SEND, adult social care and homelessness costs. County councils foresee deficits hitting £4.4bn by 2029, with many key cities among England’s most deprived.

articles.title: Why the NHS doctors’ strikes look set to continue
articles.trailText: The BMA and Wes Streeting are poles apart, with the union committed to full pay restoration and the health secretary adamant there is no money for that
articles.summary: Resident doctors in England have staged 13 strike days since March 2023 over full pay restoration to 2008 levels, claiming inflation-eroded salaries need a further 26% rise despite a 29% increase in three years. Led by the BMA’s resident doctors committee—shaped by the 2022 Doctors Vote faction—their dispute has forced 1.5m rescheduled appointments and added a chronic training-place shortage to demands. Health secretary Wes Streeting rejects further funds. With a new ballot due in January 2026 and both sides entrenched, further monthly strikes look set to continue.

articles.title: Palliative care and choice must be at the heart of the assisted dying debate | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to an article by Rachel Clarke on how people are dying without the support they need
articles.summary: Letters in response to Rachel Clarke highlight that the assisted dying debate has catalysed record focus and investment in palliative care: UK’s £100m hospice funding traceable to the terminally ill adults bill, say experts. Global experts from the UK and Australia cite similar effects. Panel members note palliative care featured heavily in Lords committee discussions, but acknowledge that even optimal care cannot relieve all end-of-life suffering. Contributors call for expanded 24/7 home-visiting GP services, unified funding models replacing patchwork charity support, and legal choice to ensure autonomy when care alone fails. Personal testimony underscores limits of even excellent palliative care.

articles.title: Sectioned children face more trauma in the institutions supposed to protect them | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: A parent replies to an article by Kate Szymankiewicz about her 14-year-old daughter Ruth, who died after being detained under the Mental Health Act
articles.summary: A parent responds to Kate Szymankiewicz’s story by describing her own 14-year-old’s three Mental Health Act sectionings and 15 months in locked wards for an eating disorder, where self-harm, absconding and no therapeutic support were daily realities. Isolated in an opaque system, they fought for and finally accessed a six-week out-of-area family support group, exposing gaps between policy and practice. Now in private therapy, the daughter is treated for institutional trauma, while the family contends with lost choice and lasting guilt.

articles.title: Maureen McGinley obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives : Nun who spent much of her life working to support people with HIV and Aids in Hong Kong
articles.summary: Maureen McGinley, 77, a Columban Sister, pioneered HIV/AIDS care in Hong Kong. Born in Clydebank, Scotland, she trained in London, was sent to Hong Kong in 1976, nursing at Ruttonjee sanatorium. In 1994 she founded the Society for AIDS Care (SAC), the first NGO offering home nursing and hospice services, opening an SAC hospice in 1997. A member of Hong Kong’s Advisory Council on AIDS (1993–99) and MBE (1995), she advocated for haemophiliac children infected via contaminated blood. Stricken by dementia in her late 50s, she spent her final years in Ireland. Survived by siblings John, Gerry and another sister.

articles.title: UK hospitals bracing for once-in-a-decade flu surge this winter
articles.trailText: Officials urge vaccination against mutated strain of virus that may be more transmissible than usual
articles.summary: In response to an early, fast-spreading H3N2 flu strain mutated by antigenic drift, UK hospitals expect a once-in-a-decade winter surge driven by infections in younger people reaching vulnerable elders. Genetic links to Australia’s record season, an elevated R of ~1.4, and lower vaccine match heighten concerns. NHS is scaling up staff/community vaccinations, expanding same-day emergency care, invoking strike contingency plans and shifting care out of hospitals to mitigate admissions. Early vaccine effectiveness remains 70–75% in children and 30–40% in adults, still protective against severe disease. Health chiefs urge high-risk groups to vaccinate.

articles.title: Resident doctors begin five-day strike in latest walkout over pay
articles.trailText: Thirteenth action since March 2023 will put further pressure on stretched budgets, say NHS groups
articles.summary: Resident doctors across England began a five-day strike – their 13th walkout since March 2023 – demanding a 26% pay rise to offset inflation. NHS Confederation and NHS Providers warn the action will worsen budget strains and force tens of thousands of cancellations, citing July’s industrial action cost of £300m and 54,000 shelved procedures. Leaders warn winter performance faces extra pressure amid rising flu. Health secretary Wes Streeting points to a near-30% three-year pay offer; the BMA refuses 'derogations' without trusts cancelling planned work and arranging cover. Patients are urged to attend appointments and seek emergency care via 999, A&E or NHS 111.

articles.title: New AI tool could cut wasted efforts to transplant organs by 60%
articles.trailText: Machine learning model predicts whether donor is likely to die within the timeframe that liver remains viable
articles.summary: Stanford researchers built a machine learning model to predict whether donation after circulatory death (DCD) liver donors will die within the 45-minute viability window, cutting futile transplant preparations by 60% versus expert surgeons. Trained on neurological, respiratory and circulatory data from over 2,000 donors—and robust to missing inputs—the tool outperformed human judgment in retrospective and prospective tests. Published in Lancet Digital Health, it aims to streamline organ use, reduce costs and expand access, with plans to adapt it for heart and lung transplants.

articles.title: Peers to mount fresh offensive to halt assisted dying bill
articles.trailText: More than half of the 942 amendments have been tabled by seven lords in move which could filibuster legislation
articles.summary: Peers in the House of Lords will table 942 amendments—over half by seven vocal opponents—to slow or filibuster the assisted dying bill, a private member’s bill by Labour MP Kim Leadbeater passed by Commons in June. Opponents argue Lords can block it as it wasn’t in the government manifesto; supporters, including 65 peers from crossbenchers to ex-cabinet ministers, warn it’s anti-democratic to frustrate the Commons mandate. Former doctor Ilora Finlay and ex-Paralympian Tanni Grey-Thompson have each tabled over 100 amendments; ex-health secretary Thérèse Coffey has lodged 60. Backers remain confident a majority will refine, not reject, the bill.

articles.title: Hospital consultants gearing up to join resident doctors in striking over pay
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Move could cause huge disruption and present ministers with major new headache
articles.summary: Hospital consultants, via the BMA, are poised to join resident doctors’ strikes over pay unless their demand for a 5.5% rise (versus the government’s 4%) is met by 31 December, or they will ballot for action in January. Residents, pursuing a 26% real-terms restoration, plan monthly walkouts after their mandate expires on 6 January. Combined strikes early in 2026 could disrupt NHS winter services, derail 18-week referral targets and deepen a 7.39 million backlog, intensifying pressure on Health Secretary Wes Streeting.

articles.title: Steve Reed convenes Tower Hamlets envoys as concerns over council persist
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Communities secretary calls meeting over two councillors seeking electoral candidacy in Bangladesh
articles.summary: Communities Secretary Steve Reed has summoned government envoys overseeing Tower Hamlets council to review progress after inspectors last year exposed a “toxic” culture under Mayor Lutfur Rahman. Reed’s call follows his rebuke of two councillors pursuing parliamentary nominations in Bangladesh while local governance reforms are underway. A July envoy report praised some improvements but flagged poor cooperation from the mayor’s office. A further report is due by year’s end before next May’s London council elections, amid opposition complaints of ongoing patronage and service failures.

articles.title: ‘Are you building communities or just houses?’: human cost of Birmingham council’s plans for Druids Heath estate
articles.trailText: Residents say they face being priced out or pushed out as 1,800 properties are demolished – with only a fraction of affordable homes guaranteed
articles.summary: After decades of underinvestment, Birmingham council narrowly approved by one-vote margin demolishing 1,800 homes on the aging Druids Heath estate to build 3,500 new units – only 400 (11%) social-rent homes are formally guaranteed, although a non-binding partnership with Homes England promises 1,785 affordable units. Residents, offered market value plus 10% compensation (£180k average), warn buy-outs won’t match rising costs and right-to-return schemes could stretch 15–20 years. They decry poor consultation, fear price gouging, and question if regeneration truly builds community or merely new housing.

articles.title: Ultra-processed foods may help explain rising bowel cancer in under-50s, study suggests
articles.trailText: Research among women finds those who eat more UPFs have greater risk of early onset of polyp that can lead to cancer
articles.summary: In a prospective analysis of 29,105 US women under 50 from the Nurses’ Health Study II (1991–2015), those consuming the most ultra-processed foods (9.9 servings/day) had a 45% higher risk of early-onset conventional adenomas compared with lowest consumers (3.3/day), independent of BMI, smoking and activity; no association was seen for serrated lesions. Participants completed food frequency questionnaires every 4 years and underwent colonoscopy. Published in JAMA Oncology, the study notes limitations—self-reported diet, UPF classification, lack of direct cancer outcomes—and suggests metabolic, inflammatory and microbiome pathways.

articles.title: Council staff visited wrong address day before Sara Sharif’s murder, review finds
articles.trailText: Education secretary says report highlights ‘glaring failures and missed opportunities’ by various agencies
articles.summary: An independent review into the August 2023 killing of 10-year-old Sara Sharif reveals multi-agency failures: social services never flagged her abuse, ignored unexplained bruises and missed over 25 fractures, and a 7 August home-education visit went to the wrong address. Sara was fatally beaten by her father, Urfan Sharif (40-year minimum term), and stepmother Beinash Batool (33 years), after years of escalating violence. The report urges agencies to ‘think the unthinkable’, tighten homeschooling checks, improve cultural awareness and ensure formal parent-professional discussions. Sara’s uncle was jailed for 16 years for allowing her death, and the education secretary calls for urgent reforms.

articles.title: The rapid rise of renters in their 60s: ‘I hate the idea of house-sharing – but I have no choice’
articles.trailText: It is often assumed that people of retirement age will no longer have housing costs to cover. But for a significant and growing group, this is far from the case
articles.summary: Retirees increasingly confront rent bills and flatsharing: ex-teacher Deborah Herring, 65, now accepts £1 000-a-month London flatshares; Pensions Policy Institute projects UK over-65 private renting rising from 6% now to 17% by 2040. SpareRoom reports over-55 users jumped from 2.7% in 2014 to 7.1% in 2024. Cases like 68-year-old Andreas Savva renting a mouldy £800-pm house and 63-year-old Tamara Kocsubej facing age bias reveal financial strain, housing stock shortages, inaccessibility (only 12% of homes for over-75s have step-free access) and demand for affordable, adaptable, communal options.

articles.title: Deaths linked to antibiotic-resistant superbugs rose 17% in England in 2024
articles.trailText: Data also shows an average of nearly 400 newly reported cases of antibiotic-resistant infections a week last year
articles.summary: UK Health Security Agency data show a 17% rise in deaths from antibiotic-resistant infections in England, increasing from 2,041 in 2023 to 2,379 in 2024, and a 9.3% rise in resistant bacteraemia cases (18,740 to 20,484), averaging nearly 400 new cases weekly. NHS primary-care antibiotic prescribing fell between 2019 and 2024, but private dispensing more than doubled—accounting for 22% of community prescriptions—partly due to the Pharmacy First scheme. Prof Susan Hopkins warns unchecked resistance poses a grave threat, urging patients to use antibiotics only when prescribed, return leftovers for disposal. Overall primary-care antibiotic use rose 10.7% over the same period.

articles.title: Private care providers in three English regions make £250m in three years
articles.trailText: More than third of profits analysed went to firms owned by private equity or based in tax havens, research finds
articles.summary: Between 2021 and 2024 private care firms in the North East, South Yorkshire and West Midlands extracted £256m in profits from publicly funded services, with over a third (£87.7m) flowing to private equity owners or tax-haven parent companies. Of that, £45m was paid in dividends and £33.6m in interest, often boosting directors’ pay while frontline staff earned below a living wage. Directors earned up to 60 times the average wage. The report by CLES, CTP, Co-operatives UK and New Economics Foundation warns of public money ‘leaking out’, urging legal profit caps and procurement reforms to redirect funds into care provision rather than investor returns.

articles.title: ‘Sobering’ study reveals extent of bullying and mental health problems for children in Wales
articles.trailText: Study of 50,000 pupils aged 7-11 also finds most struggle to sleep, and fewer than half eat fruit or vegetables every day
articles.summary: SHRN’s survey of 51,662 Welsh primary pupils (age 7–11) across all 22 authorities finds 68% sometimes/always have sleep problems (15% bedtime after 10 pm), 30% exhibit elevated or clinically significant emotional difficulties (higher among girls, low-affluence families and non-binary pupils), 51% report recent bullying (29% of Year 6 pupils cyberbullied), under half eat daily fruit (48%) or vegetables (37%), and 69% rate high life satisfaction (declines with age). Researchers and the children’s commissioner call for mental health “one-stop shops,” increased school-based staff, early intervention and preventive support. The Welsh government is investing £13 m+ annually in a whole-school mental health approach, including £3 m for school counselling, and will use these findings to shape anti-bullying and wellbeing policies.

articles.title: Domestic violence victims at risk under bill aimed at easing prison overcrowding, watchdog warns
articles.trailText: Victims and survivors “will be put in harm’s way” with “devastating consequences”, domestic abuse commissioner says
articles.summary: Dame Nicole Jacobs, the domestic abuse commissioner, warns a sentencing bill aimed at easing prison overcrowding by making permanent 56-day fixed-term recalls for most licence breaches would endanger survivors by permitting violent partners to resume stalking and abuse without parole board oversight. In a letter to Lord Chancellor David Lammy, she calls for amendments requiring fresh risk assessments for domestic abuse perpetrators before release. Official data show a 36% rise in recalls year-on-year, 75% due to licence breaches. The government argues longer recall windows allow probation to implement robust safeguards; only terrorists and high-risk criminals remain exempt.

articles.title: Reeves rejects plea for £1bn of extra cash to cover NHS redundancy payouts
articles.trailText: Health secretary Wes Streeting lobbied behind the scenes for emergency funds to pay off 18,000 staff losing their jobs
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves has refused Health Secretary Wes Streeting’s request for a standalone £1bn emergency cash injection to fund redundancy payouts for 18,000 NHS staff, instead permitting the Department of Health and Social Care (DHSC) to overspend this year by £1bn only to face a reduced 2026–27 settlement. Streeting had lobbied to support the planned mass layoff of half the integrated care board workforce amid a major NHS restructure. Disagreements over covering rising drug prices scuppered Treasury talks. The DHSC stressed no new net funding was granted, NHS front-line budgets remain protected, and the redundancy programme will proceed.

articles.title: Children being ‘sedated’ by algorithmic YouTube content, MPs hear
articles.trailText: Experts including children’s laureate lament low quality of entertainment and call for more funding for children’s TV
articles.summary: At a culture, media and sport inquiry, children’s laureate Frank Cottrell-Boyce warned algorithmic YouTube channels like CoComelon sedate rather than stimulate toddlers, lacking repetition, slowness and shared cultural experience. He blamed frictionless, personalized feeds for rising anxiety as youngsters loop into homogeneous content. Media Foundation director Greg Childs OBE added that YouTube’s 62% under-16 viewing share undermines curated broadcast TV, damages wellbeing and underfunds creators despite £700m annual ad revenue. Both called on government to renew the Young Audiences Fund via a streamers’ levy, introduce content ratings and regulation, and use AI to prioritize public-service and quality programming.

articles.title: David Lammy says 91 prisoners freed in error in England and Wales since April
articles.trailText: Justice secretary tells MPs as many as four may still be at large and blames previous governments’ cuts for mistakes
articles.summary: Justice Secretary David Lammy told MPs that 91 prisoners have been mistakenly released in England and Wales since April, with up to four still at large. He blamed cuts under previous Conservative governments—6,000 frontline officers lost from 2010–17—for a 128% year-on-year rise to 262 erroneous releases by March 2025. Among those at large: a Class B drug offender, an aggravated burglary convict and a defaulter. Lammy pledged new monthly performance boards and a £10m AI sentencing scheme, while opposition and Number 10 cite systemic strain and tougher checks.

articles.title: NHS trust fined £565,000 after woman killed herself on ‘death trap’ ward
articles.trailText: Alice Figueiredo, 22, died in 2015 on the Hepworth ward at Goodmayes hospital after 18 similar attempts to self-harm
articles.summary: North East London NHS Foundation Trust was fined £565,000 (plus £200,000 costs) after breaching health and safety, following 22-year-old Alice Figueiredo’s suicide on 7 July 2015 in the Hepworth ward at Goodmayes Hospital. Staff failed to remove plastic items from unlocked communal toilets despite 18 self-harm attempts. Ward manager Benjamin Aninakwa received a six-month prison sentence suspended for 12 months and 300 hours’ unpaid work for neglecting her safety. Alice’s mother decried the ward as a “death trap” amid systemic risk-management failures.

articles.title: UK 18- to 24-year-olds: we would like to hear your experiences of trying to find a job
articles.trailText: Persistently high numbers of 16- to 24-year-olds are not in work or studying in the UK
articles.summary: An estimated one million 16-24-year-olds in the UK are NEET, prompting a government-launched independent inquiry into youth unemployment, labelled a “crisis of opportunity” by Work and Pensions Secretary Pat McFadden. Under current figures, nearly one in five young people face months of searching with little guidance or tailored training. The investigation seeks firsthand accounts from 18- to 24-year-olds on job-search struggles: successes, persistent barriers, and suggestions for policy or support improvements. Young adults are invited to share experiences, highlighting recruitment challenges, skills gaps, or structural obstacles, to inform reforms aimed at boosting youth employment prospects.

articles.title: Paperwork blunder by UK bookmaker reveals possible illegal offshore operation
articles.trailText: Gambling Commission may launch inquiry after finding potentially incriminating evidence hidden in documents, sources say
articles.summary: UK Gambling Commission has demanded financial records from a bookmaker after the firm inadvertently included documents—hidden in white text on a white background—revealing transactions with offshore entities. Regulators suspect the operator may be routing high-roller UK bets to unlicensed offshore partners, potentially evading gambling duties, corporation tax, anti–money laundering, and safer-gambling controls.
