Early inquiries could escalate to full investigation, with personal licences of executives at risk of revocation and possible HMRC or police involvement if tax avoidance is proven. The unnamed bookmaker, sponsor of sports events, denies illegal offshore ties and has engaged lawyers.

articles.title: Crime gangs in UK making weight-loss drugs with ‘sophisticated’ fake branding
articles.trailText: Medicines watchdog says criminals are designing packaging and branding to look like legitimate product
articles.summary: UK organised crime gangs have started producing and selling unlicensed weight-loss drugs with sophisticated counterfeit packaging to mimic branded medicines, prompting the MHRA’s largest ever seizure. In a Northampton raid officials confiscated tens of thousands of empty pens, raw ingredients and over 2,000 unlicensed retatrutide and tirzepatide pens ready for shipment. MHRA’s Andy Morling warns this third production model—following counterfeit Mounjaro/Wegovy and generic syringes—poses a significant public safety threat. Products are marketed via social media and beauty salons, with both sellers and customers unaware of legal and health risks.

articles.title: NHS staff who visit patients at home say St George’s flags can mean ‘no-go zones’
articles.trailText: Black and Asian staff left feeling ‘deliberately intimidated’, according to chief executive of one NHS trust
articles.summary: NHS home-visiting staff report St George’s flags displayed across England this summer created perceived ‘no-go zones’, deliberately intimidating Black and Asian carers, say anonymous NHS trust chiefs. Incidents include abuse of a white worker with mixed-race children after she asked flag-raisers to move. Health secretary Wes Streeting warns of a resurgence in racism. The Royal College of Nursing blames anti-migrant rhetoric for fueling threats to community nurses. The Department of Health urges reporting of aggression, while looming junior doctors’ strikes risk undermining fragile service gains.

articles.title: England’s children’s commissioner calls for closure of young offender institutions
articles.trailText: Dame Rachel de Souza says hundreds of children are being locked up unnecessarily due to failing services
articles.summary: Dame Rachel de Souza, England’s children’s commissioner, warns that young offender institutions (YOIs) have become ‘waiting rooms’ where hundreds of children are held unnecessarily on remand due to failing support services. A 2023-24 report found 62% of remanded children received no custodial sentence and 17% had cases dismissed. Average remand length rose by 89% since 2013-14 to 125 nights, with 14% held over 182 days. Inspection reports cite violence and safeguarding failures at YOIs like Feltham and Oakhill. De Souza calls for YOI closures and expanded secure homes and specialist foster care. The MoJ says custody is last resort, funding community remands and prevention schemes.

articles.title: Councillors in England face suspensions for misconduct as part of government overhaul
articles.trailText: Local authorities to be given powers to suspend rule-breaking officials and to withhold allowances
articles.summary: England’s government will give local authorities power to suspend mayors and councillors for up to six months and withhold allowances for serious misconduct—bullying, assault or repeated rule breaches. Under new legislation, a mandatory code of conduct—backed by 94% in consultation—and powers to suspend officials for serious breaches—with 86% support—will apply across all councils. Cases this year include a Devon councillor jailed for harassment and a Tewkesbury councillor convicted of child sexual assault. Ministers aim to restore public trust and deter rule-breaking, while retaining flexibility on remote meetings and opposing four-day working weeks.

articles.title: AI chatbots could help stop prisoner release errors, says justice minister
articles.trailText: HMP Wandsworth gets ‘green light’ to use AI after team sent in to find ‘quick fixes’ after spate of mistakes
articles.summary: Justice minister James Timpson told the Lords that HMP Wandsworth will pilot AI chatbots and digital cross-referencing to curb prisoner release errors after a sex offender and a fraudster were wrongly freed. The tools would process paper files, match aliases across datasets, and calculate sentences, replacing manual checks by inexperienced staff. In the year to March 2025, 262 inmates were released in error—a 128% rise—amid paper-based processes and staff shortages. The MoJ approved the AI trial as part of broader reforms, including 14,000 new prison places, to rescue a system “close to breaking point.”

articles.title: A Neet way to help youth in Dudley | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Black Country jobs crisis | DWP calculations | Renaming roads | Old letter writers
articles.summary: Four Brief Letters: Kartar Uppal notes Dudley’s record youth NEET rate stems from a curriculum neglect of technical training, urging early investment to match local working-class skills to employer demand. Godfrey Keller outlines how DWP winter fuel payments hinge on age and residence in the qualifying week, with income-based entitlement confirmed next April. John Starbuck proposes renaming problematic streets—e.g., adding “Jacob” to Epstein Road—to sidestep sensitive associations. Lynn Fotheringham observes that Guardian letter lengths have shrunk over 40 years, mirroring broader shifts in correspondence.

articles.title: Crisis charity to become a landlord in attempt to rectify ‘catastrophic’ housing in UK
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Homelessness charity planning to buy properties as it can no longer rely on access to social housing
articles.summary: Crisis, a homelessness charity, will become a landlord for the first time in its 60-year history, launching a fundraising appeal to buy and manage its own housing stock after social housing access collapsed. A Heriot-Watt University–led study found 299,100 households in England faced acute homelessness in 2024—a 21% rise since 2022 and 45% since 2012—with evictions from hospitals, prisons and asylum accommodation sharply up. Crisis plans to acquire at least 1,000 homes in London and Newcastle, deploy Housing First support, and urges government to deliver its homelessness strategy, boost housing benefits and guarantee large-scale social homebuilding.

articles.title: ‘Similar pressure to London’: the housing crisis reaches Newcastle
articles.trailText: In the north-east city, charity Crisis is having to buy its own housing stock to meet sharp rise in homelessness
articles.summary: In Newcastle the north-east city once among Britain’s cheapest, soaring private rents (£500–550 pm for a room) and three-month to two-year waits for social homes have fuelled a surge in homelessness. The charity Crisis now faces daily queues of rough sleepers, sofa-surfers, families evicted and refugees, prompting its first ever housing stock purchases in Newcastle and London. Staff, stretched by shuttered advice centres, struggle to rehouse people trapped in hostels. Newcastle council acknowledges 8,500 households on its social register and says it will restore face-to-face services.

articles.title: Gren Gaskell obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Office manager and former miner who wrote three books inspired by his experiences in the Nottinghamshire mining community
articles.summary: Gren Gaskell (1925–2025), former Bulwell miner turned Thorn EMI branch manager, whose childhood hunger after his father’s pit death fueled his advocacy for the disadvantaged. Encouraged by a school secretary to read Shakespeare, he rose from the Nottinghamshire pits to office life in the 1960s while moonlighting as pub singer Tony Firelli. A lifelong Labour member and later Quaker, he chaired Malvern Writers’ Circle and U3A, publishing three collections of mining-inspired poetry and stories including Tales from the Golden Bull (2017). Retiring to Malvern with second wife Arline, he traveled across Europe and Kazakhstan. He endured Lewy body dementia with fortitude. Survived by Arline.

articles.title: It pays to support women’s health in the workplace | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Prof Geeta Nargund says employers need to take action on health inequality as research shows more than 32% of women aren’t receiving enough help to stay in work
articles.summary: Prof Geeta Nargund warns UK employers incur an £11bn annual cost from absenteeism tied to gynaecological conditions. Her research shows 15% of women shift to part-time roles and 14% quit due to women’s health issues, while 32% lack adequate employer support. Citing the Keep Britain Working review and an NHS Confederation partnership, she frames health inequality as a barrier to career aspirations and welcomes new government policy to guide workplace support.

articles.title: Review to look at role of mental health issues in UK youth unemployment
articles.trailText: Former health secretary Alan Milburn’s review is exploring reasons for rising inactivity among young people
articles.summary: Alan Milburn, former Labour health secretary, will lead a review into the impact of mental health issues and disability on UK youth unemployment, focusing on nearly one million 16–24-year-olds classified as NEET. Due summer, it aims to identify barriers and propose practical measures to prevent long-term detachment from work, training or education. It follows Charlie Mayfield’s findings of a 75% rise (190,000) in economically inactive 16–34-year-olds with mental health conditions since 2019. The government plans a ‘youth guarantee’ for paid work under universal credit, complementing the Timms review of personal independence payments.

articles.title: Home Office data in HMRC benefit fraud trial wrong in 46% of cases
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Almost half of families flagged as emigrants based on Home Office travel data were still living in UK
articles.summary: An HMRC pilot using flawed Home Office travel data to suspend child benefit wrongly flagged 46% of families still in the UK, far above acceptable limits. The scheme saved £17m but in Northern Ireland misidentified 78% of emigrants (129 flagged vs 28 actual). Labour MP Kim Johnson called for an investigation; experts warn the data is unreliable. After parents lost payments, HMRC dropped Dublin data, updated procedures, apologised and added a one-month response window.

articles.title: Royal College of Psychiatrists faces member backlash over Qatar partnership
articles.trailText: More than 150 psychiatrists sign letter condemning contract to host exams in country with well-documented human rights abuses
articles.summary: The Royal College of Psychiatrists signed a contract with Qatar’s state‐run Hamad Medical Corporation to host membership exams in Doha, prompting over 150 UK members to protest human rights concerns—from criminalisation of same‐sex relations and migrant worker abuses to gender inequality. Critics warn of reputational damage and moral conflict, while the college argues the move expands global south access, upholds UK‐standard exam integrity and includes LGBTQ+ mental health competencies.

articles.title: Having open conversations with boys is key to fending off the manosphere threat | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Siobhan Lyons says ignore the static that is social media and turn disillusionment into art, Dr Michael J Richardson thinks money, meaning and manhood should be topics of public conversation, not private ones. Plus a letter from Vicky Dunn
articles.summary: Three letters responding to Josh Sargent’s article warn that social media’s short-form content fuels the manosphere and distracts young men from reading, reflection and deeper connection. Siobhan Lyons urges replacing TikTok with classic literature and art, Dr Michael Richardson calls for normalizing public dialogue about money, meaning and manhood, and Vicky Dunn highlights local youth activities as vital for open, honest conversations that respect adolescent voices. They emphasize that boys aren’t ‘lost’ but await attentive listening, and that schools and communities must evolve to support nuanced masculine identities rather than shaming them.

articles.title: Social media misinformation driving men to seek unneeded NHS testosterone therapy, doctors say
articles.trailText: Endocrinologists warn taking testosterone unnecessarily can suppress natural hormone production
articles.summary: Social media influencers on TikTok/Instagram are promoting blood tests as a shortcut to testosterone therapy for men with normal levels, partnering with private clinics that charge £1,800–2,200/year. Endocrinologists report healthy men filling NHS waiting lists seeking unneeded TRT, which violates UK guidelines restricting treatment to confirmed deficiency (<12 nmol/L). Unwarranted TRT suppresses natural hormone production, risks infertility, blood clots, heart issues and mood disorders. Ads flagged to the ASA for regulatory breaches.

articles.title: ‘Heroic actions are a natural tendency’: why bystander apathy is a myth
articles.trailText: Modern research shows the public work together selflessly in an emergency, motivated by a strong impulse to help
articles.summary: New research by social psychologists including Reicher, Stott, Drury and Harrop shows bystander apathy is a myth. Case studies from a Worcester river rescue, the Doncaster-London train stabbing, 7/7, the Admiral Duncan pub and the Leytonstone tube attack illustrate spontaneous, coordinated, selfless group heroism. Experts urge authorities to empower communities, foster local resilience, use unifying language and expand bystander training in schools, policing and the NHS to harness our natural collective impulse to help in emergencies, especially as climate crises loom.

articles.title: Sex offender freed from Wandsworth prison by mistake is back in custody
articles.trailText: Brahim Kaddour-Cherif, who was accidentally released on 29 October, arrested in north London on Friday
articles.summary: Brahim Kaddour-Cherif, 24, an Algerian national and convicted sex offender, was accidentally released from Wandsworth prison on 29 October while serving a trespass sentence. After a public tip, police arrested him in Finsbury Park on 7 November, six days after the error was reported. His release and that of another inmate have intensified criticism of Justice Secretary David Lammy over prison clerical failures. Kaddour-Cherif, an overstayer since 2020, faces renewed custody and calls for deportation once his sentence ends.

articles.title: Tom Butler obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Social worker who became head of NHS mental health services in Manchester
articles.summary: Tom Butler, 73, former head of NHS mental health services in inner-city Manchester and social work pioneer, died of lymphoma. Born in Gloucester to Irish parents, he revolutionized child protection with early computer databases and authored key social policy texts including 1985’s Mental Health, Social Policy and the Law. After earning degrees at Middlesex Polytechnic, Durham and Manchester, he managed mental health provision in Manchester and Northumberland Trust. Predeceased by wives Marion and Sue, he retired to Suffolk, pursued music, cooking and sailing—completing a transatlantic crossing and St Kilda circuit. Survived by sister Betty.

articles.title: ‘A job is like finding a needle in a haystack’: how Dudley became centre of UK’s youth jobs crisis
articles.trailText: Almost one in five school-leavers in West Midlands town are not in education, employment or training and chancellor is under pressure to deliver promised ‘youth guarantee’
articles.summary: Dudley, West Midlands, has England’s highest youth NEET rate—20% of 16–17-year-olds—amid a national total of nearly 1 m 16–24s out of work or training. Chancellor Rachel Reeves, grappling with fallen payrolls and rising 4.8% unemployment, must fund her promised “youth guarantee” at the autumn budget and boost apprenticeships and skills investment. Critics say her employer NIC rises and minimum wage hikes have dampened hiring, notably in SMEs, hospitality and retail. Local “I Can” and “Step Up Dudley” schemes, backed by £45 m, target structural post-Thatcher deindustrialisation barriers. Experts warn prolonged youth inactivity risks over £1 m lost per person in lifetime earnings and could shave up to £86 bn off long-term GDP.

articles.title: Emma Barnett says she felt ‘mugged, robbed’ after perimenopause at 38
articles.trailText: Broadcaster says on new BBC podcast that perimenopause made her feel like she had lost her identity
articles.summary: Broadcaster Emma Barnett, now 40, described experiencing perimenopause at 38 on her BBC podcast as feeling "mugged, robbed" of her identity, marking the first time she "hasn't really wanted to be a woman" and even wishing to be male. She likened her struggle to a crime without an emergency number to call, still waiting to "come back" to her pre-perimenopause self. Barnett and guest Kate Thornton called for perimenopause normalisation in everyday discourse. Experts warn of a "menopause gold rush" as private firms profit from gaps in public knowledge, prompting calls for a national education programme on menopause.

articles.title: NHS to take over state-of-the-art hospital from private health group in ‘windfall’
articles.trailText: Nuffield Health to close London hospital after anticipated demand for private care fails to materialise
articles.summary: Barts Health NHS trust will take control of Nuffield Health’s underused state-of-the-art London hospital in December after the private group failed to attract enough fee-paying patients. Nuffield had leased and spent £65m refurbishing two dilapidated buildings in 2022—fitting 55 beds, three operating theatres and CT/MRI scanners—but decided to sell back the lease less than four years into the deal. Barts deems this “a windfall” and, backed by a £16.6m donation from Barts Charity, will open a dedicated breast cancer diagnosis and treatment centre in January. Around 180 Nuffield staff face redundancy, with some set to transfer to the new centre or other private sites.

articles.title: Call to give UK cancer patients legal right to be treated within two months
articles.trailText: Experts point to example of Denmark, where survival rates for some cancers are among the best in Europe
articles.summary: International experts urge a statutory right for UK cancer patients to begin treatment within 62 days of GP referral, mirroring Denmark’s 28-day rule, with the NHS obliged to fund private or overseas care to avoid deadly delays that raise mortality by 10% per four-week wait. Since 2015 the NHS missed its 85% target for timely starts. Researchers warn Britain’s upcoming cancer plan lacks enforceability without legal backing, also proposing named cancer coordinators and a five-year post-treatment “right to be forgotten” to combat insurer discrimination. The Health Department cites new measures—Jess’s rule, expanded diagnostics, weekend clinics and £70m radiotherapy investment to reduce waits.

articles.title: Lammy says he was right not to discuss mistakenly freed prisoner at PMQs
articles.trailText: Justice secretary says he did not have ‘all the detail’ at the time and there is ‘mountain to climb’ on prisons crisis
articles.summary: Justice Secretary David Lammy defended his decision not to detail a mistaken release of sex offender Brahim Kaddour-Cherif at PMQs, saying he lacked full information at the time. After a fraudster released in error from HMP Wandsworth voluntarily returned, Kaddour-Cherif remains at large in London. Lammy acknowledged a 'mountain to climb' over paper-based release processes, announced an overhaul and stronger checks after release errors. Labour leader Keir Starmer backed him; PM Sunak blamed past government failures for system strain and pledged reforms. Official data shows prison release errors more than doubled to 262 in the latest year.

articles.title: Loss of shops is threatening rural communities | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: If services like fuel, banking and groceries are cut off, the economic base of an area inevitably declines, says Chas Ball
articles.summary: Chas Ball warns that shop, fuel and banking closures in remote villages such as Kilchoan and others in Lochaber and Argyll undermine rural economies and accelerate depopulation. He recalls a 1977 Highlands and Islands Development Board scheme that matched local funding with outreach support to sustain community-run shops, post offices and co-operatives, fostering local wealth. Despite existing co-operatives and retailer home deliveries, he argues that without public backing for essential services, rural regions face economic decline and forced urban migration.

articles.title: Why Labour lacks credibility when it comes to housing | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: Kate Macintosh calls for a cessation of right to buy and highlights hypocrisy within the government
articles.summary: The letter by Kate Macintosh argues that Labour’s failure to end the right-to-buy policy undermines its credibility on housing. Housing benefit costs leak public funds to private landlords, doubled versus the EU average. Despite award-winning council-built Passivhaus homes at Norwich’s Goldsmith Street, residents can still buy under right-to-buy, reducing social stock. England lost a net 12,000 social homes in 2023, with over 22,000 sold or demolished. Unlike Scotland and Wales, England remains an outlier. With 44 Labour landlord MPs, meaningful reform is unlikely.

articles.title: Young people in the UK: share your experiences of living in a coastal town
articles.trailText: We would like to hear from young people aged 18 to 25 about their experiences of living in the UK’s coastal towns
articles.summary: The Guardian is launching ‘Against The Tide’, a year-long series spotlighting 18-25-year-olds in UK coastal towns. Over six months, journalist teams and photographer Polly Braden have visited ports and seaside resorts to explore young residents’ perceptions, aspirations and seasonal challenges. For the next 12 months they want first-hand accounts of daily life, opportunities and obstacles. If you’re 18-25 or work with young people in any UK coastal area, share your insights via the online form. Terms and privacy policies apply.

articles.title: Mistakenly released prisoner Billy Smith turns himself in
articles.trailText: Police continue hunt for Algerian sex offender Brahim Kaddour-Cherif as fraudster returns to Wandsworth jail
articles.summary: Billy Smith, a 35-year-old fraudster, was mistakenly released from HMP Wandsworth this week due to a court clerical error and voluntarily returned to custody after 24 hours. His release comes amid an ongoing Metropolitan Police hunt for Brahim Kaddour-Cherif, a convicted Algerian sex offender also accidentally freed last week and now at large in London. Justice Secretary David Lammy, under mounting pressure, announced plans to overhaul the paper-based prison and court systems and implement a new release-check checklist introduced weeks ago after similar errors. Ministers face scrutiny over rising error rates, with MoJ data showing 262 unintended releases in the year to March.

articles.title: Overcrowding, understaffing and old IT: chaotic context to prison release errors
articles.trailText: Mistaken releases from HMP Wandsworth should come as little surprise given near-impossible circumstances
articles.summary: HMP Wandsworth, built for 963 men but housing around 1,500, suffers chronic overcrowding, understaffing and outdated IT. An inspection found unreliable prisoner rolls amid high staff absence, leading to mistaken releases of two inmates. Around two-thirds of its 85 officers are inexperienced, with annual turnover of 1 in 7 juniors. Recent new leadership cut security failings from 81 to 4, yet grim conditions persist—700 self-harm incidents, assaults and deaths—aggravated by manual release procedures and systemic underfunding.

articles.title: Woman with stage 4 cancer has welfare benefit stopped after falling ill abroad
articles.trailText: Ana Paula Cabral’s universal credit payments were abruptly ended by DWP when she failed to return from Portugal trip
articles.summary: Ana Paula Cabral, 65, a UK resident from Portugal, began universal credit after her stage-4 colon cancer diagnosis. The DWP stopped her payments in September when she fell ill during a family trip to Portugal and exceeded the one-month overseas limit, ruling her absence wasn’t solely for treatment. Despite approval from UK and Portuguese doctors to continue chemo abroad, her appeal was denied under rules allowing up to six months only if travel is primarily for medical care. Facing rent arrears and possible eviction, Cabral fears losing her home.

articles.title: England prison chiefs summoned to urgent meeting with ministers over wrongful releases
articles.trailText: Justice minister promises digital overhaul of ‘archaic’ paper system partly blamed for average of 22 people being wrongly freed each month
articles.summary: Facing pressure after two more inmates – including Algerian sex offender Brahim Kaddour-Cherif – were wrongly freed, prison governors in England are meeting ministers to address an average of 22 monthly wrongful releases blamed on an ‘archaic’ paper-based system. Justice minister Alex Davies-Jones announced a digital overhaul with a specialist team alongside Lynne Owens’s rapid review. Opponents criticized justice secretary David Lammy’s handling and delay in reporting incidents. Recent cases include Kaddour-Cherif, fraud convict William Smith and Ethiopian offender Hadush Kebatu. The Prison Officers’ Association called for a royal commission.

articles.title: Latest mistaken releases expose deep cracks in England’s prison system
articles.trailText: Breakdowns in communications and staffing and security issues show how years of neglect have pushed jails to breaking point
articles.summary: A second mistaken release of a foreign prisoner has exposed deep faults in England’s jail system: outdated tech, breakdowns in communication among prisons, the Ministry of Justice and courts, and a malfunctioning automated release-date calculator that forced manual errors. During the September 2024 emergency scheme 37 inmates were freed under repealed laws. High remand rates, lost warrants, inexperienced staff and high turnover have led to 262 erroneous releases in a year (up 128%). Notable cases include Hadush Kebatu’s confused re-release and HMP Wandsworth’s lingering security failings post-Daniel Khalife escape, despite David Lammy’s new sign-off checks.

articles.title: Resident doctors’ strike to go ahead after Wes Streeting’s last-ditch offer is rejected
articles.trailText: Resident doctors in England to strike for five days next week, saying health secretary’s latest offer is too limited
articles.summary: Resident doctors in England will proceed with a five-day strike next week after Health Secretary Wes Streeting’s latest proposal—doubling to 2,000 the number of specialist training places and covering exam and professional fees—was rejected by the BMA’s resident doctors committee as inadequate. The offer rules out further pay increases in 2025-26 and caps 2026-27 at 2.5%, which doctors say would be a real-terms pay cut. With 30,000 applicants for 10,000 training posts, campaigners insist only a multi-year pay deal and genuine job guarantees can avert industrial action.

articles.title: Anti-trafficking campaigner welcomes UK ban on strangulation in pornography
articles.trailText: Samantha Browne says ban will help stop young people thinking violent practice is normal or safe
articles.summary: The UK’s crime and policing bill amendment will make it a criminal offence to possess or publish porn featuring strangulation or suffocation in the UK. Anti-trafficking campaigner Samantha Browne, who was exploited from age 16 in the adult industry and now leads consent workshops, says the ban will stop young people normalising violent sex and pave the way to outlaw other abusive content. Research links sexual choking to brain injury even without loss of consciousness. Browne warns that ever-more extreme porn fuels desensitisation, erectile dysfunction and demand for hardcore acts, though critics question policing overseas material.

articles.title: David Lammy under pressure as two more prisoners mistakenly freed
articles.trailText: Algerian sex offender and a fraudster released by Wandsworth jail, days after new checks brought in
articles.summary: Justice secretary David Lammy is under fire after two more inmates—24-year-old Algerian visa overstayer Brahim Kaddour-Cherif, convicted of indecent exposure, and 35-year-old fraudster William Smith—were wrongly released from HMP Wandsworth days after stricter checks were ordered following the Kebatu blunder. Lammy denied further errors at PMQs but was later corrected by the Ministry of Justice. The Metropolitan police have launched a manhunt for Kaddour-Cherif. With accidental releases rising to 262 in the year to March 2025, Lammy has commissioned an independent review by Dame Lynne Owens, while the POA demands a full system overhaul.

articles.title: Tackling the democracy deficit in schools | Letter
articles.trailText: Letters: Students, parents and staff should be given a voice in important educational issues so that young people can understand why democracy matters, says Fiona Carnie
articles.summary: Fiona Carnie, an educationist, argues that despite student, parent and staff councils, English schools remain deeply undemocratic: student councils rarely influence policies; parent councils struggle with engagement beyond individual child concerns; staff councils are discouraged to avoid teacher dissent over workload and curriculum. Governing bodies seldom genuinely consult these constituencies, leading to decisions made “to” rather than “with” stakeholders. This systemic exclusion undermines young people’s practical understanding of democracy, leaving them ill-prepared to appreciate its value if they never experience meaningful participation in school governance.

articles.title: End-of-life care needs a fundamental review, not just more funding | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Prof Sam H Ahmedzai and Dr Greg Mewett respond to an editorial about the crisis in funding in England’s adult hospice sector
articles.summary: Prof Sam H Ahmedzai and Dr Greg Mewett argue that England’s end-of-life care crisis requires more than cash. Ahmedzai warns that hospice overreliance and late referrals—mostly of cancer patients in their final weeks—leave those with other terminal illnesses underserved and perpetuate geographical and socioeconomic disparities. He urges a fundamental service-model overhaul. Mewett adds that legalised assisted dying complements, not competes with, palliative care: jurisdictions like Victoria have seen palliative referrals and funding rise alongside voluntary assisted dying.

articles.title: Almost 30% of people abused as children, England and Wales data shows
articles.trailText: ONS data, which includes emotional, physical and sexual abuse as well as neglect, suggests 13.6 million people affected
articles.summary: ONS data for year to March 2024 shows 29.1% of adults in England and Wales—31.5% of women and 26.4% of men—suffered abuse as children (emotional 22.7%, physical 16.5%, sexual 9.1%, neglect 7.6%), totalling 13.6 million. Over 91% of sexual abuse perpetrators were male. LGBTQ+ (48.1% gay/lesbian, 62.5% bisexual, 53.4% trans) and disabled (42%) people report higher rates; mixed-ethnicity (40.2%) exceed white (31%), Black (18.2%) and Asian (14.7%). Charities urge urgent policy action.

articles.title: UK to launch pilot scheme that helps homeless people access banking
articles.trailText: Five biggest banks take part in programme that will also help domestic abuse victims recover their credit score
articles.summary: The UK Treasury’s new financial inclusion strategy will fund a pilot enabling homeless people to open accounts with Lloyds, NatWest, Barclays, Nationwide and Santander without a fixed address, using Shelter to vouch for applicants. It also proposes credit-score reviews for domestic abuse survivors, support for families with minimal savings and expansion of payroll savings schemes. Further measures include mandatory financial education—from interest calculations in primary maths to a compulsory citizenship course—to boost long-term resilience.

articles.title: MPs ask HMRC to explain child benefit error that froze payments to parents
articles.trailText: Answers demanded after 23,500 families wrongly suspected of fraud when incorrect data showed they had left UK
articles.summary: MPs have written to the HMRC permanent secretary demanding answers after an anti-fraud drive wrongly halted child benefit for 23,500 families flagged as emigrants by incomplete Home Office travel booking data. The Treasury select committee, led by Labour MP Meg Hillier, wants to know who signed off the initiative, why booking rather than boarding records were used, how recipients were verified, what safeguards existed and whether compensation will be offered. HMRC has apologised, reinstated benefits for around 2,000 parents, promised a dedicated support team and revised procedures to check claims before suspension, while MPs seek assurances no innocent families will suffer again.

articles.title: NHS staff bearing brunt as ‘ugly’ racism of 70s and 80s returns, says Streeting
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Health secretary and NHS England chief warn of winter pressures and rising levels of abuse
articles.summary: NHS staff are experiencing a resurgence of “ugly” 1970s-style racism, with verbal and physical abuse becoming “socially acceptable,” Health Secretary Wes Streeting and NHS England chief Jim Mackey warned. With winter looming – the “triple whammy” of flu, Covid and a five-day junior doctors’ strike over a 29% pay claim – trusts face record A&E demand, corridor care and trolley or ambulance delays. Streeting and NHS bodies call for zero tolerance of racism amid rising anti-migrant rhetoric among politicians and urge doctors to call off planned industrial action to avert further harm.

articles.title: A precious web of care still exists | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: Keith Flett on the support his partner, Megan, received towards the end of her life
articles.summary: In a letter, Keith Flett recalls the end-of-life care his partner Megan Davies received during her terminal lung cancer battle. Despite acknowledging systemic shortcomings, he highlights how a collaborative network—family, friends, her GP, and hospice palliative nurses—enabled Megan to stay at home enjoying familiar comforts until a final two-day hospital stay where care remained compassionate. Flett notes occasional delays in medications and treatments, yet considers this “precious web of care” vital and questions how it can be sustained amid NHS strain and austerity in Britain.

articles.title: Firms not supporting staff through IVF could lose £217m in hidden costs, study shows
articles.trailText: Cost of sick leave for appointments, productivity loss and resignations is more than of paid leave, research estimates
articles.summary: Research by Fertility Matters at Work finds UK firms without formal fertility policies lose £217.3m annually via sick leave, productivity drops and resignations—£35,317 per affected employee versus £388 for ten days’ paid IVF leave. Sick absences (63% of patients) cost £53.8m, productivity £27.8m, turnover (6%) £30,614 per hire, and the Treasury £47.9m. MP Alice Macdonald’s 10-minute rule bill seeks a statutory right to paid fertility leave. Case studies detail disciplinary threats and mental-health impacts, while experts urge supportive cultures and the government outlines flexible working reforms.

articles.title: Tell us: are you a UK centenarian or do you know one?
articles.trailText: We would like to hear from centenarians, their family and friends
articles.summary: In the UK the centenarian population doubled from 8,300 in 2004 to 16,600 in 2024, with male centenarians rising from 910 to 3,100 and females from 7,400 to 13,600. The Office for National Statistics data highlights this demographic shift and we’re seeking centenarians or their relatives to share first-hand accounts of life across a century’s events, reflections on historical changes, advice for their younger selves and their secrets to longevity.

articles.title: Women must be warned of home birth risks and have access to skilled midwives, experts say
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Pregnancy experts warn of inadequate medical advice and lack of safe and reliable care
articles.summary: After a coroner’s ruling in Rochdale that a mother and newborn died from a postpartum hemorrhage and cord complication during a poorly supported home birth, UK experts warn women must receive clear, explicit risk information and access only to highly experienced, well-rested midwives. They highlight patchy home-birth services, staffing shortages, inconsistent training and communication failures—in Cahill’s case midwives had worked 12-hour shifts and lacked confidence. Specialists call for transparent discussions on emergency transfer delays, strict competency assessments, adequate staffing and investment to ensure informed choice and safe, personalised care regardless of postcode.

articles.title: Phillipson calls for ‘less public debate’ from EHRC on gender recognition rules
articles.trailText: Minister responds to calls from watchdog’s chair to approve new guidance on transgender rights ‘as soon as possible’
articles.summary: Equalities minister Bridget Phillipson has urged the EHRC to shift from public debate toward supplying ministers with necessary materials—such as an equalities impact assessment—and consulting devolved governments, as it presses for rapid approval of its 300-page statutory guidance on gender recognition. This follows the April Supreme Court ruling defining “woman” and “sex” as biological terms. Ministers insist on a line-by-line review and cross-UK consultation to avoid legal jeopardy for single-sex services, amid businesses’ and Labour MPs’ cost and legal concerns and transgender advocates’ alarm at interim advice that would bar trans people from sex-segregated spaces. The EHRC warns speed is needed; critics accuse Phillipson of deliberate delay, which she rejects as due diligence.

articles.title: Pornography depicting strangulation to become criminal offence in the UK
articles.trailText: Legal requirement to be placed on tech platforms to prevent users from seeing such ‘choking’ material
articles.summary: Parliament’s Crime and Policing Bill will criminalize possession or publishing of porn depicting strangulation or suffocation, making it a priority offence that forces platforms to block such content or face fines up to £18m. A separate amendment extends the prosecution window for intimate image abuse from six months to three years. Based on a government-commissioned review highlighting risks of normalizing sexual violence and causing brain injury, Ofcom will enforce automated detection and stricter moderation to protect women, girls and children from harmful online sexual material.

articles.title: Equality commission’s guidance after sex ruling is fundamentally unworkable | Letter
articles.trailText: Letters: The EHRC has ignored warnings about the contradiction between possibly being sued for challenging someone’s gender versus being sued for failing to, says Rachel Taylor MP
articles.summary: Rachel Taylor MP criticizes the EHRC’s post-Supreme Court guidance on sex-based spaces as fundamentally unworkable, saying it forces businesses to police bathroom use by birth sex—an impossible task that risks humiliating trans people and exposes firms to costly litigation. She argues the guidance exceeds the court’s allowance for proportionate exclusion, marginalizes transgender individuals and fails to advance women’s rights. Taylor urges the incoming EHRC chair to adopt a balanced, legally grounded approach.

articles.title: Walking 3,000 or more steps a day may slow progression of Alzheimer’s, study says
articles.trailText: Scientists find even modest amounts of exercise appear to delay brain changes and cognitive decline in patients
articles.summary: A 14-year study of 296 cognitively unimpaired adults (50–90) found walking ≥3,000 steps/day delays Alzheimer’s progression. Participants wore pedometers, took annual cognitive tests and PET scans for amyloid-β and tau. Those averaging 3,000–5,000 steps saw a 3-year delay in decline; 5,000–7,000 steps yielded a 7-year delay. Among those with high baseline amyloid, higher step counts correlated with slower tau buildup and cognitive loss. Researchers urge randomized trials to confirm causality and explore mechanisms such as improved blood flow, reduced inflammation and neurotrophic factors.

articles.title: UK’s unregulated pregnancy scan clinics putting lives in danger, say experts
articles.trailText: Hospital specialists report cases of missed health problems, misdiagnosed conditions, and women erroneously told their babies had died
articles.summary: High street pregnancy scan clinics with untrained staff have led to missed health problems, misdiagnoses and false alerts such as non-existent miscarriages or ectopic pregnancies. Hospital sonographers documented missed early pregnancy sacs, unrecognized fetal abnormalities—including spina bifida, polycystic kidneys and fluid-filled ventricles—and misdiagnosed cervical issues. The Society for Radiographers urges protected titles for qualified sonographers and strict regulation. Patients are advised to verify Care Quality Commission inspections, staff credentials, clinic longevity and independent reviews. The Department of Health highlights a voluntary Register of Clinical Technologists and is reviewing proposals for statutory oversight.

articles.title: NHS hospitals to test AI tool that helps diagnose and treat prostate cancer
articles.trailText: Three-year study will test biopsy analysis tool shown in trials to identify men likely to benefit from certain drugs
articles.summary: The Vanguard Path study (£1.9m, University of Oxford, Prostate Cancer UK) will run three years in NHS hospitals, testing the ArteraAI Prostate Biopsy Assay on more than 4,000 biopsy images. The AI tool produces personalized risk scores to guide treatment decisions: identifying men likely to benefit from abiraterone, selecting candidates for hormone therapy plus radiotherapy, and supporting active surveillance. The trial includes retrospective analysis of treated UK patients and prospective testing at three NHS trusts to evaluate predictive accuracy, impact on clinician decisions and time to treatment. If validated, it could streamline diagnosis and reduce over or under treatment.

articles.title: Why we must tackle the crisis in end-of-life care | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Dr Sam Royston calls for a national delivery plan and sustainable funding, while James Sanderson says it’s time for the hospice sector to wake up. Plus letters from Kate Kirk and Ian Spero
articles.summary: In letters responding to the Guardian's 29 October hospice editorial, Dr Sam Royston warns that over 5.75 million UK deaths over the next decade will overwhelm palliative services without a new national delivery plan and sustainable funding. James Sanderson urges the hospice sector to address funding inequities and expand access for deprived areas and diverse ethnic groups to reduce 999 and A&E reliance. Kate Kirk emphasizes that 'good deaths' supported by hospice care shape bereavement outcomes and recalls Cicely Saunders' pioneering pain research. Ian Spero advocates integrating palliative care into community design via the upcoming ISO 25553 standard, promoting continuity, dignity and closer-to-home support.

articles.title: Why Reeves should gamble on tax hikes | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Betting shops | Prunella Scales | Obama again | Sofa dogs | Sofa cats | Riot Women
articles.summary: Six readers respond: John Saxbee urges Rachel Reeves to press ahead with a gambling tax rise after Betfred warns it would shutter all 1,287 shops; Pete Hendy praises Prunella Scales’s Anti-Nazi League activism despite his ambivalence about Fawlty Towers; Hilary Bird asks if a constitutional tweak permitting Trump a third term would similarly readmit Obama; Michael Dixon and Robert Moore debate sofa etiquette for dogs versus cats; and Trevor McCarthy suggests Sally Wainwright’s Riot Women cast release a charity single aimed at Christmas No 1.

articles.title: A fatal drop: what do we know about the drugs, 500 times stronger than heroin, taking Australian lives?
articles.trailText: Only a few years after first being detected in Australia, nitazenes have been found in everything from vapes to fake heroin – and the death toll is rising
articles.summary: Fatal overdoses of nitazenes, synthetic opioids up to 500x stronger than heroin, have surged in Australia since 2021. In June 2024, four men in Melbourne died after snorting what they thought was cocaine but was protonitazene. At least 30 nitazene-linked overdoses have occurred; UNODC tracks 26 variants, including isotocyanozene first detected in Canberra in 2023. Border Force seized 60+ shipments, yet speck-dose toxicity evades detection, spurring coroner calls for drug-checking, naloxone and wastewater monitoring amid political push-back.

articles.title: Tired all the time? There may be a simple reason for that
articles.trailText: Levels of fatigue among women in Britain are soaring, and this isn’t the kind that can be cured by a nap. What lies behind the exhaustion epidemic?
articles.summary: UK women of reproductive age increasingly suffer severe fatigue often misattributed to overwork or mental health, yet almost one in three are iron deficient. Heavy periods, dietary factors and lack of routine ferritin testing mean diagnosis averages eight years. Common signs—brain fog, hair loss, anxiety, breathlessness—are dismissed, and oral iron pills frequently cause gut issues. Intravenous iron infusions offer rapid relief but face NHS access and cost barriers. Experts urge regular ferritin screening, tailored treatment pathways and greater medical awareness to address this gender health gap.

articles.title: How scientists are shining light on the biology behind seasonal affective disorder
articles.trailText: Researchers tracking large cohorts are discovering the effects of sleep, light and therapy on people impacted by winter’s arrival
articles.summary: Researchers using large cohorts such as UK Biobank reveal that seasonal affective disorder, a subtype of depression with onset in autumn and remission in spring, stems from endogenous circadian and physiological shifts triggered by reduced daylight. Symptoms include extended sleep, lethargy and carb cravings. Studies show seasonal fluctuations in gene expression and sleep quality across half a million people. Bright light therapy or morning sunlight resets circadian rhythms, while cognitive behavioural therapy tailored to winter can reframe negative perceptions. Embracing outdoor activity, consistent sleep schedules and winter rituals can mitigate mood dips; persistent cases warrant professional help.

articles.title: Everyone says they are worried about hate crimes. But Australia’s laws to combat them are all over the place
articles.trailText: Some state police forces have specific laws and units relating to hate crime, others have neither. Experts say a national definition is needed
articles.summary: Debates over antisemitism and Islamophobia amid the Gaza war have exposed patchy hate-crime laws in Australia. Only NSW and WA have dedicated police units; NT, SA and Tasmania use prejudice as sentencing aggravators. Since 2020, available records show over 435 charges nationally—125 in Queensland, 14 in Victoria, two in the ACT—far less than complaints logged by NSW Police or community registers. Operation Avalite handled 1,367 AFP reports with seven charges. Experts and a Senate inquiry urge a consistent national definition and database to boost tracking and convictions.

articles.title: Ministers were warned of errors at jail that released sex offender by mistake
articles.trailText: Chaotic release procedures at HMP Chelmsford were flagged to the prisons minister last year
articles.summary: An independent monitoring board reported chaotic release procedures at HMP Chelmsford, including date mix-ups and canceled briefings, after a complaint that a vulnerable inmate had no resettlement support. The Essex prison mistakenly freed convicted child sex offender Hadush Kebatu, who had sexually assaulted a 14-year-old and a woman days after crossing the Channel. The IMB warned of prisoners “falling through the cracks.” Prisons minister James Timpson acknowledged local issues; justice secretary David Lammy cited “human error” and launched the strongest release checks ever, with Lynne Owens leading an inquiry.

articles.title: ‘Out of reach’: stalled newbuilds leave Labour’s social housing targets in tatters
articles.trailText: As some families face a 200-year wait for an affordable home, what exactly has gone wrong?
articles.summary: England builds just over 10,000 social homes a year—far below the 90,000 needed and Labour’s pledge of 1.5 million new homes in five years—leaving some families facing 200-year waits. London developments have stalled, prompting a cut in affordable quotas from 35% to 20% for fast-track sites. High interest rates, surging material costs, Brexit-linked labour shortages and retrofit bills squeeze housing associations. Planning delays and missing landlord contracts stall 10,000 homes, while community resistance to densification further impedes progress. Despite a £39 billion investment and planning reforms, delivery remains painfully slow and targets out of reach.

articles.title: Woman turned away from UK-Italy flight due to ill child has benefit stopped
articles.trailText: Family denied entry at gate after one of their children had epileptic seizure – but HMRC said she took a one-way trip
articles.summary: Sally and her family were denied boarding on a July holiday flight to Italy after her child suffered an epileptic seizure. Sixteen months later HMRC halted her child benefit for three children, misinterpreting a one-way flight booking as emigration. She submitted airline letters and insurance claims to prove they never left the UK. This error is one of 23,500 similar cases triggered by a government crackdown using border and booking data. HMRC has apologised, pledging not to suspend payments before contacting recipients. Critics warn data inaccuracies and process flaws risk penalising law-abiding families and question Home Office data sources.

articles.title: Charities and stars call on UK government to set child poverty reduction targets
articles.trailText: Signatories of open letter include National Children’s Bureau, Barnardo’s and celebrities such as Emilia Clarke
articles.summary: An open letter coordinated by Big Issue founder Lord John Bird and signed by Emilia Clarke, Chris Packham, George Clarke, over 20 MPs and peers (Labour, Greens, SNP) and leading charities (National Children’s Bureau, Child Poverty Action Group, Barnardo’s, Amnesty UK, Trussell) urges the UK government to set binding child poverty reduction targets. Critics warn warm words won’t deliver change amid delays to Labour’s child poverty strategy and growing hardship—100,000 more children fall into poverty annually, nearly 5 million projected by 2029. Bird’s amendment to legally mandate targets was rejected in June but will be reintroduced in the Lords. The strategy, now slated for the November budget alongside a two-child benefit overhaul, risks half-measures, charity and think-tank analysis warns. The government pledges a £500 m investment in Best Start hubs, extended free meals and a £1 bn holiday crisis fund but has yet to set quantifiable benchmarks.

articles.title: Drone-blocking technology ‘urgently’ required at jails in England and Wales
articles.trailText: Ability to maintain control in prisons ‘critically undermined’ by scale of illicit drug trade, MPs say
articles.summary: The Commons justice select committee warns organised gangs exploit sophisticated drones—sightings up 770% since 2019—to smuggle drugs into prisons, with 39% of inmates reporting easy access and 11–19% developing new addictions. It demands urgent rollout of SkyFence or equivalent drone-jamming systems in all category A facilities within two years and estate-wide within 24 months, deeming current police and NCA measures inadequate. Government figures show 38,042 inmates freed early under an overcrowding scheme since September 2024.

articles.title: Nearly 150,000 aged 90 and above wait 12 hours in England’s A&Es each year
articles.trailText: Older people left in their own excrement and wet beds for hours and forced to watch others die, Age UK report finds
articles.summary: An Age UK report reveals that 149,293 people aged 90+ in England waited over 12 hours in A&E departments in 2024-25—one-third of attendances—amid more than one million 60+ patients facing similar delays. Many spent days in corridors, left in soiled beds, denied pain relief and forced to witness deaths. Caroline Abrahams called it “a crisis hiding in plain sight,” urging a government plan with clear targets and funding to end corridor care. MPs, nursing bodies and NHS leaders demand urgent action; ministers pledge £450 m for new urgent care centres.

articles.title: Jaywick’s continued decline and intensifying London poverty tell same story of ‘broken’ Britain
articles.trailText: Latest deprivation index shows how geography and housing costs shape inequality more than policy ever has
articles.summary: Jaywick Sands has topped England’s deprivation index since 2010, becoming a symbol of economic neglect, austerity and geographic isolation, scoring in the worst 10% for employment, income, health, crime, housing access and environment. While local MP Nigel Farage offered vague condolences, council leader Mark Stephenson cited recent progress and strong community spirit. Other post-industrial hubs like Blackpool and Birmingham remain chronically deprived, highlighting a static hierarchy unaffected by “levelling up.” Newly adjusted measures that factor in housing costs reveal extreme child poverty in 31 inner London pockets—Tower Hamlets 71%, Hackney 64%, Newham 60%, Islington 53%—reshaping funding allocations and sparking north–south resource tensions.

articles.title: Living with the hidden horrors of illegal HMOs  | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to an article by Aditya Chakrabortty on the scandal involving houses in multiple occupation
articles.summary: A resident describes two unlicensed HMOs in their six-flat block being illegally overcrowded with up to eight adults despite permission for three, resulting in broken furniture, urine-soaked mattresses and cockroach infestations. The housing association has dismissed repeated tenant complaints as “unproven” to protect landlords’ rights. Correspondents urge strict enforcement: confiscate and renovate non-compliant properties, fund courts for swift action, and allow tenants to reclaim rent for unlicensed HMOs. They fault underfunded councils, overwhelmed courts and buy-to-let incentives for enabling exploitative conditions and call for stronger regulation and accountability.

articles.title: Why can’t we eradicate both pensioner and child poverty? | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Dr Carole Easton and Dr Steve Cushion say that we should not pit one disadvanted group against another when it comes to the government’s funding priorities
articles.summary: Dr Carole Easton and Dr Steve Cushion argue that framing pensioner versus child poverty as a trade-off is misguided: over 2m pensioners live in poverty and hasty triple lock cuts risk deepening their hardship. The state pension reflects intergenerational solidarity, with today’s workers funding retired generations. They warn against ageist rhetoric and stress that without carefully planned reforms and a shift in national priorities, impoverished children will become impoverished pensioners. They note no guarantee savings from scaling back the triple lock would aid children and caution that sudden reforms could skyrocket pensioner poverty.

articles.title: Alan Kilburn obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives : Housing association chief executive who pioneered the use of private finance to support social housing
articles.summary: Alan Kilburn, OBE, died at 89; as chief executive of North Housing in the 1980s, he led major regeneration of Georgian and Victorian terraces in Newcastle, insisted tenants own their homes, served as 1982-83 president of the Chartered Institute of Housing and on the Duke of Edinburgh’s Inquiry, forging £65m in private finance amid cutbacks. He rebranded North as Home in 1995, expanded across England, and later held non-executive directorships at Barratt, Northern Rock Foundation, Affinity Sutton and Centre for Life. A founder of disability charity Azure, he began as a housing manager in Peterlee and is survived by his wife Doreen and two children.

articles.title: Almost all children in 73 areas of England live in low-income households
articles.trailText: New official measures show levelling up attempts have failed to shift high levels of deprivation
articles.summary: Revised 2025 indices of multiple deprivation show 73 English neighbourhoods where ≥99% of children live in income-deprived families once high rents are factored in, including 31 micro-areas in inner London (Tower Hamlets, Hackney, Haringey, Westminster). Blackpool, Middlesbrough, Burnley, Manchester and Birmingham remain the five most deprived local authorities; Jaywick in Essex again ranks worst at neighbourhood level. The housing-cost adjustment reframes child poverty as a capital crisis, may alter November’s council funding formula and impact local authority and NHS budgets amid the government’s pending child-poverty strategy. Coastal towns still feature heavily, though some areas have seen relief through gentrification.

articles.title: UK woman who booked Oslo flight but did not fly loses child benefit ‘because she emigrated’
articles.trailText: Exclusive: HMRC told Lisa Morris-Almond there was no record of her return to UK, but she did not take the trip
articles.summary: Lisa Morris-Almond had her UK child benefit frozen after HMRC wrongly flagged her as emigrated based on a booked but never flown London–Oslo flight. She joins 23,500 parents suspended in a pilot fraud crackdown driven by Border Force passenger data rather than PAYE tax records. HMRC apologised, halted pre-emptive suspensions, reinstated PAYE cross-checks and urged affected claimants to answer a simplified questionnaire. The scheme, which had reviewed 1.5 million of 6.9 million beneficiaries and restored 589 payments so far, faces Lib Dem demands for parliamentary scrutiny amid reports of similar false positives, such as a woman flagged post-Eurostar trip.

articles.title: Only full abolition of two-child benefit cap will substantially cut poverty, thinktank says
articles.trailText: Resolution Foundation says half-measures would have little or no meaningful impact on child poverty rates
articles.summary: Resolution Foundation warns only fully scrapping the two-child benefit cap will meaningfully reduce child poverty, cutting 330,000 children out of poverty today and 150,000 by 2029-30; partial measures (lifting the limit for working families, raising it to three/four children or tapered payments) would barely alter rates. Introduced in 2017, the cap blocks £3,500 per additional child, affecting 1.7 million youngsters, and, unless abolished, is set to drive poverty from 31% to 34% by 2029-30. Existing boosts to universal credit, free school meals and crisis funds are insufficient, the thinktank concludes.

articles.title: Patients go to court to stop embryos being destroyed after admin error
articles.trailText: Lawyer says ‘difficult to understand’ rules on storage consent led to confusion and left clients ‘in limbo’
articles.summary: A group of at least 15 fertility patients, including cancer survivors, are suing to prevent their frozen embryos being destroyed after clinics missed consent renewals due to errors in applying 2022 and 2020 storage extensions (from 10 to 55 years with 10-year consent cycles). Clinics failed to notify or held wrong expiry data while still accepting payments. Lawyers argue this breaches Article 8 rights and seek a court order to allow six-month windows to renew consent. The HFEA and DH support case-by-case relief; judgment pending from Mrs Justice Morgan.

articles.title: Robert Wilkinson obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives : Local authority community worker who became a freelance expert in recording oral history
articles.summary: Robert Wilkinson, who died aged 73 of Lewy body dementia, spent over 30 years as a Waltham Forest community worker (1977–1998), later managing lottery funding bids in Camden and securing more than £15 million for local projects. In 1983 he co-founded the Waltham Forest Oral History Workshop, served as treasurer of the Oral History Society and worked freelance from 2007 to 2020, including residencies at Kettle’s Yard and the British Library. A lifelong socialist, union rep and school governor, he is survived by his wife Val, three sons and five grandchildren.

articles.title: Councils in England face clampdown on four-day working weeks
articles.trailText: Steve Reed writes to South Cambridgeshire council raising concerns over performance and value for money
articles.summary: Local government secretary Steve Reed has written to South Cambridgeshire council—the only English authority formally trialing a four-day, 32-hour week at full pay—warning it has damaged housing services, citing declines in rent collection, reletting times and tenant satisfaction. Reed has sought formal assurances and a meeting to mitigate further service impacts amid broader government guidance discouraging shortened workweeks. Council leader Bridget Smith disputes these findings, highlighting £400K savings, 41% lower turnover, improved recruitment and stable performance across most KPIs. Ministers can only discourage, not ban, such trials. The 4 Day Week Foundation’s Joe Ryle decries the clampdown.

articles.title: HMRC pauses child benefit crackdown after 23,500 families caught up in data error
articles.trailText: Parents say they were treated as fraudsters because Home Office travel records failed to show their return to UK
articles.summary: HMRC has paused suspending child benefit payments after flawed Home Office travel data wrongly halted 23,500 cases, misidentifying routine holidays, work trips and Belfast–Dublin returns as fraud. A Guardian/Detail probe revealed parents flagged despite legitimate travel—eg, a working trip to Amsterdam before birth, a repatriation from France—and forced to supply years of bank statements. Following two apologies, HMRC will cross-check PAYE records, verify eligibility before action and deploy a dedicated team to reinstate benefits without lengthy interviews. MP Paul Kohler has urged strong safeguards for Northern Ireland families; an urgent review is underway.

articles.title: Hundreds of hospice beds and staff cut in England  amid funding crisis
articles.trailText: National Audit Office reports nearly two-thirds of independent hospices in deficit in 2023-24 as demand increases
articles.summary: A National Audit Office report finds that in 2023–24 nearly two-thirds of England’s independent hospices ran a £78 m deficit, forcing cuts to about 300 inpatient beds and staff despite rising palliative-care demand. Only 29% of hospice income came from government, the rest from charities, creating a postcode lottery in service provision. With ministers unaware of their reliance on the sector, the NAO urges the Department of Health and NHS England to assess funding resilience and plan for future end-of-life care needs.

articles.title: ‘No more children are going to die like you’: how Sheffield mother kept her promise to boys killed by father 11 years ago
articles.trailText: Claire Throssell has been central to the campaign to repeal parental contact laws following the deaths of her two sons at the hands of their father in 2014
articles.summary: Claire Throssell, whose sons Jack (12) and Paul (9) were killed by their father during an unsupervised, court-ordered visit in 2014, has spearheaded the Child First campaign with Women’s Aid to repeal the legal presumption of parental contact after her warnings of violence were ignored. Eleven years after promising Jack “no more children will die like you,” she met the prime minister as the government announced plans to scrap that presumption. A new report logged 67 similar deaths over 30 years, and Throssell continues to push for child-safety reforms.

articles.title: NHS makes morning-after pill available for free across pharmacies in England
articles.trailText: Those in need of free emergency contraception no longer have to see their GP or attend a sexual health clinic
articles.summary: The NHS has expanded free access to the morning-after pill across nearly 10,000 pharmacies in England, removing the need for GP or clinic appointments and ending a postcode lottery where costs reached up to £30. National clinical director Dr Sue Mann calls it the biggest change to sexual health services since the 1960s and a key step in shifting care into communities, with four in five people living within a 20-minute walk of a pharmacy. The rollout coincides with new pharmacy support for patients newly prescribed antidepressants. Industry and government leaders stress the need for sustainable funding to keep pharmacies at the heart of accessible reproductive and mental healthcare.

articles.title: Five more prisoners freed in error after sex offender’s release from Essex jail
articles.trailText: Union says staff shortages and confusion over early release schemes are driving a rise in mistakes
articles.summary: The Prison Officers’ Association says five additional inmates were mistakenly released in one week across five facilities—including HMP Pentonville, Durham, The Mount and Reading Crown Court—after a convicted sex offender’s accidental early release from HMP Chelmsford sparked public outrage. One released prisoner remains at large. The union blames staffing shortages, inadequate training and confusing early-release schemes introduced to ease overcrowding. Justice Secretary David Lammy described the blunder as human error and has ordered immediate tightening of release checks. MoJ data show error releases rose 128% to 262 in the year to March 2025.

articles.title: EHRC guidance will help businesses comply with the law on sex and gender | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Kishwer Falkner , chair of the Equality and Human Rights Commission, says its updated code of practice will balance the rights of service users and protect all from discrimination
articles.summary: Kishwer Falkner, EHRC chair, reassures businesses that the EHRC’s updated code of practice on sex and gender under the Equality Act—submitted to government seven weeks ago—will clarify legal duties after the Supreme Court’s redefinition of “sex.” Informed by consultations with over 50,000 organisations and individuals, it offers practical examples to help service providers balance user rights and avoid discrimination. While not exhaustive, it may necessitate policy changes or facility reconfigurations. Falkner emphasises that compliance with the Equality Act is mandatory, as litigation risks outweigh implementation costs, and that the EHRC advises on but does not create the law.

articles.title: Gambling does not cause any ‘social ills’, lobbyist tells incredulous MPs
articles.trailText: Head of UK’s Betting and Gaming Council was asked to repeat claim as she spoke against increasing taxes on sector in November budget
articles.summary: Grainne Hurst, chief executive of the Betting and Gaming Council, told MPs on the Treasury select committee that gambling causes no “social ills” and warned that higher taxes in the November budget would jeopardize jobs, high-street betting shops and sports sponsorship. Under scrutiny from chair Meg Hillier and member John Glen, she insisted the sector is properly taxed and further levies would push punters into unregulated markets. Expert witnesses—including ex-Paddy Power director Stewart Kenny and policy analysts—urged higher taxes on risky products like online casinos while keeping lower rates on horse-racing and bingo. MPs now await Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s budget decision amid industry threats of shop closures.

articles.title: Bankrupt Woking to get £500m bailout in Surrey council shake-up
articles.trailText: ‘Unprecedented’ move helps to smooth over creation of two new ‘mega council’ unitary authorities
articles.summary: Ministers will underwrite a £500m bailout for bankrupt Woking borough, wiping out part of its £2bn debt racked up by risky Tory-era investments. The unprecedented intervention by communities secretary Steve Reed paves the way for Labour’s plan to merge Surrey’s county and 11 district/borough councils into two unitary “mega” authorities. West Surrey will combine Woking with five boroughs, East Surrey merges six districts, aiming to deliver efficiency savings, devolution and service improvements. Additional support may follow if asset disposals and grants fall short. The shake-up marks England’s largest local government reorganisation since the 1970s.

articles.title: Exclamation marks! Why do women use them three times as much as men?
articles.trailText: It’s the punctuation that can make you seem warmer and more agreeable – but also much more compliant and lacking in analytical thinking
articles.summary: New Journal of Experimental Social Psychology research finds women use exclamation marks three times more often than men, driven by a need to appear warm and approachable in text-based communication where neutral punctuation can seem cold or hostile. While exclamation marks boost perceived friendliness, overuse undermines authority and analytical credibility, explaining their absence in formal proclamations like royal announcements. Inflation of exclamation marks in casual writing—exacerbated by Gen Z’s aversion to periods—diminishes their impact, fueling a cycle of increasing punctuation intensity to signal warmth.

articles.title: Black women with fibroids face delays and poor care in the UK, says report
articles.trailText: Exclusive: All-party parliamentary group on black health found 27% not offered any treatment after diagnosis
articles.summary: All-party parliamentary group on Black health’s report, based on a survey of over 500 women (70% Black British), reveals UK Black women with uterine fibroids face systemic neglect: 27% were offered no treatment post-diagnosis, over half waited at least two years for a diagnosis, and a quarter endured fibroids for more than a decade. Disproportionate first-line hysterectomies overshadow under-utilised non-surgical options. Only six UK studies on fibroids ran between 2014–21. Experts and MPs call for urgent research, policy reform, improved screening, and equitable care to address this reproductive health emergency.

articles.title: HMRC cuts child benefit for 23,500 families based on incomplete travel data
articles.trailText: UK tax agency apologises after flagging people as having emigrated, often when they return via different routes
articles.summary: HMRC suspended child benefit for 23,489 of 6.9m claimants after its crackdown flagged one‐way travel data as evidence of emigration. Affected families – from parents doing one‐day autism‐support trips to Amsterdam to bereaved relatives flying via Dublin – were wrongly classed as living abroad, faced suspension demands and had to produce bank, school and GP records. HMRC apologised, is reviewing systems and says most cases were valid suspensions; ministers claim the fraud drive could save £350m with expanded investigator teams.

articles.title: Picture of health: going to art galleries can improve wellbeing, study reveals
articles.trailText: Viewing original works of art can relieve stress, cut heart disease risk and boost immune system, first study of its kind finds
articles.summary: A UK study led by King’s College London measured physiological responses of 50 adults (aged 18–40) viewing original Manet, Van Gogh and Gauguin art at the Courtauld Gallery versus reproductions outside a gallery. Gallery viewers saw cortisol levels drop by 22% (vs 8%), IL-6 and TNF-alpha fall by 30% and 28%, plus increased heart rate and skin-temperature dips. Findings show original art simultaneously modulates immune, endocrine and autonomic systems to reduce stress and boost wellbeing. Art Fund calls benefits universal, urging gallery visits.

articles.title: Cyclist gets 3D-printed face after drunk driver left him with third-degree burns
articles.trailText: Dave Richards, 75, who suffered full-thickness burns, given mimetic prosthetic by new NHS 3D medical centre
articles.summary: Dave Richards, 75, was left with full-thickness third-degree burns to one side of his face, back, pelvis and multiple ribs after a speeding drunk driver hit him in July 2021 while he cycled. Surgeons removed his eye to avoid infection, reconstructed his face with a free flap from his neck, and have now fitted him with a custom 3D-printed prosthetic face—matching his skin, hair and eye colour—produced at Bristol’s new NHS 3D medical centre integrating scanning, design and printing. The driver received a three-year sentence, served one and a half years on good behaviour.

articles.title: Foster carers across England facing widespread racism, sector leader says
articles.trailText: Government urged to act over ‘impact of far-right sentiment’ on children, foster carers and social workers
articles.summary: Harvey Gallagher, chief executive of the Nationwide Association of Fostering Providers, warns of widespread racism, extremism and far-right sentiment undermining foster care in England. He cites reports of BAME foster children too fearful to leave home, white carers questioned in public over ethnically diverse placements, and African-Caribbean and Asian social workers facing their “most racist” working environments. Gallagher has urged children’s minister Josh MacAlister for urgent government guidance to tackle normalized discriminatory attitudes, protect unaccompanied asylum-seekers and prevent a hostile climate that could drive vulnerable youth toward radicalisation. A coalition of 150+ charities backs the call. The education department pledges new recruitment hubs, £500m early intervention funding and forthcoming reforms.

articles.title: Ministers warned not to scapegoat prison staff over mistaken release of Hadush Kebatu
articles.trailText: Justice secretary blames human error but other say there are systemic problems and targeting an individual is ‘unjust’
articles.summary: Justice Secretary David Lammy has ordered an inquiry, chaired by Lynne Owens, after asylum seeker Hadush Kebatu—convicted of sexually assaulting a 14-year-old—was mistakenly freed from HMP Chelmsford and re-arrested two days later. The Prison Officers’ Association condemns the suspension of a single discharge manager while senior staff share blame, and chief inspector Charlie Taylor warns that release errors are “endemic” across an overstretched system. Ministers will impose a five-page checklist and stricter ID checks, yet governors say these measures won’t fix deep staffing cuts and systemic breakdowns.

articles.title: ‘Gross failure’ led to deaths of mother and baby in Prestwich home birth
articles.trailText: Jennifer Cahill and her daughter, Agnes Lily, died in birth described by coroner as ‘a Victorian-age nightmare’
articles.summary: An inquest into the June 2024 home birth of Jennifer Cahill in Prestwich concluded that a 'gross failure' by community midwives and NHS trust advice led to her fatal postpartum haemorrhage and newborn Agnes Lily’s death days later. Despite Cahill’s high-risk status after a previous severe hemorrhage, she received inadequate risk assessment, unclear guidance on hospital delivery, poor communication of her birth plan and exhausted midwives failed to monitor vital signs properly. Coroner Joanne Kearsley condemned the 'Victorian-age nightmare' and will recommend urgent training and referral process reforms.

articles.title: Men need twice as much exercise as women to lower heart disease risk, study finds
articles.trailText: Researchers suggest ‘sex-specific strategies’ after analysis of cardiovascular health improvements
articles.summary: Analysis of UK Biobank data from 80,243 adults finds women achieve a 30% drop in coronary heart disease risk with 250 minutes of weekly exercise, while men require 530 minutes to match this benefit. Women meeting standard 150-minute guidelines saw a 22% risk reduction over eight years; men saw 17%. Among 5,000+ patients with existing heart disease, active women had a threefold lower mortality risk compared to active men. Published in Nature Cardiovascular Research by Dr. Jiajin Chen et al at Xiamen University, the study suggests tailoring guidelines to account for sex differences.

articles.title: NHS trust pleads guilty after teenage girl absconded from 24-hour care and killed herself
articles.trailText: Ellame Ford-Dunn, 16, suffered with severe mental health problems and absconded from Worthing hospital in March 2022
articles.summary: University Hospitals Sussex NHS Trust pleaded guilty at Brighton magistrates to failing to provide safe care after 16-year-old Ellame Ford-Dunn, diagnosed with autism, ADHD and dyslexia, absconded from its Bluefin acute children’s ward in March 2022 and killed herself minutes later. The court heard the trust’s 2019 missing-patient policy lacked guidance on pursuing vulnerable absconders. Admitted amid a national shortage of child mental-health beds, the ward lacked resources. UHSussex faces sentencing on 26 November and further manslaughter probes.

articles.title: Physiotherapy care in decline because of poor NHS facilities, poll shows
articles.trailText: Six in 10 practitioners say loss of rehabilitation space in hospitals is harming chances of patients recovering
articles.summary: Survey of 2,000 NHS physiotherapists by the Chartered Society of Physiotherapists finds 40% have lost dedicated rehab space, 60% had rooms reallocated, and 74% report a decline in rehab quality. Fifty-seven percent lack essential equipment, driving 51% to see increased patient disability and 53% more readmissions. Stroke rehab gyms cut to 15 m² struggle to meet three hours of daily supervised therapy. Practitioners warn sidelining rehab risks recovery and urge enforcement of NHS estates guidance. The Department of Health pledges more community-based rehab centres.

articles.title: What does mistaken release of Hadush Kebatu say about state of prisons in England and Wales?
articles.trailText: The Ethiopian asylum seeker, jailed for sexual assault and due to be deported, was wrongly freed instead
