articles.summary: After 40 years without accommodations, Sandra Thom-Jones, autistic and diagnosed at 50, discovered during Melbourne’s COVID lockdown that remote work eliminated sensory and social exhaustion from bright lights, AC, noise and masking. Empowered, she negotiated dimmer switches, AC vent removal, WFH days, sunglasses, headphones, diet considerations, boosting her wellbeing and productivity. As a senior leader, her visible adjustments encouraged other autistic staff to seek reasonable changes. She urges workplaces to understand neurodivergent needs and implement low-cost accommodations for mutual benefit.

articles.title: Hampstead Heath swimming ponds considering limiting transgender users’ access
articles.trailText: Trans swimmers currently able to use a mixed pond or either of the segregated ponds for the gender they identify as
articles.summary: City of London Corporation is consulting on six options for transgender access to Hampstead Heath’s gender-segregated ponds—where trans swimmers can currently choose men’s, women’s or mixed pools—including a ban on using ponds that match their gender identity. Triggered by Sex Matters’ legal threat after the Supreme Court ruled trans women aren’t legally women, and pressure from the Kenwood Ladies’ Pond Association, the review follows a failed 2018 protest and a 2024 vote rejecting exclusion. Sex Matters cites privacy and dignity; trans users call proposals discriminatory, impractical and warn of policing by physical traits. The CLC vows a fair, transparent, law-compliant outcome.

articles.title: Stalin, Putin and an enduring obsession with immortality | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Readers respond to an article by Aleks Krotoski about dictators and tech billionaires wanting to ‘solve the problem’ of ageing
articles.summary: Readers trace a throughline from Stalin’s 1939 backing of haematologist Aleksandr Bogomolets—whose serums, herbs and young-blood transfusions promised a 150-year lifespan—to Putin’s rumored rejuvenation via youth blood. They invoke Aldous Huxley’s After Many a Summer, where an immortal-seeking millionaire devolves evolutionarily, as a cautionary tale against modern biotech narcissism. The letters argue that the elites’ obsession with eternal youth persists and may now be reaching new extremes under Putin.

articles.title: More than 60,000 cancer patients in England ‘not getting necessary radiotherapy’
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Analysis of NHS data by Radiotherapy UK also shows some patients face waits of up to six months
articles.summary: Exclusive Radiotherapy UK analysis of NHS data shows only 120,569 of 181,023 patients (35%) received needed radiotherapy, leaving 60,455 untreated annually and some waiting up to six months. Uptake varies regionally (33.7–36%), with 61% waiting over 62 days versus an 85% target. Seventy-five percent of radiotherapy chiefs warn staff shortages and idle machines risk patient safety, prompting 91 leaders to demand urgent government investment in equipment, workforce and policy prioritisation. International benchmarks rank the UK behind Denmark and France in radiotherapy access and timeliness.

articles.title: Advantages of online GP booking systems | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Martin Giebner says the problem is the mismatch between demand and capacity, not how appointments are booked, while Jonathan Hauxwell thinks online systems create better-targeted appointments
articles.summary: Two letters argue that online GP appointment booking for routine concerns streamlines workflow, freeing reception staff for urgent calls and addressing the true bottleneck—demand vs capacity. Martin Giebner notes non-urgent slots remain unchanged and can be self-booked, reducing admin burdens. Jonathan Hauxwell praises his practice's online triage, with 90-minute responses, same-day visits or prescriptions, plus phone fallback, retaining phone access for those unable to go online. They caution against BMA's "tsunami" rhetoric and hail it as one of the few sensible government health-policy interventions, stressing that clear guidance and support will be key to uptake.

articles.title: Landmark study shows 1.4m Britons have a gambling problem
articles.trailText: Watchdog’s report highlights growing dangers of slot machines and in-play betting on matches
articles.summary: Britain’s Gambling Commission survey of 19,000 finds 2.7% of adults (1.4 m) score 8+ on the problem gambling severity index, marking a new extrapolated national estimate. Rates are highest in deprived areas and for slot machines and in-play sports betting—weekly in-play bettors are three times likelier to be problem gamblers. Published as Chancellor Rachel Reeves signals autumn-budget tax rises on the £11.5 bn industry and Gordon Brown backs a £3 bn duty hike, the report prompts debate over economic drag versus tax revenue. The Betting & Gaming Council disputes the methodology and defends voluntary £170 m funding for research and treatment. Operators are urged to use these insights to mitigate risks.

articles.title: UK woman who refused cancer drugs was influenced by mother, inquest finds
articles.trailText: Paloma Shemirani, 23, died after refusing chemotherapy for non-Hodgkin lymphoma despite doctors’ concerns
articles.summary: Coroner ruled 23-year-old Paloma Shemirani’s refusal of chemotherapy for non-Hodgkin lymphoma—and her subsequent death—was “adversely influenced” by her mother, Kay (aka conspiracy influencer Kate Shemirani). Coroner Catherine Wood said Paloma “probably would have survived” had she accepted chemo. Doctors had estimated an 80% survival with chemo, but Paloma, who had a background in natural healing, instead pursued alternative treatments and forensic psychiatrist sessions recommended by her mother. Twin brother Gabriel blamed Kay entirely. Struck off in 2021 for spreading Covid-19 misinformation, Kay denied responsibility and accused medical staff of negligence.

articles.title: Blackburn MP’s baby was target of ‘depraved’ online abuse hours after being born
articles.trailText: Independent Adnan Hussain says racist and sexist posts expose ‘dark abyss of hatred and despair’ in UK being left to grow unchecked
articles.summary: Independent Blackburn MP Adnan Hussain says his newborn daughter was subjected to “utterly depraved” racist, sexist and Islamophobic abuse on X within hours of her birth after he shared a pixelated photo. The pro-Gaza MP, elected in 2024, deleted the post when bots and users questioned his Britishness, demanded his baby’s deportation and hurled gendered slurs. Hussain warns this episode exposes an unchecked “dark abyss of hatred and despair” in UK public life and urges a force equally strong to counter rising online extremism.

articles.title: Sunbeds should be banned in UK, skin cancer experts say
articles.trailText: Campaigners urge ministers to close tanning salons across country over dangers posed by UV radiation
articles.summary: Cancer experts including Manchester’s Christie hospital, Melanoma Focus and an Australian specialist urge UK ministers to ban all commercial sunbeds, citing carcinogenic UV exposure and widespread flouting of the under-18 ban. IARC classifies sunbeds as melanoma-causing; melanoma rates (17,600 diagnoses, 2,700 deaths yearly) are rising. Current under-18 restrictions fail among 16-17-year-olds. Closing ~4,463 salons (£11–55m compensation) and public education could save lives and ease NHS costs. Tanning is surging among Gen Z, sometimes marketed as wellness. WCRF endorses closures; Cancer Research UK warns against sunbeds but stops short of a full ban. Govt says sunbeds raise melanoma risk and is weighing further regulation.

articles.title: Autism should not be seen as single condition with one cause, say scientists
articles.trailText: Those diagnosed as small children typically have distinct genetic profile from those diagnosed later, study finds
articles.summary: An international analysis of genetic and behavioural data from over 45,000 autistic individuals in Europe and the US reveals that autism diagnoses before age 6 and after age 10 reflect distinct biological and developmental profiles rather than a single condition. Early-diagnosed children exhibit stable social-communication deficits, motor delays and specific genetic variants, while later-diagnosed adolescents show rising social difficulties, higher co-occurring depression, ADHD- and PTSD-related genetic signals. Researchers emphasize a diagnostic gradient and warn against rigid subcategories despite broad autism heterogeneity.

articles.title: Samaritans to push on with branch closures despite volunteers’ objections
articles.trailText: Charity has apparently reduced number of sites it wants to shut but insists ‘change needs to happen’
articles.summary: Under pressure from volunteer backlash, Samaritans will press ahead with plans to shrink its 200-strong UK branch network via three-year regional pilots in southeast England, Yorkshire and Humberside, and Scotland. Proposed measures—branch mergers, clusters, relocations and potential closures—aim to boost call-answer rates from 70–80% to 90% by creating larger hubs and attracting more volunteers. While the charity has removed specific closure targets, volunteers warn many may quit, fearing loss of community roots, longer travel, reduced morale and safety concerns over home-based call handling. CEO Julie Bentley insists the changes are evolutionary, not revolutionary, and vital to sustain services.

articles.title: Scottish parliament votes in favour of allowing councils to cap rent increases
articles.trailText: Legislation hailed as ‘historic step for fixing rigged housing market’ but campaigners say bolder action needed
articles.summary: Scotland’s parliament passed a landmark housing bill granting ministers power to designate rent control zones where councils can cap rent increases at inflation plus one percentage point (max 6%). Touted as the UK’s first long-term rent controls and hailed by the Scottish Greens, the measure exempts mid-market, build-to-let and student housing, prompting tenants’ union Living Rent to warn of a “two-tier” system. The bill also enacts “Awaab’s law” for mandatory landlord repairs, stronger support for social tenants facing abuse, and uncapped taxes on second and empty homes. SNP minister Màiri McAllan lauds new homelessness-prevention duties, while Shelter Scotland and campaigners urge bolder action amid falling housing completions.

articles.title: Campaigners urged to tell new story on child poverty in Scotland
articles.trailText: Charities launch practical guide for campaigners, saying ‘the way we talk about it doesn’t always help’
articles.summary: Joseph Rowntree Foundation and Save the Children have published “The new story of child poverty in Scotland,” a practical guide urging campaigners to reframe narratives on child poverty to counter far-right exploitation of public disillusionment. It recommends using single statistics, storytelling that emphasises shared futures, and avoiding technical overload or stigmatizing language. Polling shows over 75% support stronger action. The toolkit stresses connecting with feelings of being ignored, offering hopeful solutions, and leveraging next May’s Holyrood election to rebuild trust and secure political commitment.

articles.title: Rosalind Hinton obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: GP and family planning doctor who helped one of her patients become the first woman to give birth to an IVF baby
articles.summary: Obituary of Dr Rosalind 'Ra' Hinton, died aged 94, GP and family planning doctor in Bristol. Born to physician Lucy Hamson and lawyer Charles Elliott, she endured wartime evacuation to Monmouthshire, studied at Downe House and was renowned for her resilience, intellect, humour and compassion. Trained at Royal Free (1955), she spent three decades treating infertility. Her 1976 referral of Lesley Brown to Patrick Steptoe led to birth of Louise Brown, the first IVF baby. Married naval officer Josh Hinton (1956), taught at Bristol University. Survived by three children, six grandchildren, two great-grandchildren and brother.

articles.title: NHS 10-year plan will embed privatisation and hollow out the health service | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Government reforms could lead to the NHS going the way of social care, where the state is longer able, or willing, to deliver, says Margaret Greenwood
articles.summary: Greenwood warns the government’s 10-year NHS plan embeds privatisation by shifting outpatients from public hospitals to public–private neighbourhood health centres and contracting out core services. She cites Centre for Health and the Public Interest research showing 1 in £3 spent on cataract operations leaks out as profit, and invokes Sam Freedman’s Failed State: Why Nothing Works and How We Fix It, which documents social care beds falling from 64% state provision in 1979 to 6% by 2012. She fears these reforms will hollow out the NHS, replicating social care’s loss of state capacity and will to deliver.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves to lift two-child benefit cap in November budget
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Officials exploring options to change rule that affected 1.7 million children in Great Britain last year
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves intends to lift the two-child limit on universal credit and child tax credit in her November budget, addressing Labour MPs’ and child poverty campaigners’ demands. Keir Starmer backs responses to a child poverty taskforce report advocating full repeal—affecting 1.7m children and costing around £3.5bn, but officials explore tapered payments beyond three or four children or extend increases only to working parents to mitigate costs and avoid incentives to economic inactivity. Critics say only full removal ends a “cruel” cap; partial reforms risk keeping 120,000–350,000 children in poverty. Some propose funding via higher gambling taxes, winter fuel cuts and a £500m family hub investment is already planned.

articles.title: Labour to tackle care sector crisis in England with pay increase and new negotiating body
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Wes Streeting to put £500m behind initial rise but unions say ‘substantially more’ investment will be needed
articles.summary: Labour will boost care workers’ pay in England from 2028, backed by an initial £500m and a new joint negotiating body of unions and employers to establish legally backed fair pay agreements. Health Secretary Wes Streeting pledges to fund this via the £4bn adult social care budget, aiming to stem high vacancy rates and visa strain. Consultation starts after the employment bill, with negotiations in 2027. Unions Unison and GMB welcome action but call for “substantially more” investment. A national care service blueprint will be delivered over a decade by Lady Casey.

articles.title: GPs in England threaten action over online appointment booking plan
articles.trailText: Doctors’ union says GPs will be overwhelmed by ‘triage tsunami’ and gives ministers 48 hours to take measures
articles.summary: GPs in England, led by the BMA, warn that rolling out all-day online booking (8 am–6:30 pm) from 1 October without promised safeguards will trigger a ‘triage tsunami’, overwhelming practices, cutting face-to-face slots and risking delays to urgent care. They’ve issued ministers a 48-hour ultimatum for safety measures or face ballots on industrial action, such as capping patient lists. Health Secretary Wes Streeting defends the move as boosting choice and easing the 8 am rush; DHSC points to pilot successes, while the Patients Association urges swift, expert urgency assessments.

articles.title: Cannabis stocks soar after Trump shares video promoting drug’s use for seniors
articles.trailText: Video posted on Truth Social touts CBD as a ‘gamechanger’ and promotes Medicaid coverage of CBD products
articles.summary: Cannabis equities jumped after Donald Trump shared a nearly three-minute video on Truth Social, produced by the Commonwealth Project, calling hemp-derived CBD a “gamechanger” for senior pain and stress relief and urging Medicare and Medicaid coverage. Leading firms—Tilray (up 40%), Canopy Growth, Cronos Group—and the MSOS ETF rallied Monday. The clip praised Trump’s 2018 farm bill legalizing industrial hemp. Though Biden’s HHS has asked the DEA to down-schedule cannabis from Schedule I, federal decriminalization is pending. Currently 40 states allow medical use and 24 recreational. New DEA chief Terrance Cole’s stance on reclassification remains uncertain.

articles.title: Housing secretary says work will start on three new towns before election
articles.trailText: Steve Reed hails predecessor Angela Rayner as ‘true working-class hero’ and accuses Tories of blocking new homes
articles.summary: Steve Reed, new housing secretary, vows to begin building three pilot new towns—Tempsford (Bedfordshire), Crews Hill (north London) and South Bank (Leeds)—before the next election, part of a 12-town target, blaming 14 years of Conservative planning blocks for unaffordable housing. Donning a “Build, baby, build” hat, he accused Tories of “crushing dreams,” pledged to reform planning to speed developments and praised predecessor Angela Rayner as a “true working-class hero.” Reed admitted recent completions lagged due to past permission delays. Shadow secretary James Cleverly called the promises empty, while Reed reaffirmed support for Keir Starmer’s leadership.

articles.title: David Enoch obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Psychiatrist who helped to switch mental health care away from hospitals and into the community
articles.summary: David Enoch (1926–2025) was a pioneering psychiatrist and founding fellow of the Royal College of Psychiatrists who championed humane mental health care. Spurred by wartime service, he studied at St Thomas’ and the Maudsley, publishing Uncommon Psychiatric Syndromes (1967) on Capgras syndrome. As consultant at Shelton Hospital, he instituted “care in the community,” transforming asylums into training centres. He advised on reforms after Barbara Robb’s Sans Everything exposé. In Liverpool he built a leading department, taught with compassion, authored faith-informed works like Healing the Hurt Mind, and remained active until 2012. Survived by wife Anne, son Dafydd and grandchildren.

articles.title: UK businesses fear new EHRC guidance on toilets will be ‘unworkable’
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Stonewall writes to ministers and warns cost of compliance could be ‘significant’ for struggling companies
articles.summary: Businesses warn new EHRC guidance implementing April Supreme Court ruling on sex in toilet access, which would allow birth certificate checks to enforce single-sex facilities, will impose significant unassessed costs, be confusing and unworkable. Stonewall, in a letter to ministers, blasted the lack of practical examples, clear cost analysis and the six-week, AI-analysed consultation, urging clearer rules. UKHospitality, Co-op, Awin and others cite logistical, legal and inclusion risks—from listed buildings to data privacy—while hundreds of firms fear becoming legal test cases.

articles.title: Elijah used to carry knives to feel safe. After leaving a Melbourne youth gang he chose a different path
articles.trailText: Teenagers speak out about the realities of life for young people affected by knife crime and youth offending
articles.summary: After release from detention, 17-year-old Elijah* rejoined a Melbourne youth gang and carried knives for protection, reflecting a surge in violent offending after the stabbing deaths of 15-year-old Dau Akueng and 12-year-old Chol Achiek. Police say children made up 1,128 of 5,400 serial repeat offenders responsible for 40% of crime and 7,118 youth arrests last year. Enrolling in an alternative education school and embracing Christian faith enabled Elijah to abandon weapons; he’s now starting a pre-apprenticeship. Advocates and a state inquiry stress early intervention, integrated health, education and social support for “crossover” kids to curb youth violence.

articles.title: Build prefab homes to address harm to ‘generation of homeless children’, says Labour MP
articles.trailText: Siobhain McDonagh urges parliament to pass renters’ rights bill to stem no-fault evictions in England
articles.summary: Labour MP Siobhain McDonagh warns of a ‘generation of homeless children’, calling for prefabricated homes to alleviate record temporary accommodation—131,140 households (169,050 children) at March end, linked to at least 74 child deaths since 2019 from unsafe sleeping, mould, overcrowding and lack of kitchens. She urges fast-tracking the renters’ rights bill to ban no-fault evictions, proposes a short-term prefab housing mission and long-term social housing build, noting Lords’ amendments and councils’ financial strain impede progress. Shelter says ~32,000 families sought council help after no-fault evictions since last July; repossessions rose 8%. Govt pledges £1bn in homelessness services and 1.5m homes by 2029 but planning shortfalls and Lords’ resistance hinder delivery.

articles.title: ‘They’ve got to go somewhere’: Bolton residents on the rise of HMOs
articles.trailText: Frustration has been brewing for some time in Horwich on outskirts of Bolton with more than 700 houses in multiple occupation
articles.summary: Residents in Horwich, Bolton, are alarmed by the surge in Houses in Multiple Occupation (HMOs) – over 700 properties, eight times the national average – as family homes are evicted, bought for ~£150k and converted into six-bed HMOs for asylum seekers without planning permission. Neighbours report falling house values (–£30k–40k), rising rents, and social unease. A grassroots “Say No to HMOs” campaign secured tougher planning rules for small HMOs. While some welcome asylum seekers, many fear alienation, property devaluation and potential far-right backlash, calling for a mature debate and government action.

articles.title: This jury was too judgmental about ADHD | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: Anyone who is neurodivergent needs understanding and support, without being made to feel that they are using their difference as an excuse, says Sue Marshall
articles.summary: Sue Marshall criticises a jury’s misunderstanding of ADHD in Raquel’s kitchen-sink case, arguing ADHD is a neurological condition rather than a behavioural choice. Drawing on her experience as a mother of an adult son with ADHD, and learning through an Open University course, books and podcasts, she notes that while therapy and mentoring can provide coping strategies, people with ADHD need empathy and support instead of being accused of using their condition as an excuse.

articles.title: The reading of the will only happens in fiction | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: The contents of a will should be well known to the deceased’s executors and solicitor (if there is one) beforehand, writes Graham Mullan
articles.summary: Graham Mullan’s letter challenges the misconception of a formal “reading of the will,” noting it exists only in Agatha Christie novels and TV melodramas. In reality, executors and solicitors know a testator’s wishes in advance and can immediately implement provisions—especially funeral instructions. He highlights that, once probate is granted, UK wills become public records accessible to anyone (save for royals and their privacy concerns). Mullan urges practical estate administration over theatrical reveal ceremonies and stresses transparency through publicly available probate documents.

articles.title: Samaritans volunteers could quit if branches are closed, say local directors
articles.trailText: Charity’s board accused of failing to listen ahead of decision expected this weekend on ‘future-proofing’ plans
articles.summary: Local directors of Samaritans warn thousands of helpline volunteers may resign if the board approves closing half of its 200 branches over the next decade in favour of regional call centres. In a letter signed by seven branch directors, they accuse leadership of ignoring volunteers’ “widespread concerns,” risking local fundraising, volunteer burnout and safety without in-person support. Surveys show 64–74% oppose closures and many fear remote call-handling will undermine camaraderie. They seek a no-confidence vote in chair Keith Leslie. Samaritans defends changes as cost-saving, improving response times and recruitment.

articles.title: Share your experiences of caring responsibilities in your relationship
articles.trailText: We would like to hear from people who have had caring responsibilities in their long-term partnership or marriage
articles.summary: As the number of full-time unpaid carers rises, the Guardian is soliciting first-hand accounts from individuals in long-term partnerships or marriages about unpaid caring responsibilities. It invites people who have depended on partners due to illness, and those who’ve been primary carers, to share challenges: partner unwillingness or inability to help, fears about care post-diagnosis, relationship fallout, or breakup. Submissions will inform coverage of how caregiving impacts intimacy, roles, and resilience in couples. Confidential contributions welcomed via an online form, subject to standard terms and privacy policy.

articles.title: ‘Exciting’ clinical results offer hope for new class of MS therapies
articles.trailText: Cambridge trial suggests diabetes drug with antihistamine can partially repair damage in the nervous system
articles.summary: A Cambridge phase 2 trial (CCMR Two) tested metformin plus antihistamine clemastine in 70 relapsing MS patients over six months. Compared with placebo, the combo accelerated visual-evoked potentials by 1.3 ms, indicating partial remyelination, but produced no measurable vision or disability improvements in that timeframe. Side effects included fatigue and diarrhoea. Investigators call this a proof-of-concept for a new class of remyelinating therapies and stress the need for larger, longer studies. Experts caution against off-label use until clinical benefit is confirmed beyond nerve-signal gains.

articles.title: ‘I can’t escape these machines’: addicts tell of huge losses from slot gambling
articles.trailText: Councils given more powers to stop ‘unwanted’ sites opening, as number of UK slot machines exceeds 30,000
articles.summary: Britain now houses nearly 30,000 low-stake slot machines in adult gaming centres and bingo venues, replacing high-stake FOBTs banned in 2019. Favoured by planning rules, these outlets proliferate in poorer areas, enabling spins every 1.5 seconds and fueling £751m in punters’ losses—up 67% in two years. Vulnerable players recount losses of £100 to £3,000 per session, while revenues for top operators rose 12% to £479m. Self-exclusion is poorly enforced amid minimal staff training and low wages. The government plans to boost local authorities’ powers to block new sites.

articles.title: What is the impact of vaping on teeth and oral health?
articles.trailText: We look at the science behind vaping and the claims it causes tooth decay, gum disease and dry mouth
articles.summary: Lily James reported vaping damaged her teeth, driving her first dental filling. Robust smoking data confirm tar and toxins cause brown stains, gum disease, tooth loss and mouth cancers. Vaping’s direct effects remain unclear: Newcastle research found marginally worse gum inflammation but no extra bone loss, while a US review of 13,000 records linked vaping to increased caries and plaque. Propylene glycol and glycerol may induce dry mouth, weakening saliva’s protective role. Cancer risk appears low but unverified. Experts recommend smokers switch, non-smokers avoid.

articles.title: Careless and damaging talk about autism | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Noting the lack of evidence for linking paracetamol to autism, James Watson-O’Neill warns against describing the condition as a tragedy or something to fear, while the mother of an autistic child says pigeonholing autistic people is deeply damaging
articles.summary: Sense CEO James Watson-O’Neill and leading autism charities condemn the Trump administration’s tenuous link between prenatal paracetamol use and autism, arguing the evidence is weak and flawed. They warn that describing autism as a tragedy or a condition to fear perpetuates stigma, undermining autistic individuals' value and contributions. A parent letter underscores autism’s diverse spectrum—highlighting that not all autistic people exhibit social or communication difficulties—and criticizes pigeonholing as harmful. The writers urge media, policymakers and public figures to use respectful, inclusive language that acknowledges autistic people’s talents, perspectives and rights.

articles.title: It’s wrong to blame boomers for Britain’s inequality and economic woes | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: It’s more complicated than that, says Rosa Anderson in response to an article by Phillip Inman, while Peter Mather says boomers are being stereotyped, and Moira Sykes says the article picks the wrong target
articles.summary: Rosa Anderson argues Inman’s boomer-bashing oversimplifies Britain’s growing inequalities, noting class, gender, race and parental wealth transfers matter more than generation, and cites Institute for Fiscal Studies data showing affluent parents provide 26 times more support than poorer ones. She warns millennials may outpace boomers in wealth but unevenly. Peter Mather decries ageist stereotyping, urging policy debate over caricatures and political/educational divides. Moira Sykes disputes the “selfish boomer” myth, calling to target property developers, buy-to-let landlords and four decades of neoliberalism. All call for nuanced, evidence-based analysis over generational scapegoating to tackle widening economic, social and health disparities.

articles.title: Women who miss first breast cancer screening at ‘40% higher risk’ of dying from the disease
articles.trailText: Study monitored 500,000 women from Sweden and found 32% did not attend first mammogram appointment
articles.summary: A Karolinska Institute analysis of 500,000 Swedish women invited to their first mammogram (1991–2020) finds, after adjusting for social, economic, reproductive and health factors, that 32% missed the appointment, correlating with a 40% higher breast cancer mortality over 25 years (9.9 vs. 7 deaths per 1,000). Non-attendees are likelier to skip subsequent screens and be diagnosed at advanced stages, implying delayed detection drives excess deaths rather than incidence. The study highlights first-screen engagement as a predictor of long-term outcomes and urges targeted outreach to boost early participation and survival.

articles.title: Doctors’ tribunals are in need of urgent reform | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: While doctors found guilty of sexual misconduct have been allowed to return to work, others who participated in peaceful climate protests have faced prolonged suspensions, write Prof Hilary Neve , Dr Rammina Yassaie and Annie Mitchell
articles.summary: Prof Hilary Neve, Dr Rammina Yassaie and Annie Mitchell critique the Medical Practitioners Tribunal Service (MPTS) after doctors convicted of rape and sexual predation were allowed back into practice, while those peacefully protesting climate-related health harms faced lengthy suspensions. They highlight conflicts of interest arising from GMC-sourced funding, subjective mitigation like character references, and inconsistent standards. Citing GMC research that public trust hinges on intentional harm rather than legality, they urge urgent reforms: independent funding, specialist tribunal training, objective sanction criteria, transparent reporting and complainant support.

articles.title: Care privatisation costs hit the NHS – and then the taxpayer | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Private care providers | System-built housing | Donald Trump | Tax in Rwanda | Cycling essentials
articles.summary: Brief letters cover: Ruth Sumner warns that profit-driven private care home closures exacerbate NHS bed blockages – one in seven beds held by patients fit to discharge –while taxpayers absorb a £200bn ‘privatisation premium.’ David Fletcher rejects system-built state housing as costly and ugly. Pam Barrett derides medical advice from Trump on injecting disinfectant. Tony Fletcher spots Rwanda’s ‘Pay tax, support a better Rwanda’ slogan at the cycling world championships. Paul Rosser champions a £6.99 rear-view mirror as an essential cycling accessory. Readers are invited to submit letters.

articles.title: Cheap supplies of HIV-prevention jab for poorer countries hailed as ‘genuine chance to end’ global epidemic
articles.trailText: Lenacapavir described as ‘next best thing’ to an HIV vaccine will cost $40 a year for each patient in 120 countries from 2027, funders say
articles.summary: From 2027, 120 low- and middle-income countries will access twice-yearly lenacapavir injections for HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis at $40 per patient annually, under Gilead’s voluntary licences to six generics including Dr Reddy’s and Hetero Labs. Endorsed by WHO as “the next best thing” to an HIV vaccine after near-complete prevention in trials, rollout partnerships—Unitaid, CHAI and Wits RHI with Dr Reddy’s, and the Gates Foundation with Hetero—seek to overcome past cost barriers, though funding gaps and excluded high-incidence nations could delay universal access.

articles.title: Is Tylenol the same as paracetamol, and should you take it in pregnancy? Here’s why experts say Trump should be ignored
articles.trailText: The US president claims the painkiller also known as acetaminophen is linked to autism. Here’s what the science says
articles.summary: President Trump urged pregnant women to avoid acetaminophen (Tylenol), claiming it raises autism risk, but global experts warn this unfounded assertion could endanger maternal health and erode trust in science. Decades of NHS guidance endorse paracetamol as the first-line analgesic in pregnancy. Large epidemiological and sibling-comparison studies, including 2.4M Swedish births, found no causal link between prenatal paracetamol use and autism. Agencies like the MHRA and FDA maintain no proven harm, though the FDA will update Tylenol labels to note a "possible association". Critics fear reduced use may lead to untreated fever, increased maternal anxiety, stigma, and worse obstetric outcomes.

articles.title: Fears of new PFI-style ‘disaster’ as firms handed £6m to advise on using private funds for NHS clinics
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Consultants and lawyers hired to advise on using public-private partnerships to build ‘neighbourhood health centres’ in England
articles.summary: Ministers have awarded Deloitte and Addleshaw Goddard £3m each to advise the Department of Health on using public-private partnerships (PPPs) to deliver new ‘neighbourhood health centres’ in deprived parts of England, developing business cases, procurement strategies and financial models for 43 planned clinics. Critics warn this risks repeating PFI’s costly legacy – NHS still owes private firms over £40bn – and breaches Labour’s pledge to keep the service publicly funded. DHSC insists any PPP will meet stringent value-for-money criteria, while the NHS Confederation argues private capital may be vital to modernise facilities. Chancellor Rachel Reeves will decide on PPP financing in the 26 November budget.

articles.title: Change prostate cancer treatment for black men to avoid ‘epidemic’, NHS urged
articles.trailText: Campaigners seek to raise awareness that twice as many black men are getting the disease than white men
articles.summary: Campaigners led by Stafford Scott warn of a prostate cancer epidemic among Black men in England, who face twice the incidence and mortality rates of white men. They urge the NHS to update guidelines to prompt earlier PSA testing and conversations, improve Black leadership and trust via partnerships with community organisations, and ensure data transparency and oversight. Through the A Dialogue of Equals podcast, they amplify lived experiences and demand holistic, community-informed reforms. The Department of Health is investing £16m in detection trials with 10% Black participants.

articles.title: Almost 1.5m homes could be built on brownfield sites in England, report finds
articles.trailText: Exclusive: CPRE study suggests housebuilding targets can be met without encroaching on green belt land
articles.summary: A CPRE study of local authority brownfield registers across England reveals enough land for 1.4m homes to meet the government’s 1.5m target without encroaching on green belt. Nearly 54% of sites, covering 32,884 ha, have planning permission for 770,000 dwellings deemed deliverable within five years. The bounty spans 30,257 sites including urban retail zones and derelict factories, yet developers favor greenfield build on areas of outstanding natural beauty. CPRE calls for strict brownfield-first enforcement to curb car-dependent countryside sprawl. Regional breakdown: 462,000 homes in London, 180,000 in south-east, 191,000 in West Midlands.

articles.title: ‘Loud and proud’: UK summit kicks off new conversation for working dads
articles.trailText: Organisers of event urge fathers to push for more equal parental rights in face of Britain’s current poor offering
articles.summary: The UK's first Working Dads' summit in London, organised by Parenting Out Loud founder Elliott Rae, urged fathers to take full parental leave, challenge outdated masculinity, and push for equal rights. Several hundred in person and 2,000 online were cautioned against corporate rollbacks on diversity and inclusion. Rae noted involved dads see lower stress and may curb the UK’s high male suicide rate. Speakers highlighted the UK’s paternity leave ranking (40th/43 OECD) and the motherhood penalty cutting women’s pay by a third. Labour MP Stella Creasy backed equal parental rights to counter maternity discrimination. A government review under the employment rights bill pledges day-one paternity leave.

articles.title: ‘Pay no attention’: global health agencies dismiss false Trump claim on everyday painkillers
articles.trailText: Medical experts and regulators say US president should not be questioning established science
articles.summary: Global health agencies including WHO, UK’s MHRA, EU’s EMA, Spain’s regulator and Australia’s TGA have dismissed President Trump’s baseless claims linking prenatal paracetamol use and autism or urging parents to delay vaccines. WHO labelled vaccine-autism theories “inconsistent”, and UK health secretary Wes Streeting urged the public to trust clinicians over politicians. Experts noted Trump’s briefing with Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. cited a 2025 review of 46 studies without proving causality, while a 2024 Swedish cohort of 2.4 million births found no link. Regulators warn untreated maternal fever risks outweigh medication fears and stress diagnostic changes, not immunisation, drive rising autism rates.

articles.title: My private messages to a lifelong friend who died | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: Heather Lee , who finds comfort in sending her late friend messages on Twitter, notes that everyone grieves differently
articles.summary: Heather Lee, responding to Justin Myers’ reflection on losing a best friend, shares her own grief after her lifelong friend of 40 years died suddenly of a heart attack. She describes the void felt when their friend group meets, her hesitation about visiting the friend’s ashes in her mother’s garden, and how private Twitter messages let her ‘talk’ to the late friend and ease her pain. Lee argues that deep friendships can be as impactful as family ties, that grief varies widely, and that employers should consider the emotional toll of friend-loss when supporting staff.

articles.title: Gender-critical discourse must calm down | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: People should not be arrested, face job loss, or excluded for what they say or who they are, says one letter writer
articles.summary: In response to Susanna Rustin’s discussion on gender-critical women, the author urges a more civil debate. While rejecting the original letter’s stance, they agree most trans people aren’t ‘bigots’ but feel demands to bar trans individuals from longstanding spaces is discriminatory. They warn that blanket medical or sports policies cause needless harm, note the lack of evidence for danger in non-contact sports, and criticize relying solely on chromosomes for policy. The letter calls for an end to arrests, job losses or exclusion based on speech or identity and invites assuming goodwill on all sides.

articles.title: Tenants’ complaints about poor social housing in England jump 43% in a year
articles.trailText: Ombudsman made 26,901 interventions to put things right, including child’s bedroom window boarded up for four years
articles.summary: Complaints from England’s social housing tenants rose over 40% year-on-year, with 7,082 ombudsman decisions on repairs and service failures and a 43% spike in poor condition grievances. The ombudsman made 26,901 interventions, awarding £5.4m—40% for damp, leaks and mould. Cases include a child’s boarded-up bedroom for four years, asbestos-threatened ceiling and blocked-access doors for a wheelchair user. Average awards fell to £947, signs of improved landlord redress, but 120 landlords had 75%+ complaints upheld. Awaab’s law, requiring 24-hour emergency repairs, starts 27 October; full rollout delayed to 2027.

articles.title: Violence in GP surgeries driven by waiting times and drug refusals, global study shows
articles.trailText: Research covering 24 countries finds female and younger staff face worst aggression from patients
articles.summary: Global analysis of 50 studies across 24 countries finds up to 90% of GP staff report physical or verbal assaults, often triggered by long wait times (31–73%) or refusals to prescribe drugs. Younger, female and junior staff, especially receptionists, face most aggression, which damages mental health and prompts resignations. Some incidents involve baseball bats, knives or COVID-infected coughs, prompting police calls or patient removals. Unmet patient demands also fuel aggression. Researchers warn inadequate conflict training may exacerbate violence. Led by U Nottingham’s Shihning Chou, the first global study highlights abuse as a public health issue. Published in BJGP.

articles.title: English GPs adopt ‘Jess’s rule’ to help ensure they do not miss serious illnesses
articles.trailText: ‘Three strikes and rethink’ approach named after Jess Brady, who died after her cancer was misdiagnosed
articles.summary: England’s NHS is introducing ‘Jess’s rule’, a ‘three strikes and rethink’ policy requiring GPs to revisit undiagnosed cases after three consultations or worsening symptoms. The initiative, named after 27-year-old Jessica Brady—wrongly treated for long Covid and only diagnosed with stage four adenocarcinoma in a private appointment—was developed by NHS England and the Royal College of General Practitioners. Health secretary Wes Streeting praised the change, driven by Andrea Brady’s petition of nearly 500,000 signatures. Jess’s rule also targets diagnostic delays among young people and ethnic minorities to improve early detection of serious illnesses.

articles.title: Graham MacGregor obituary
articles.trailText: Medical researcher and health advocate who challenged the food industry to use less salt and sugar
articles.summary: Graham Alexander MacGregor, CBE, died aged 84. A professor of cardiovascular medicine at St George’s and later Queen Mary, he founded Action on Salt in 1996 and Action on Sugar in 2014, catalysing UK industry pledges that cut average salt intake by 15% and soft-drink sugar by 42%, preventing up to 20,000 strokes/heart attacks annually, saving £1.5 bn and underpinning the UK’s sugar levy, childhood obesity plan and energy-drink ban for under-16s. He co-founded World Action on Salt, Sugar and Health with the WHO.

articles.title: ‘We’re here to help’: how Ofcom is urging porn sites to follow the Online Safety Act
articles.trailText: Amid the feathered dancers at an adult industry event, regulators with clipboards have been advising compliance
articles.summary: At an adult industry conference in Prague, Ofcom regulators toured booths urging 1,700 delegates to comply with the UK’s Online Safety Act age-verification rules introduced on 27 July. They stressed honesty in risk assessments, noted top sites have added checks or blocked UK visits and reported 7.5 m age-verified visits in August, but admitted VPN downloads and pirate-site traffic have surged. No fines yet, but 12 investigations cover over 60 services, with penalties up to £18 m or 10% revenue. Ofcom’s Porn Portfolio team continues outreach globally, while sites grapple with moderating AI-generated content and child-safety thresholds.

articles.title: ‘She never got help’: mother says daughter who died on motorway was failed by care system
articles.trailText: Tamzin Hall, 17, was struck by a vehicle after leaving a police car on the M5 motorway in Somerset after being arrested at a children’s home
articles.summary: Amy Hall says her 17-year-old daughter Tamzin, autistic with severe mental health needs, was failed by care regimes: delayed CAMHS assessments, dozens of unregulated placements and inadequate children’s home support. On 11 November 2024, after staff called police, Tamzin left the back of a police car on the M5 near Taunton and was fatally struck on the opposite carriageway. The IOPC has served misconduct notices on two Avon & Somerset officers over why she was in a standard car, how she removed handcuffs without bodycam footage, and why officers abandoned the scene; an inquest is due in November.

articles.title: ‘If he can be found, every one of the users can be’: unmasking the man behind toxic gossip website Tattle Life
articles.trailText: For almost a decade, the site has torn apart the lives of celebrities and ordinary people alike, while its creator’s identity has remained a mystery. Until one couple turned super sleuths …
articles.summary: Tattle Life, a paid-members gossip forum run by anonymous internet entrepreneur Sebastian Bond, has for almost a decade trafficked in malicious commentary targeting mostly female influencers and small-business owners, exposing private data and driving victims to trauma. After enduring defamatory threads about fake pregnancies, business sabotage, child services complaints and leaked personal records, Northern Irish retailer Donna Sands and her Silicon Valley husband Neil used forensic digital sleuthing to unmask Bond in court on 13 June 2025. Awarded £300,000 in damages, the Sands now seek to hold Bond’s users accountable, freeze his assets and pressure networks to block the site, aiming to end its profit-from-misery model.

articles.title: ‘Men don’t know why they became unhappy’: the toxic gender war dividing South Korea
articles.trailText: Toxic masculinity is a global phenomenon, but nowhere is it more virulent than in this hypermodern, connected society. What can other countries learn from this ‘ground zero’ of misogyny?
articles.summary: After Jinju convenience-store worker On Ji-goo endured a misogynistic assault by a men’s-rights activist, South Korea’s appeals court for the first time recognised misogyny as a criminal motive. Despite OECD-leading female tertiary education, Korea still has its largest gender pay gap, systemic workplace inequality and hyperconnected digital misogyny—from Ilbe’s slurs to Telegram’s “nth room” sexual-slavery chats and deepfake pornography. Anti-feminist figures like Bae In-gyu and Lee Jun-seok have mobilised male resentment into politics, provoking women-led protests and Yoon Suk Yeol’s impeachment. Groups such as Feminism With Him now run dialogue workshops to redirect male frustration constructively.

articles.title: Labour’s NHS job cuts plan in chaos amid row over £1bn costs
articles.trailText: Integrated care boards in England cannot afford severance payments, leaving restructuring plan in chaos, union says
articles.summary: Labour’s planned NHS shake-up in England has stalled as integrated care boards (ICBs) cannot afford up to £1bn in redundancy costs needed to cut 12,500 jobs by year-end under NHS England’s 50% running-cost reduction mandate. Dozens of ICBs – including North East and North Cumbria, South-west London and Yorkshire systems – have paused layoffs amid talks between NHS England, DHSC and the Treasury over emergency severance funding. Staff unrest has soared, with unions warning prolonged limbo and ministers insisting savings will boost frontline care.

articles.title: How do weight loss medications affect our relationship with food?
articles.trailText: From reduced hunger to a changing palate, weight loss jabs can alter our experience and enjoyment of food
articles.summary: GLP-1 receptor agonists like semaglutide (Wegovy) and tirzepatide (Mounjaro) reduce appetite, slow gastric emptying and amplify fullness while improving insulin response. They lower the reward value of high-fat, sugary and salty foods—mirroring bariatric surgery—temporarily shifting taste preferences and often heightening saltiness and sweetness perception, which correlates with reduced cravings, appetite and alcohol intake. Gastrointestinal effects (nausea, bloating) further deter high-energy foods. These drugs also act on taste-bud cells and brain reward centers. Together, these changes reshape the palate and relationship with food, opening up new flavor appreciation.

articles.title: The pill, Puerto Rico and the patriarchal medical system | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Rebecca Siddall responds to an article on attitudes to the contraceptive pill and reflects on medical misogyny
articles.summary: PhD researcher Rebecca Siddall responds to a recent article on contraceptive myths for overlooking entrenched medical misogyny, notably the pill’s coercive trials on uninformed Puerto Rican women whose serious side-effects were dismissed as psychosomatic and framed by racist stereotypes. She argues that the persistent labeling of women’s health concerns as “hysteria” reflects a legacy of violence and gaslighting. While social-media–driven activism echoes past movements and may surface some misinformation, Siddall insists medical practitioners must develop safer, rigorously tested birth-control methods rather than suppressing legitimate patient worries.

articles.title: Scrapping of two-child benefit cap closer as Bridget Phillipson attacks ‘spiteful’ policy
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Clearest sign yet No 10 is preparing to ditch policy as its preferred deputy leadership hopeful says issue is ‘profoundly personal’
articles.summary: Labour education secretary and deputy leadership frontrunner Bridget Phillipson has signalled the government is poised to scrap the two-child benefit cap after denouncing it as a spiteful measure that has pushed 1.7 million children into hardship. Keir Starmer has previously promised repeal when finances allow, and campaigners expect abolition in the 26 November Budget at a £3.5 billion annual cost. As co-chair of the child poverty taskforce due to report this autumn, Phillipson—backed by five metro mayors and major unions—seeks a mandate to make child poverty the party’s “unbreakable moral mission.” Rival Lucy Powell also supports repeal, intensifying pressure ahead of the final deputy leadership vote on 25 October.

articles.title: Assisted dying bill to get further scrutiny by Lords committee
articles.trailText: Special panel to address concerns over funding and implementation as legislation passes first stage in Lords
articles.summary: Peers approved the Assisted Dying Bill’s second reading without a vote; a dozen-member Lords committee—established after Labour peer Luciana Berger’s motion—will this autumn examine its funding, NHS and justice impacts, procedural safeguards, coroners’ roles and implementation. The bill would permit adults in England and Wales with under six months to live to request an assisted death, subject to approval by two doctors and a social worker, legal and psychiatric panel. Sponsor Charlie Falconer supports scrutiny but warns against killing the bill; critics like Elizabeth Butler-Sloss urge radical improvements. The committee reports by 7 November; if enacted, services must start by 2029.

articles.title: Probation Service failing to assess thousands who pose risk to women, watchdog says
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Chief inspector of probation says it is inevitable there will be more murders and rapes without an improvement
articles.summary: The Probation Service in England and Wales fails to assess and monitor about a third of the 160,000 offenders in the community—around 100,000 cases—creating tens of thousands of unaddressed risks to women and girls, warns HM chief inspector Martin Jones. His six-month inquiry found inadequate use of data, staff shortages and public protection deficits that make further murders, rapes and serious sexual offences inevitable without urgent reform. High-profile failures like Damien Bendall’s low-risk classification highlight the limits of electronic tagging. Jones urges improved interagency information-sharing and support for addiction, housing and employment. The justice minister pledges 2,300 new probation officers and a 45% budget increase by 2028.

articles.title: GPs in England: have you been reducing your hours or left the job altogether?
articles.trailText: We’d like to hear from GPs who have been cutting their hours or are planning to, and why, as well as from GPs who have left their jobs or will be quitting soon
articles.summary: One in three qualified GPs in England now practices outside the NHS—up from 27% in 2015 to 34% in 2024—leaving almost 20,000 doctors unavailable to the health service. Surge in private contracting, relocation abroad, widespread part-time working and looming winter strikes against proposed NHS reforms have weakened general practice. Two surgeries close each week (1,000 since 2018). The Guardian seeks firsthand accounts from GPs reducing hours or quitting, their motivations and alternative roles pursued.

articles.title: UK doctors guilty of sexual misconduct are not being struck off, research finds
articles.trailText: Analysis reveals 24% of guilty doctors handed suspensions but are allowed to keep working in medicine
articles.summary: Analysis of 222 Medical Practitioners Tribunal Service hearings (Aug 2023–Aug 2024) by the Royal College of Surgeons found 46 proven sexual-misconduct cases; in 11 (24%) doctors were suspended rather than struck off despite GMC recommendations. No sanctions exceeded GMC advice. All offenders were male, mostly in senior roles, with several cases of repeated abuse. Researchers and RCS leadership warn that inconsistent penalties risk public safety and trust, calling for urgent reforms—stronger tribunal training, victim support and clearer sanction guidelines—while regulators defend ongoing policy updates.

articles.title: Cost of private psychology soars in UK as practitioners turn away clients
articles.trailText: Prices have risen by 34% since 2022, with 29% of psychologists refusing new patients
articles.summary: Since 2022 private psychology fees in the UK have surged 34%, with 12-session packages now averaging £1,550 (up from £1,152) and per-session rates rising from £96 to £129.20. A survey of 349 practitioners shows 29% are at capacity and turning away new clients. Regional fees range from £164 in Leicester and £160 in London to £85 in Colchester, while waiting times span 16.9 days in Scotland to 23.8 in Wales. Record NHS mental-health backlogs (1.79m on community service waiting lists) drive one-third of patients private, prompting fears of a two-tier system as providers cope with cost-of-living pressures. NHS England plans to expand its talking-therapies workforce to reduce delays.

articles.title: NHS drug pricing is all about the art of the deal | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Better negotiation with big pharma could ease the process, writes Andrew Dillon , in response to an article by Polly Toynbee about Donald Trump’s complaints about NHS pricing
articles.summary: Former NICE chief Andrew Dillon rebuts Polly Toynbee’s “special circle of hell” depiction of NHS drug pricing, urging stronger negotiation frameworks. He acknowledges that new medicines, always pricier than predecessors, deliver incremental or transformative patient benefits and are routinely endorsed through NICE’s cost-effectiveness assessments. Although its value threshold dates back 25 years, NICE often flexes it to approve promising treatments. Dillon pinpoints slow NHS uptake and government–pharma profit caps as added hurdles, and calls for three reforms: an independent review of the threshold; binding uptake targets; and early pharma engagement with realistic launch prices in exchange for preferential cap terms.

articles.title: Nearly one in three single-parent households in Australia live in poverty, Hilda report shows
articles.trailText: Group nearly three times more likely to be in poverty than two-parent households, statistical report finds
articles.summary: Household, Income and Labour Dynamics in Australia survey found 31.3% of single-parent families living below the poverty line after housing costs in 2023—nearly triple the two-parent rate—and down from a 2022 peak but above the 25% share a decade ago. Co-director Roger Wilkins attributes rising poverty over 10–15 years to Howard and Gillard policy changes that shifted predominantly mothers off parenting payments onto lower unemployment benefits. He warns of a “silent crisis” affecting 34.7% of children in these households, highlights the lack of an official poverty measure and calls 2023’s extension of generous parenting payments to age 14 insufficient.

articles.title: Intersex people in Europe face ‘alarming’ rise in violence, EU finds
articles.trailText: Increase in violence since 2019 is linked to online campaigns seeking to sow disinformation and fuel hatred
articles.summary: An EU Agency for Fundamental Rights survey of 1,920 intersex respondents across 30 countries reveals a sharp rise in violence and harassment since 2019, especially among trans, non-binary and gender-diverse people. Physical/sexual assaults rose from 22% to 34%, and hate-motivated harassment jumped from 42% to 74%. Over half (57%) underwent non-consensual medical treatments, 39% conversion practices (versus 25% across all LGBTIQ), and 53% reported suicidal ideation (vs 37%). The agency blames online disinformation campaigns and urges legal protections for sex characteristics and targeted support.

articles.title: Scrap policy that gives refugees with leave to remain 28 days to find housing, say UK groups
articles.trailText: Halving time asylum seekers have to leave Home Office accommodation will make thousands homeless at time when ‘racist sentiment’ is on the rise
articles.summary: Over 60 UK homelessness and refugee organisations, including Crisis, Shelter, St Mungo’s and the Chartered Institute of Housing, have urged ministers Shabana Mahmood and Steve Reed to scrap a policy halving the move-on period for refugees with leave to remain from 56 to 28 days. They warn 28 days is insufficient to secure rented housing, employment and benefits, risking thousands of new refugees rough sleeping this winter amid rising racist sentiment. The letter cautions increased homelessness will strain local authorities and inflame community tensions. The government defends its wider asylum reforms and backlog reduction efforts.
